description:
I have lived in the Inner Richmond for 5 years. I have gone to Bunn Mi, pretty decent and Mai's good stand by as well and super friendly. Today I finally tried Little Vietnam (not sure why I took so long) and I have to say it was the best noodle bowl I have had. I had the 5 spice chicken and the chicken was mostly thigh, I think, and perfectly cooked. The pickled veggies were perfectly in proportion to the rest and with the smaller bowl I was not overwhelmed with noodles. 

This is my new go to. The service was friendly and truly appreciated and I will be back as I can eat bun many times a week.

Thank you. It was a pleasure.
author: J A.

description:
A great little spot for vegetarians!

I had the spicy vegetarian soup ($12) and it was loaded with carrots, broccoli, cauliflower, and two types of tofu! They've got a fish pho for any pescatarians out there and another type of vegetarian soup as well. 

There are four seats indoors and outdoor seating available. No bathrooms. Quick service and lots of foods you can pick up on the go. The popular items here are the banh mi and spring rolls.
author: Patty B.

description:
I had this place bookmarked and my boyfriend has been here previously so I was looking forward to trying their Banh mi. 

We ordered two sandwiches: a five spice chicken and a spicy lemon grass pork. For an appetizer, we got one of their ready made shrimp spring rolls with peanut sauce. It was the best thing we ordered. 

A woman from the kitchen brought out the sandwiches and placed some napkins on the table for us. It looked like the perfect sandwich so I was ready to dig in! They were served hot and the rolls were toasty. Like a traditional Banh mi it included long thinly sliced carrots and cucumbers, but only a lone jalapeño.

A few bites in, I noticed it was very dry. There was absolutely no mayo or pâté!! I was very surprised and asked my boyfriend if he had anything in his. There was a tiny smidge. We needed some kind of sauce to finish our sandwiches and luckily there was a small amount of peanut sauce left from our spring rolls. My boyfriend let me know there was a change of ownership. Wish I could've tried a sandwich from the previous owner.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Was here for lunch and enjoyed the banh mi and the tofu egg roll.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Banh mi sandwiches have been all rage recently, and Little Vietnam Cafe happens to be one of the fave in the city. To caveat, I only eat fish and veggie, so that's what I'll be reviewing here. 

Other banh mi spots in the city that have options that I can eat tend to be fish cake, tofu, or some sort of a shredded veggie situation, which isn't always a crowd pleaser. BUTTTT what I love about the fish option here is that it's a freshly breaded/fried lemongrass fish filet! REALLY great lemongrass flavor. Perfectly flakey fish. Yum. In previous visits, I've also come by for bun rieu aka crab noodles aka super delish. 

Service is very basic bc it's mostly a to-go spot. There are a few seats inside and outside, but not really a sit-down restaurant by any means. Sandwiches are def on the pricier side, which bothers me a bit when you can get these sandwiches for half the price elsewhere. I'm usually pretty happy w the banh mis overall, but today, the bread was a bit on the stale-esque side. I toasted the other half when I got home, and it was MUCHH better. 4 stars!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Price may be higher than Cafe Bunmi but portion size is also bigger so same value. I wonder if you can buy the $1 special sauce in May Wah. The grilled meats taste good, slightly less greasy than Cafe Bun Mi but not too dry. Both establishments are good.
author: Robert S.

description:
I went here the other week with my boyfriend to get some lunch. Upon entering, I observed that the shop was decorated for Halloween!! I love that...it's typical to see Christmas decorations year-round at Asian eateries but it's nice that this place kept up with the seasons. The restaurant is small, but there is a decent amount of seating inside and outside. 

The menu has a wide selection of Vietnamese food, including banh mi, spring rolls, rice dishes, and bun. I ordered a grilled chicken banh mi and my boyfriend ordered the lemongrass pork banh mi. I overheard quite a few people ordering the vegetarian spring rolls as well as the bun dishes. Sadly, the sandwich I had was definitely not the best banh mi. But still better than Lee's. My sandwich came with mayo instead of the typical butter that is in Viet sandwiches. There was also a bit too much cilantro and only one stick of cucumber. Also the baguette was just OK. The meat on the other hand, was fantastic!! If I were to go back I would probably try the bun since I know the meat will be good. 

Overall, this place is a bit pricey for Vietnamese food and the interior is a bit dirty. I'd come back here out of convenience if I'm in the area but it probably would not be a destination.
author: Kelly Q.

description:
Came here to eat today and had ordered my usuals, one of which included bun rieu. It turned out to be very bland today (they tend to be pretty inconsistent with the way they make their bun rieu here). So I went up to ask for some shrimp paste. It took them a while to get that to me as I was standing there in front of the register waiting. After going back to my table I realized I needed more lemon as well so I went back inside to ask for one more slice of lemon. The owner/cashier told me abruptly that I can't keep asking for one thing after another rudely, and that completely threw me OFF to the point where I told him to forget it. 
 
It's one thing where I'm intentionally being an annoying and inconsiderate customer asking like 3+ times for additional condiments but I wasn't. I simply didn't realize I needed more lemon until after. I'm a usual regular here at this place and I was astounded by how rude this person was to me today. I come here very often and he's usually pretty nice but now I probably won't be returning as much after this incident. Would much rather bring my business elsewhere where it's appreciated lol
author: Sunia L.

description: Small place good for grab and go food. They have Banh Mi, spring rolls with different toppings: pork, chicken, cold cut, tofu,etc. They also offer a variety of noodle soups. I was craving for Bun Rieu, an original Northern noodle dish. Here they made it with a Southern flare: the toppings include pork ham as well as the shrimp paste ball which was absolutely delicious. The broth has a strong shrimp paste flavor, which instantaneously made me salivate. A good amount of tomato wedges were included. The tofu slices were very thin though. I prefer a thick piece of tofu that is juicy when biting into it. This was not the case. This is one of the reason I gave 4 stars. Also the amount of noodles were meager compared to the amount of topping. I ordered the small size as recommended by the dude at the register, but it was too little for me. I read other reviews about inconsistency with this particular noodle dish. Maybe I was there on their good day. Hope for the best in my future visits.
author: Thuy V.

description: I don't know why its hard to find a HOT bowl of pho or just soups that are HOOOOT but this place sure does it.  Get the pho dac biet here and maybe other noodle soups but DONT get the garlic noodles unless you like eating mush.  The garlic noodles are just not up to par in the city so stick with pho.
author: Vince L.

description:
Banh Mi:

1. Soft pillowy baguette with thin crispy skin.                     Checked
2. Charred Juicy flavourful Grilled Pork                               Checked
3. Good balanced proportion of pickle and jalapeno          Checked
4. Extra galangal spicy sauce that works well with above  Checked
5. Good mayo and juice ratio                                               Checked
6. Good serving temperature                                                Checked

Wow, it fires on all 6 cylinder!!!! This is the best banh mi in san francisco!!!! so far!
author: Dan A.

description:
This place use to be a lot better before they remodeled. It's a tiny hole in the wall right by smart and final. There is literally only 5 seats inside. if you go on a busy day, be prepared to take your food to go.

My boyfriend and I usually get there combination pork banh mi with extra pate. The baguette has a nice toasty crunch to it. The meat was good, but I was kind of disappointed that they didn't fully spread the pate over the baguette. Felt like they skimped on the page even though we ordered extra. We also ordered bun rieu to share. It definitely had that home made taste to it. Definitely has a more traditional recipe than most places. Not the best bun rieu, but definitely a convenient spot to get quick noodle soup and sandwiches.
author: Ada H.

description: Small little place we happened upon after visiting Green Apple Books. Delicious and fresh pho (we tried beef and chicken), lemongrass pork ban mi and garlic chicken noodles. They had grab and go fresh spring rolls and other small noodle plates too.
author: Angie N.

description: Extremely expensive for a Vietnamese sandwich that was mediocre and had no real crunch to the bread. They sell individually wrapped spring rolls but $$$. Was it good? Meh. Was it worth it? No.
author: Julie L.

description:
Horrible experience. I gave the lady $40 for a total check of  $22.50, then decided against the order of two shrimp rolls for $6.50. 

Now my total was $16 for two chicken banh mi with extra meat. She owed me $24 back but gave me $14. I had to point out twice she owed me $10. Felt like it was intentional on her part. 

On to the sandwiches: AWFUL. The worst banh mi I've EVER had. I asked for extra jalapeños on both- I was given TWO SLICES TOTAL on BOTH sandwiches. I then sat outside in my car and began eating a sandwich. The bread was totally stale- at least one day old- and had apparently been briefly microwaved. It was simultaneously soft, tough, and chewy. The flavor of the chicken was good, but it was extremely dry and served cold. There was virtually no sauce, 2 slices of cucumber, and a miserly portion of pickled carrots.

I went back in and politely requested extra jalapeños. After a few minutes I was given a total of three more slices in saran wrap. 

I will NEVER return to this house of disrespect and pray my honest review prevents at least one person from suffering such a dispiriting experience at this establishment (where, previously, I'd had two good experiences and one other bad one).
author: Grizzle J.

description: I usually get the spicy beef noodle soup. I think the food here is pretty solid and I've never had issues with service. Prices went up recently. Definitely on the pricey side for Vietnamese food.
author: Connie S.

description: Had lemongrass pork sandwich, was a little too dry for my taste. Shrimp cocktail was OK. I know this is a new trend in Vietnamese cuisine , I guess I expected something interesting, but it turned out just a regular nothing interesting sandwich. I will have to try other banh mi places to have a final opinion on this trend.
author: Mel C.

description:
Compared to other Vietnamese place around Richmond-- a big nahh.. Came here because of the good reviews, but I was wrong. When I ordered, I asked "can i please have a grill pork sandwich", the lady was like "fried egg and pate also, very good" in 2 seconds... she talked so fast and without asking me, it was a statement that I HAVE TO add it. I didn't understand what's going on and she already told the kitchen to make it. 
Plus, a dish of garlic noodle with beef costs $14... $14 with that dish... wayyy overpriced... I prefer going to other restaurants to have a better seat. The whole place looks cheap ..
author: Minh H.

description: We've had them cater our weekly lunch once every quarter from as far back as I can remember (even before I took this role over almost 3 years ago)...and they never fail to disappoint! Occasionally they have been late in delivery, however Peter doesn't fret under pressure with our employees itching to grab a vermicelli bowl/lining up before notification of lunch being ready to serve is sent out. They never run out of food - occasionally run out of specific toppings (jalapenos, peanuts, etc.), but never fish sauce, soy sauce or proteins! Regardless, this is a favorite among our employees and as an inexpensive choice we will continue to have them return regularly!
author: Jackie E.

description:
I have tried the tofu bun mi and vegetarian pho several times and always enjoy both. The sandwich comes standard with mayonnaise, pickled veggies, jalapeños and cilantro; the best thing is that the sandwich is packed full of flavorful tofu. The pho is always fresh and they have chili oil, etc. you can add in if you would like. They also have a variety of pre-made spring rolls with peanut sauce you can grab and go. 

They accept card at this location with $10 minimum.
author: Mary S.

description: The food was so delicious and very vegan friendly!! I loved the vegan spicy tofu pho. The bahn mi was fantastic as well. Loved sitting at the window and people watching with my boyfriend. Definitely would recommend this cute place!
author: Emma D.

description: Super dirty and sticky inside. Pho lacks flavor. Better save your money and head somewhere else. Fully regret trying this place.
author: Roxanne C.

description: Best pho in SF so far. Phó Ga - Chicken that hasn't been frozen. Noodles that hasn't been sitting at the bottom of the bowl getting hard waiting for broth.  - fresh ingredients. The formula is simple. Why don't everyone do it. The downside is there are only 6 stools & sort a table & chair - so no proper place to sit.
author: Leung T.

description:
Among all the Chinese restaurants around here, you find this awesome place. Everyone in the back is Vietnamese cooking, making food authentic. The people are so nice here, you can't resist them. 
They have thick pho noodles, Banh mi, goi cuon, bun bowls, rice plates. It's nice and convenient to get great food at reasonable price. They are really great at to-go orders. 

The place is a little small so it doesn't accommodate large parties. You can sit outside on a nice day. They serve veggie broth and chicken broth for pho if you don't want the beef broth. 

At lunch time, they get super busy. The vermicelli bowl was good! And they had another noodle soup dish called bun ga that's really good! It's like bun rieu but with fish paste. Must try!  

Stop by if you are in the area. You won't be disappointed.
author: Jackie N.

description: Fabulous Pho Chay (vegetarian) and two other dishes.  Nice owner.  Outdoor seating. Ate here while walking north from the Calif. Acad. Science.  Local and delicious!
author: Maria C.

description: Great vegetarian pho that seems healthy and simple. They have a packaged version of all menu items so you can check out the quality and contents. Nice staff too!
author: Renee M.

description: Amazing. Admittedly, was not looking for much out of my lunch here. Assumed we'd stop in, order the Bahn mi, like it then move on. But this was phenomenal. I had the bahn mi with tofu, highly recommended. And the service was speedy and accommodating.
author: Matt M.

description:
In the area, and need some food before you really start to live up to that bumper sticker of yours that says "Zero to bitch in 0.2 second", try this place. It's super fast and easy to order. Simple and clear menu, and delicious vermicelli bowls. 

I find many Vietnamese places tend to overcomplicate things. It's really what sets Vietnamese food apart from other Asian food, its simplicity is what makes it unique, healthy and delicious. There is a delicate balance one must strike. Herbs, check; carb, check; protein, check; sauce, double check. 

Often people underestimate the power of sauce usage in Vietnamese cuisine. It's vastly important and must be fully appreciated if you intend to fully appreciate Vietnamese food. 

What I like about this little cafe is that it delivers the V. bowls in a delicate balance with uncomplicated flavors, then their light sauce serves as a pour over, toss it all up, you get a noodle salad with freshly grill meats, veggies and herbs.

Lady behind the counter is your typical sassy second generation Vietnamese American. Fluent in both languages, gives you non-nonsense suggestions, and communicate clearly as to what each of the over the counter items are as you are having trouble to decide which item to order. 

We both got our vermicelli bowls. His was lemongrass pork and crunchy roll, mine was a mixture of lemongrass pork and five spice chicken.

Used up all the little condiment sauces. Then I slather it all over with abundant sriracha sauce for added heat.

A quick lunch winner. 

All those walking-bys. Finally made it.
author: Victoria E.

description: Yummy I got to eat here. Cuz I found parking .. Wow remodel the place too.. Bun bo hue yummy not as spicy.. Also got 2 sandwiches and lemon grass fried tofu to go..
author: Crisy G.

description: Little Vietnam Cafe was alright. Most definitely a hole-in-the-wall. $10 minimum on a credit card. I ordered the chicken sandwich, which was good, but nothing to write home about.
author: Lauren A.

description:
3.5 Stars.

The folks that work/own this place are really nice. The food is pretty good and the prices are pretty nice....although a new clean menu board is going up and you know what that means.

Place is a bit of a hole in the wall..not the cleanest. 

The Banh Mis are good not great ( saigon is still the best). The bread is really good but the meats are just so so and they dont give you a lot of it. My pate is just a schmear ( old vietnamese verb) not a slab. My strawberry lemonade could have killed a diabetic....as the sugar was waaaayyy over the top.

Would I come back...yes as the vermicelli bowls and rice bowls looked pretty good.
author: David G.

description: I love the tofu sandwich, the vegetarian pho is on point, and the vegetarian spring rolls make my toes curl in ecstasy. The iced coffee is to die for! I love supporting this small business. There's always fast, great customer service. I heart you Little Vietnam!
author: Ashley N.

description: Always good service and good food! Love their spicy beef pho, and also like their beef pho. Every time I go to the farmer's market on Sunday, I will make sure to have my lunch there:)
author: Yuan Z.

description: I was on a serious search for some Vietnamese iced coffee, since American coffee isn't strong enough to keep me awake. With the help of Yelp, Little Vietnam Cafe came up and I'm so glad I came here. The coffee was extremely good! Strong enough to keep me awake, but sweet in taste! Exactly what I was looking for. Owner is extremely friendly and sweet!
author: Nina P.

description:
The space is pretty small, seats 5 inside and 10 outside. There was a dead fly lying on the table. The owners/customer service seems pretty nice, but what I'm basing my review off is the taste.

I ordered a beef pho where the broth is a little too salty and the meat was a bit dry. They did not provide basil, lemon, and bean sprouts like most pho places. My brother ordered a garlic noodle that seemed alot better than my pho. 

I have definitely had better pho and I would not come back, but try it for yourselves because everyone's tastebuds are different.
author: Selina G.

description: Bad service, they want you buy for $10 to use credit card. Confuse orders, then gave me wrong order.
author: Paul Z.

description:
Pho here was below average.  I believe the signature item here is the bahn mi however if you're gonna serve pho you should do it right.   

Broth 2 of 5 
Noodles 2 of 5
Beef 3 of 5
Portion 3 of 5
Price 3 of 5 

Don't let this review stop you from ordering the bahn mi (which I haven't tried) since it appeared to be a popular item.
author: Dan O.

description: I visited Little Vietnam Cafe for the first time recently and had the tofu banh mi. I really enjoyed it, and definitely plan to visit again soon!
author: Katherine N.

description: I think they were sold at some point, since I no longer see the owner behind the counter anymore. Their prices have gone up quite a bit, and their sandwiches aren't quite as good anymore (although they now offer some add-ons like a fried egg, which I guess is okay). It's really fallen out of my lunch rotation since the sale, though.
author: Doug T.

description:
Given the price point, it's worth your $$. Not a huge fan of their bread (baguette). However their rolls and sandwich filings taste fresh. 

Seating: They have a few patio tables outside
author: Alex P.

description:
In reality a 3.5 but I'll round up, Little Vietnam Cafe is one of those "only in SF or NY" type hole in the wall restaurants. Seating maybe 10-12 people max, Little Vietnam is hard to spot from the sidewalk because it is off of busy Clement St. located a few doors down 6th avenue. The restaurant appears to be run by an old Asian couple, the wife takes orders and works the cash register, while the husband brings food out from the kitchen. 

Eating in can be somewhat awkward because of how small the place is, but the food is very good! I had the beef pho which was delicious. Rich salty beef and bone broth, plenty of noodles, very thin slices of rare beef, along with the usual sides of hoisin, srirarcha, lime, beansprouts, jalapeños and mint leaves. The GF got the chicken pho which she enjoyed. We also split an order of the lemongrass spring rolls which were very good as well. The flavor was delicious but the bowls of pho were slightly smaller than the ones I am used to at other pho places I go to and priced the same. On the one hand this was a good thing as accordingly I could not over eat, and on the other hand I believe the prices are a tiny bit high relative to the proportions. 

The "restaurant" is tiny! So small in fact I have a hard time understanding why they offer "eat in" options. They basically have bar stool sitting for 6 and 2 teeny tiny tables that could seat 3 small people each, the tables are the sort you'd see on an outdoor patio. Almost looked child sized. I am approximately 6'2 I had to sit at the bar because I could not physically fit my legs under the table when seated in the chair. 


+1 Star Good beef pho, broth very savory and flavorful, beef very rare

+1 Star Good chicken pho and spring rolls. 

+1 Star Mostly reasonably priced (under 10$ for a bowl of pho) 

+1 Star A decent helping of local, family owned, SF charm

-1 star for how ridiculously small and awkward dining in here is. The man, when serving you, has to stand right behind you and literally lean over you and whoever you're eating with to set the food on the bar or down on the tiny little tables. I'd recommend doing take out.
author: Tomas K.

description: I like this place.  Very mom and pop as an elderly couple run it, where the husband mans the front counter and the wife does cooking duties in the back.  The food is solid, not spectacular but if you're looking for a quick Vietnamese lunch, look no further on Clement street because this place does service fast.  There's pre-packaged spring rolls and vermicelli trays to-go.  Sandwiches are made quick.  I prefer the grilled pork banh mi.  The sandwich itself isn't as generous in meat portions as their competitor, Cafe Bunn Mi.  But hey, on days where I don't want to queue up at Cafe Bunn Mi, I'll head over to Little Vietnam Cafe for faster and friendlier service.
author: Bailey N.

description:
This review is for office catering. I have not tried their food on location.

The food was okay, the service was horrible. The woman was pretty rude and not doing her job as asked.

The real reason I am giving this one star is for their health standards. I saw them unpack, set out for employees and RE PACK food that was left in open air and being served buffet style to take back to their restaurant. All while NOT being refrigerated. Not only is this shady, but it I am sure it breaks some health care violations.
author: Ninja R.

description:
Had a lot of expectations going into this place, but after leaving, my GF and I felt a little disappointed.  First off, the place is very small, a couple of tables for seating outside and like 5-10 very tight seats along the wall on the inside.

Price wise, I'd actually have to go $$ on this one.  It's fairly expensive for Vietnamese food.  A bowl of Bun Bo Hue or Pho will go around $8.80 - $9.30.  Banh Mi sandwiches are around $5.25 which is pretty steep considering these kinds of sandwiches are very simple.

I had the Bun Bo Hue, which is a spicy beef noodle dish.  I've had this plenty of times and I was not impressed with this one.  It's tough to review this one, because I'm use to the broth having a strong flavor with a hint of spice.  This one was bland to be honest.  Also, I've always heard food in Vietnam tend to be on the bland side.  So may be this is very accurate and representative, not sure.  Either way this was just OK.

My GF had the garlic noodles which turned out to be OK too.  These garlic noodles were really dry...SUPER dry.  It's not oily like other garlic noodles.  Sad to say, but it was a little on the bland side as well.  We have pretty bland taste buds too - we don't like strong flavors and even to us, it's bland!

The imperial rolls were pretty good - typical and is what I expected.  Sorry guys, but I'm going to have to say the fish sauce was on the bland side as well XD !  Fish sauce tend to be really strong but this one was very light.

Portion wise, it wasn't bad, we were full and satisfied.  Overall, I don't think we would come back.  It's just OK.
author: Kevin N.

description: I came pass by this area and I saw the Ha Long Bay painting outside the store. I miss Viet Nam so I decided to drop by and grab some Vietnamese coffee. I was really happy  to see some of my favorite Vietnamese food like the Pho and their spring rolls. I ended up not just having the coffee but tried the Pho Dac Biet and their Goi Cuon. Ngon qua(DELICIOUS)!
author: Brenda L.

description: Quick spot for Vietnamese sandwiches and vermicelli bowls. I stuck with the grilled pork on both and added the imperial rolls to the bowl. It was nice to see a bahn mi under 5$ but it could have used more of the pickled veggies. They were quick and very friendly - it looks like the take credit cards now which is convenient. They also had ready made spring rolls in the refrigerated section which is super handy for a quick lunch. Finished off with a strong iced coffee.  Good spot in the inner Richmond.
author: jennifer m.

description: I don't know WHAT you below four stars people are talking about! I was worried when I saw the recent reviews because I hadn't been back in a few years and was wondering if the quality had gone down; UH, NO!  The last time I visited I had a delicious veggie banh mi for about $5. No complaints. This time, I took a serious risk and got vegetarian pho. As a vegetarian, I usually just order pho tai, get the steak rare on the side, throw it in my husband's bowl and pretend that the bowl of meat juice I'm drinking is the one cow that died of natural causes that year :( I do all this because I was tired of being served bowls of hot, composted, flavorless garbage filled with weird, unnecessary vegetables like broccoli (BROCCOLI IN PHO :O). But I wasn't disappointed this time. LVC didn't just give me trash juice with scraps floating in it. The broth was complex and coconuty, more like tom yum than just plain veggie broth.  The tofu was braised, not just mushy, uncooked cubes carelessly tossed in. And there were APPROPRIATE veggies, like bok choy, in the soup. And not just a whole damn bok choy bunch tossed in (yes, I have been served a bowl of pho with a whole head of still attached bok choy, like an asshole) but actually chopped bite-sized. I can, without equivocation, say that it was the best bowl of veggie pho I've ever had and it solidified for me that yes, despite my whole life's experience, veggie pho can be a thing.  For what it's worth for you animal murderers my husband said the meatballs in his pho were delicious and velvety as well and that he could taste their sweet tiny screams. My husband is an asshole.
author: Sasha G.

description:
The perfect spot for your quick Vietnamese food fix. Friendly and attentive service and the pho sac biet broth was delicious. It speaks volumes when you try the broth before adding any other sauces and ingredients. I do wish there were a few more condiments for my pho, but not complaining. The pho portion is huge. 

Limited seating so I wouldn't recommend bringing more than 2 other people with you, but perfect for to go meals.
author: Kayla S.

description:
This is my go-to pho / banh mi joint when I need a Pho fix, or some real banh mi. 

I really like Cafe Bunn Mi on Clement, but everytime I try to go there it's packed. So I started coming here instead and now I just go here. It really is a special place.

The man you order and pay with is the man you always order and pay with. A very neighborhood place where people of all types come in here to grab a roll or a sandwich - lots of take-out. The man is very nice to all the patrons, definitely a lot of regulars comes here and he talks like he is proud of his food. (But not boasting or anything - it's more endearing.)

Peek inside the window where he shouts orders to in Vietnamese, and it's like you've got all of your surrogate Vietnamese grandmas and aunties back there cooking your food. I may not have a Vietnamese grandma, but today I do! She's asking me if I've eaten yet... and why haven't I?! So she plops down a giant bowl of Pho, and boy is it delicious!

With so many ....I'll call it... fusion... banh mi places popping up, you have to come to a place like this to get the real deal. To me, it's not a real banh mi, unless it's got strange meats on it with pate. They do them just the way I like it here.

Like I said, I like Cafe Bunn Mi - Their pho is good, but their "bunn mi's" are definitely the fusion variety. If you'd like to try the real deal walk a block down to Little Vietnam Cafe and give your surrogate Vietnamese grandma-ma a visit.
author: Bonnie H.

description: I'm vegan so got the tofu bahn mi and spring rolls and both were delicious. The sandwich comes with mayo so vegans be sure to ask for no mayo! The man who helped us was super friendly and helpful and service was super fast!
author: Katie B.

description:
Really nice experience here. My haircut lady down the street recommended it and I'm happy she did. 

The only other Vietnamese sandwich place I've had is Saigon in the tenderloin, which most say is the best. Honestly, my experience here was better. They have more meat options and the man at the register had a contagious smile. 

Service was nice and quick as well. Highly recommend if you're in the area. Only caveat is it's a bit pricier than Saigon. But still inexpensive.
author: Noah D.

description: Small but the food was delicious and the staff was very friendly. I had the vermicelli with grilled chicken and the spring rolls and both were made well and when asked, they took out ingredients I didn't like.
author: Elle D.

description:
This review is for the banh mi that was delivered to our office.

We had the lemongrass beef, lemongrass pork, and five spice chicken banh mi. The meat was pretty good, tasty and well seasoned. However, the sandwich itself was dry. The bread was stale, and there was too much cilantro in the sandwich (I aboslutely hate cilantro). 

I've definitely had better banh mi around! Considering that the meat was decent, I might try rice plates next time.
author: Christina N.

description:
How the holy hell is this place four stars?

As nice and well-meaning the operators are, their food is pitiful, i.e., listless, limp, stale vegetables in the pho and similar apathy in the five-spice chicken plate.

What a waste of money.
author: Inigo M.

description: Small diameter and underwhelming meat-to-bread ratio. I wasn't expecting mind = blown, but I evidently can't expect a halfway #eatheartyfortonightwedineinhell sando either. Especially for a chunk more $ than SF's top banh mis? More like banhizza please.
author: Dan B.

description:
My first impression of Little Vietnam Cafe was how quick the service was. We ordered our lunch and were instructed to sit outside since we were eating there. Not even a minute after we sat down, our banh mi were already in front of us! 

I got the Lemongrass Pork (Spicy) Banh Mi for $5.00 even. It was a decent size, which was great, and had that great crunch you get when eating a Banh Mi sandwich. However, it was a little difficult to eat because the meat was all stuck together and I kept pulling out the middle of my sandwich with each bite. By the end of it, I was stuck with too much bun, which was fine, just a little imbalanced I guess. 

My friend got one of their rice plates, which she said was disappointing. There wasn't a whole lot of flavor and the plate was sesame-city. 

Despite this, I did enjoy my sandwich, but it's not someplace I'd really go out of my way for. Oh, and they're CASH ONLY like most of Clement.
author: Cara O.

description: Love this place. The owner is the sweetest man. He likes to talk football and always tell each customer "See you soon!" The fresh spring rolls and banh mi are delicious. Make sure to add the egg!
author: Melissa T.

description:
this review is for the catering only!

i ordered a party platter of spring rolls for pickup for my sister's bridal shower. when i called the shop, it was very busy so i was told to email my order to littlevietnam@gmail.com. i was initially a bit skeptical about this, but decided to go through with it anyway. i was able to get a quick response within 15 minutes or so, so setup ended up being quick and easy.

i ordered 35 spring rolls - 12 chicken, 12 beef, and 11 shrimp, and requested each roll to be cut into three pieces for easy finger food accessibility. pickup time was 10am on a saturday morning, and total price was $115.

showed up at 10 am, and my rolls were perfectly arranged on a large platter, complete with three big plastic containers of sauces - soy sauce, sweet and sour, and the vietnamese vinaigrette. check my photo - this is exactly how the platter was arranged.

we were very pleased with the service and rolls, and they were a huge hit for the bridal shower! i would definitely use little vietnam again for catering! :)
author: Caitlin C.

description: what happen here?! I would always stop here and get my Bahn mi's... the last 2 times they were ok not much too it, (lack of flavor) but today ordered chicken, beef and crispy tofu Bahn Mi sandwiches and they were DRY ... bread stale and the chicken one had hardly any chicken!! Beef tasted old.. so disappointed.. BLAH......should have just waited to get back to Pacifica and go to Bunny's ! Best Bahn Mi's around by far...
author: michelle c.

description: This place is tiny. I'd for for at most 7 people at the bar seating by the window. They serve Northern Vietnamese pho which has was wider noodles (like Turtle Tower) and a much more mild broth. I usually order the beef pho, which is nothing I would wrote home about, but this time my expectations were let down. It tasted like my broth was watered down!  I also noticed there was a white residue floating in my water.
author: Joseph H.

description:
3.5 stars

Went to grab a beef pho and pork fresh rolls. Both were quite tasty, although the rolls weren't anything too special, they are quite lengthy though. The pho however, is quite unique, and I did enjoy the change from the usual pho flavours. The beef broth tasted quite good, and definitely tasted like it was stewed from beef, and not too salty which is great. The noodles are also different from your traditional skinny pho noodles. These ones were a a bit thicker, and tasted fine. 

Overall, this little joint is quite cheap and if you are looking for a Bahn Mi alternative give this place a shot. But if it is your first time, beware, it is quite 'little' and there isn't much in the way of seating spaces.
author: David C.

description: I kinda love this "little" place. Really decent and authentic 5-Spice Chicken bahn mi with fried egg this go-around.  Your only issue might be that it can be difficult to decipher what to do next, ie. pay, sit, wait for their next move. They are very nice, however. With experience one learns their quircky ways.
author: Rick W.

description: One the reason why I love this place is bc they serve some great Vietnamese sandwich I know from local area. Came to this place with my friend and love it!!!!! Must go place to grab a brunch during weekend!!!!
author: Toshio T.

description:
I really dig this place. I really do. 

Family-owned; extremely friendly people. 

Five-spice chicken bunh mi was exceptional.

Bun bo hue was, so far, the best I've ever had.

Now, if they served french fries....that would just be amazing. 

Can't go wrong with this joint. 

HIT. IT. UP.
author: Aren A.

description:
3.5 stars but rounding up since it's one of the better Vietnamese sandwiches I've had in a while. Little Vietnam Cafe is a tiny shop in the Inner Richmond, but they have a pretty extensive menu for such a small place. Some counter seating is available inside and some small tables outside.

We came in on a Saturday afternoon around 4pm to pick up banh mi for dinner that night. There was no line at the time, but a few people either eating outside or waiting for their to-go order. I opted to try the Five Spiced Chicken Banh Mi ($4.15, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/little-vietnam-cafe-san-francisco?select=Fe4sCZTBV11SaX3Cmqkz7Q#Fe4sCZTBV11SaX3Cmqkz7Q) which was good, but the chicken wasn't my favorite. However, I loved their mayo, and the pickled vegetables were also really good. The baguette was also solid. I tried a bite of my friend's grilled pork, which I liked better and would opt for that one next time. The people here are really nice, and they make your sandwich quickly (took 5-10 minutes), so I will definitely be back for more sandwiches in the future! My only complaint about coming here is that parking in this area is horrible, and even though there is street parking available, it's very difficult to find a spot on the weekends.
author: Amy D.

description:
I had Little Vietnam's very reasonably priced fancy pork banh mi, and it was KICK ASS.  Ratio of meat to pickled veg to herbs to bread was perfect.  Pork was nicely cooked and lean, and had a lovely grilled flavor. Bread was fresh.  

As a bonus, the sandwich was constructed well, so the meat didn't shoot out the other end when I bit into it.  My friend had the chicken curry, and it was also delicious.  I unreservedly recommend this modest but delightful little place for your Vietnamese sandwich needs.
author: Amanda C.

description:
I came to Little Vietnam Cafe kinda by accident.  My husband and I had a craving for some pho, and found the closest Vietnamese restaurant on Yelp.  We ordered a vermicelli bowl thinking that was pho.  It wasn't.  Then we realized that we should've ordered the soup.  Note to self:  if you're looking for pho, order the soup.

Anyways, the bowl itself was pretty delicious.  I got the lemongrass pork, which came with noodles and some greens.  Very tasty.

We also ordered some shrimp spring rolls.  Good sized servings.  Nice and fresh and a great peanut dipping sauce to go with it.
author: Gina J.

description: Decent bun rieu on this side of the bay. The soup was quite tasty as the herbs used in the broth had just the right kick in it. I have passed by this place all the time, however would not hesitate to come back again!
author: Tracy C.

description:
YELP MENU PRICING IS WAY OUT OF DATE!  

Food here is good, had the vermicelli rice bowl with imperial rolls and grilled pork, pork was cold by the time I brought it back to the office, that was my fault because had to go to the ATM first for yet another clement street cash-only venue.  Very nice old man was there to give me my food, and overall, it was a good experience eating here (cafe sua was excellent) the only real disappointment  was relying on the pricing listed online because

YELP MENU PRICING IS WAY OUT OF DATE!
author: Eric R.

description: I'm not often in this neighborhood but was glad to find Little Vietnam Cafe the other day while waiting to get my car repaired. Had a wonderful lunch plate with egg roll, noodle and a little salad. With a soda I think it came to about $7. Seemed like great value for a tasty and quick lunch!
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Flew into SF and went straight here with a friend. He knows I love banh mi and he wanted to see what I thought of this place.

Well I think it's awesome. I went with a lemongrass pork sandwich. In addition to all the regular fixins (carrots, peppers, cilantro, cucumber), I decided to add paté, a fried egg, and special sauce to my sandwich.

The combination was amazing. Gooey egg, salty, funky paté, and the delicious grilled pork were great choices. The green ingredients were all crunchy and delicious. With banh mi, the bread is key, and this bread is great. Crusty on the outside, soft on the inside. This was absolutely the best banh mi I've ever had, and I hope to see the little shop and proprietor going strong next time I visit.
author: Zach N.

description:
Well, it's been awhile since i visited clement street. I always loved the banh mi at little vietnam cafe. Today was different. I order the combo, always have, the chewy, gelatinous cold cuts sprinkled with pickled carrots, cucumber, cilantro and jalapeno. Pate is the mortar that holds the flavors together, binding the bread, veggies and coldcuts. Proper proportions are essential and today they were seriously off.

The pate was a quarter size smear on one side of the bun. The pickled carrots were sparse, one sprig of cilantro and gobs of mayonnaise. The predominant flavor of mayonnaise does not a banh mi masterpiece make. For that reason my review reflects a downgrade. I'll try somewhere else next time.
author: Kelly K.

description:
Great little spot to grab a quick bite to eat. We had a bowl of pho and the pork vermicelli noodles--definitely hits the spot! The noodles were so delicious and tender, the broth packed with flavor.

I will definitely be coming back!!
author: Vanessa S.

description: Came here with a friend for lunch yesterday. The beef combo pho is on point -- thick noodles, lots of meat and quick service. Extra points for the outdoor seating and fair prices. Will definitely be back on the next rainy day.
author: Allison D.

description: My favorite go to spot for Vietnamese sandwiches. For a little bit extra you can add a fried egg to it!
author: Paul K.

description: Very good. We had a tofu and chicken sandwich. Taste great. You come in,get your sandwich and go. Few seats indoor and outdoor. Owner is really nice. Must try.
author: Galois G.

description:
Little Vietnam Cafe is a small step up cafe offering take out. only a few seats for sitdown

menu: banh mi, noodles, ready made snacks, bites, rice plates, spring rolls, soups, etc.

eats: spicy meatball banh mi (4.15)
-large banh with  gray looking pork hash filling, lots of it
-surrounded by the usual veggies and jalepenos
-pork had no taste beyond the sweetness of the  msg and spiciness
-sammie made to order
-4 star value, taste 3 stars for too much msg.

crumbs:
-some snacks premade
-fast, friendly service.
author: Victor G.

description: Great little spot whenever your craving pho or sandwiches, it's pretty good here when I first tried this place I got a viet sandwich and it was bomb, the bbq  pork was soo good and the bread was crispy.
author: Tommy L.

description:
Recently moved to the bay area a few months ago, and i'm slowly getting the idea that a lot of asian places only takes cash. So it can be inconvenient at times. 

However, hands down to the best garlic noodles ever!! It had so much flavor and it was available at such a great price! It's too bad that wasn't my dish. :(  I ordered the vermicelli noodles with grilled shrimp and the boyfriend ordered the garlic noodle. I've had better vermicelli noodles but it was worth a try! Must try the yummy looking pho next time..
author: Lisa H.

description:
I thought it was okay. Better than some other places I've tried, but not as good as Saigon Sandwiches in the 'loin.

They do use fresh ingrediants, like whole pieces of chicken & beef, rather than the shredded stuff, so that's definitely a plus. I love, love the bread. It was toasted and had the right chewiness & texture. However, it definitely could've been bigger / more stuff inside. It was on the smaller side for the price ($4+).
author: Alysha K.

description:
Cute little hole in the wall!
I was in the area and walked past this place and saw a decently long line. I originally wanted pork buns around the corner, but that line was insane. This was about 5-7 people deep and banh mi sounded very appealing to me after seeing this spot, so I decided to wait. 
The line goes by quickly, they have some things on the menu you order and some quick grab and go items (i.e. spring rolls and salad). It's an older couple who works here. The nice older man works the front counter, takes your order, passes it on to the woman in the back, and quickly adds up the total for your order, and within 3-5 minutes you get your food from the back. I got two lemongrass pork banh mis, grabbed a pack of spring rolls, and got two water bottles for $20 even. The sandwiches were delicious as were the rolls. I really like this place because of the set up and the friendly old man who quickly gets through the line in an orderly manner. It's a nice spot to go to- support your small local shops!
author: Lori C.

description:
Not the best pho, the noodles were kinda mushy, the broth was average, and the toppings were very sparse.

Also, the inside of the restaurant smells a little like bathroom. Yuck.

If you're visiting, I'd recommend trying the bahn mi instead.
author: Jess C.

description: Good Banh Mi, reasonably priced. Based on 1 visit, I will try other sandwiches.
author: Michael C.

description:
This is my new favorite Vietnamese restaurant. It's so delicious I would even take my very persnickety Vietnamese parents here. 

My friend and I soaked up the sun while eating our delicious bowls of lemongrass roasted pork with vermicelli and egg rolls. It was so good, we stopped talking and ate in silence. I've had their Vietnamese sandwiches, and those are also delicious. Love. The service was friendly and prompt, but the food was the star.  

Casual, tasty, reasonably-priced, and I love supporting small family run businesses. Win-win-win-win.
author: Tina T.

description:
Had a bahn mi craving, and went to get it fixed at Little Vietnam. 

Let's break it down:

The bread - fluffier (if that's not a word, it should be) but still as crunchy as other bahn mis. 
The filling - I ordered the housemade meatball, the hus got lemongrass pork. Both were generous, tender, super tasty, well seasoned.
The condiments - excellent, crisp carrots, fiery peppers, fresh cilantro
The ambiance - friendly, no frills, counter seating, everyone is near enough that you see what they are eating and immediately have food envy that you did not order the spicy beef noodle on the one day that it has rained in the past 3 months. 

Solid bahn mi, we'll be back to try the other fare.

A lot of people get take out, so the place has a nice flow of people but they are very quick with orders. We waited like a total of 4 minutes and our fresh sandwiches appeared.

And I have to say, sitting there the folks that run this place are SUPREMELY nice and polite (some guy came in and ordered the five spice chicken rice plate with no pepper, no garlic, no salt, no rice and extra chicken and the lady was like 'SURE!'). 

ps. I think this place is better than Cafe Bunn Mi!
author: Subie C.

description: So far my favorite vietnamese sandwich spot in the inner rich.  The combo in particular is my favorite and reminds me of an old Richmond favorite that closed down many, many years ago - Little Paris.  Only 4 stars since service can be slightly slow but all in all I go back quite frequently.
author: Meredith K.

description: Ordered the lemongrass pork bahn mi and it was delicious had to take another one to go for safe measure lol. My order was done lightning fast will come here again.
author: Bryan P.

description: So good. Me and my dare had are food to go. I can't wait to come here again I thought all the food was good.
author: Seaera T.

description:
Great little place with good bahn mi sandwiches and a great selection of desserts. Other items I've had there are alright but I've stuck with the sandwiches for years. Very friendly service and convenient location. However, very limited indoor seating, and although they have outdoor sidewalk seats it's fairly noisy and dirty as that's a busy street with the 44 bus line. 

I mostly go because I like the sandwiches (gotta get extra jalapeño!!) and the old guy's smile has merit. 

WATCH OUT if you try parking in Smart and Final's lot! Although you'll be tempted because it's "only a few minutes" I've heard they are pretty quick with the parking penalties there.
author: T J.

description:
While running an errand nearby I tried to think of any places I had bookmarked on Yelp to try.  I recalled a deli on 6th Ave. and in my search I found Little Vietnam, another bookmarked spot.  

I ordered the Lemongrass Pork sandwich for $4.15.  It came fairly quickly and was nice and warn, wrapped up to go.  Luckily it was still warm when I arrived home, with the bread still crunchy.  The sandwich was filled with a generous portion of tasty slices of pork.  It came with the usual fresh vegetables and the proportion of meat to veg was spot on.   I thought it was big enough that one sandwich was just right.   I've been to some places where there are more vegetables than meat or the sandwiches are so small I needed more than just one.  the bread had just enough crunch for me, not so much that it was going to take out the roof of my mouth, but enough to give the sandwich the right texture.

I quite liked the sandwich.  I don't know that I would go out of my way to eat here but I would certainly consider stopping by if I were in the area.  They offer other items on their limited menu that are prepared or made to order, with some items for vegetarians.  I did like this sandwich more than the ones from Irving Cafe.
author: Melissa L.

description: One of my favorite spots in the hood. My partner and I always share the garlic noodles and the lemongrass fish sandwich. Delicious and inexpensive!
author: Jenn F.

description:
My youngest sibling drove me all over town to run my errands while I was sick. As his reward, I said I would treat him to lunch, anything he wanted. He said he wanted something that was not too expensive because he didn't want me to spend too much money. Bless his heart. Although he's a brat sometimes, he's a good kid.  
If he had wanted a 5 course meal I wouldn't have minded.

Anyway.

We stumbled upon Little Vietnam Cafe because he had a craving for banh mi.

Banh mi is just so so. The bread cut up the roof of both of my brothers' mouths. I took one bite and didn't like it. Not enough pate for my liking.
I had gui cuon (spring roll) and they were on the dry side 

This place is so so.
author: Susy C.

description:
Discovered this spot (luckily in my neighborhood) after beloved Tu Lan closed a few years back. I have to say it's some of the best Vietnamese I've ever had.

5 star dishes:
- Green papaya salad with any of the meats selection or just plain
- vermicelli bowls with 5 spice chicken or pork
- Spicy beef pho
- Banh Mi- 5 spice chicken and pork are outstanding. Great bread, sauce and proportions of ingredients.
- TOFU BANH MI! YES! and I'm not even much of a tofu fan
- LEMONGRASS FISH SANDWICH. OMG! Seriously the best banh mi sandwich I've ever had. The only reason I don't order it every time I go there is because it's fried.

Not much for atmosphere here but we often like the outdoor tables for a quick, inexpensive bite. Counter seating only inside.

Cash only. David the owner and his kids that work the counter are all sweet as pie. Super quick service and food is ready minutes after ordered but always prepared fresh.

I go here at least 3 times a month. It's the bomb. Try it.

I only wish they sold beer. But you can't have it all.....
author: S. W.

description: This place is soooo good! Their home made chicken soup and tofu rolls always hit the spot! I work on 6th ave so I've been checking out all the little restaurants near here on my lunch break, the food here is very fresh and healthy so it doesn't weigh you down and keeps you running at work! I come here almost everyday for lunch! :-) The workers always greet you with a smile and always take the time to wish you a great day! Love coming here!
author: Kristen B.

description:
I adore Little Vietname Cafe for their sandwiches. I haven't tried anything else here but the sandwiches certainly don't disappoint. 

For a budget friendly $4.15 you get a perfectly crunchy baquette filled with flavourful spicy lemongrass beef or pork. Delicious! 

The staff is always friendly and the service is great.
author: Leanne S.

description:
[warning: haiku attempt]

Pork Banh Mi was meh.
Bread was not very crunchy.
Overall? Two Stars.
--------------------------------------

[in other words...]
I was disappointed today, as I've usually had decent meals here.
Perhaps an off day? Kinda troubling when I get those...
author: Derek N.

description: This is my go-to spot for banh mi. The bread is fluffy on the inside and crackles on the outside.  A bonus with this spot is you can always add extra veggies, and meat. This is a quick in-and-out counter spot, although if you're luck you can snag a seat outside on a sunny day. My only gripe about this shop is they close pretty early--so no dice if you're in the mood for grabbing a bite for dinner.
author: Andrew L.

description: Had one of the best meat ball Vietnamese sandwich here last week for lunch. So good with the addition egg add on.
author: Phi N.

description: Super homey, casual shop with maybe 6 seats inside? Mostly for takeout. It was a cold rainy day which was perfect for pho but also felt too cold to eat at the drafty bar. I think we got a chicken pho and garlic noodles? It was satisfying but nothing mindblowing.. so I don't really remember. I'd go back though, they were super nice and I like these cute mom-and-pop joints.
author: Vivian H.

description:
The banh mi sandwiches get only 3-stars, the additional star is for the noodle bowls, rice plates and soups. I'd order only the meals here, the best meat choices are the lemongrass pork or the BBQ chicken, forget the beef. The imperial rolls are only okay, better elsewhere. There's a few seats inside if u choose to dine in.

The bread is the weak link in their sandwiches. The cold banh mi (ham, pate, fancy pork) are $3.50, while the hot banh mi (chicken, pork, beef, meatball, tofu) costs $4.50 - that's a bit high, considering that most top places charge around $3-3.50 or less. And u don't have to go to the TL area to get that either. Y & Y Vietnamese Deli, just one block away, makes much better banh mi for around $3.20 in this area.
author: Luis C.

description:
I gave it 3 tries in 12 months.  The first 2 times, grilled pork in the bahn mi was not hot.  It used to be hot with an aroma that would make your mouth water.   Today, the pork was barely warm and very salty.

I also didn't appreciate having the bahn mi  slapped into my hand without a thank you or eye contact.  Not even a napkin!  She was too busy chatting it up with her friend.

I'm all in favor of supporting mom & pop businesses, not this one.  Three misses in a row.  My bad luck.
author: Debbie T.

description:
Delicious banh mi.  Excellent price.  Good portions.  Clean establishment.  

The storefront is small, with a few seats for people eating in, so perhaps grabbing and going is a better bet.  I stopped in for the lemongrass pork banh mii the other day for lunch to go.  There was a bit of a line, but things moved quickly, the father and daughter taking the orders and manning the cash register were very friendly, and the other patrons all seemed happy with their food.  

A few menu options were prepackaged and sitting on the counter for immediate purchase, but my sandwich was prepared and wrapped fresh, still warm when I got back to work to eat it.  Nice crusty bread, good portion of meat and veggies, fresh cilantro and jalapeno slices, and a tasty aioli made this a sandwich I'd definitely order again.  They apparently also take credit cards now, but the prices are low enough that you're likely to have enough cash on hand anyway.  

I will definitely be back for a quick banh mi and maybe i'll even try the other flavors, but why miss out on a good standard?
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
Friendly staff.  Mediocre soups.  Good sandwiches.

We came here looking to get some morning pho.  They were supposed to open at 9am, but they actually weren't quite ready yet at that time.  We came back a little while later after getting some coffee and ordered, then sat down.  All the staff there was attentive and friendly, and our food was served FAST!  Unfortunately, it wasn't all that great.

We tried the spicy beef soup, combination beef soup, and a beef rice plate.  I don't know if they call these things on the menu by these names instead of bun bo hue or pho etc because theyre not supposed to be those things or what, but they definitely weren't exactly what we were expecting.  The spicy beef soup wasnt very spicy, and didn't have any of the big chunks of tendon etc that I'm used to in bun bo hue.  The combo soup was relatively bland, not much there.  The beef rice plate we got was also very bland, and too fatty.  I don't usually mind fat, but when there is lots of fat and still no flavor, es no bueno.

Just so I could have a taste of everything, I ordered a couple sandwiches to go.  A few hours later, I ate my combo vietnamese sandwich.  It was delicious!  And pretty big!  It was exactly how it should be, with pickled carrots, pate, headcheese, ham, cilantro, jalepenos, etc.  They're cheap too, at only $4.10 per sandwich.  My only complaint is that the guy asked me if I wanted it spicy, and I said yes, but my sandwich had no heat at all.

If I were to come back, itd just be for sandwiches.  No more soup for me!
author: Jon B.

description:
Had the 5 spice chicken banh mi made Peter's Way, and boy did it taste delicious!  Who ever knew an egg would complement banh mi so well?  The banh mi was packed with flavor and had a complex mix of textures -- from crunchy bread, to crunchy bread, to crispy veggies, to wet mayo/sauce, and to light & delicate parsley.  I definitely was in for a treat.   The only complaint that I had was that the chicken skin was not crispy - I like my 5 spice chicken baked to a tender crispness.  So while I was enjoying the flavors and textures of my sandwich, I did not enjoy biting into chewy chicken skin/fat.  

I also had the fresh-squeezed limeaide which was really good too, albeit a little pricey considering the price of limes.  It tasted similar to the limeaide you can buy at Safeway, so I am hoping they did not use that pre-made stuff to make their limeaide otherwise it'd be a total rip!

Overall, this place is a great find and everyone who works here is very friendly.  Just be careful that whoever is helping you is entering your items correctly because they sum everything up using a calculator - just in case an item might be incorrectly punched in.
author: Matthew L.

description:
I like this place way better than the famous Saigon Sandwhiches in the TL.  Obviously cleaner, larger, way less ppl, and the people who work there are a lot more friendly.  

When suffering from an uncurable alternate reality hang over, I always have the urge for a sandwhich.  Either Freddy's by the ocean or Little Vietnam, where I am free to squirt cock sauce all over what I am about to put in my mouth. ooooh E.  Make a stop at The Hemp Center on Geary,  then head to 6th street for Coconut water and Banh Mi. 

Always get Tofu and Veggie, perfect ratio of ingredients, fresh, clean and super quick and casual.  Large portions and I always leave with half, which I will later devour when the sickly hangover cloud comes back.  

The only good part of being hung over.
author: Chelsey G.

description:
Officially, my new spot for Best Banh Mi in SF!

I ran into this place out of desperation, actually.  I was waiting to pick up and order around the corner and felt my blood sugar dropping.  I needed something fast, quick, and satisfying (that's what she said) I saw this small shop that reminded me of place in PI - A small set of stairs, leading to what looked like a small counter.  Sort of like a Carinderia that you would see on any street in PI. The chicken sandwich came out in less than a minute and it met all my requirements for a Best Banh Mi Award:

1. Roll was warm, semi-crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside
2. Meat (chicken) was warm, well seasoned, and there was an abundance of it
3. The veggies were present, but not so much as to overpower the meat, which was the star

BOOM! Locked and Loaded, baby.  After having one of their sandwiches, I had to bump Saigon Sandwiches down to 2nd place.

Their specialty is Banh Mi, but they also do have pre-packaged meals - rice rolls, spring rolls, bbq'd meats, i even saw one that had garlic noodle with 5 spice chicken! 

I've been here several times since that first time last year and the taste has always been good  Consistency is as important as the taste for me, so this is definitely my new spot for Best Banh Mi in the city!
author: Ray R.

description: I was starving and ate a  BBQ pork banh mi while driving home. It survived about 3 lights before it was gone. Most of it made it to my stomach although a fair amount landed on my stomach. It was cheap, it was fast and it was good ( like no pâté yuck.)
author: El B.

description:
This shop is pretty small and quaint. No frills. There's limited seating inside and outside.

Menu is pretty standard. Prices are reasonable. Cash only. Wait time is between 5-10 minutes.

The sandwiches are hit and miss. Sometimes they come nicely toasted bread, filled with lots of meat and veggies, other times they're cold and not spicy even after biting into the green pepper. The spring rolls are really good.

Family owned business. The owner usually behind the register, an older gentleman, is always friendly. The frequent buyer card is also a nice touch.
author: Bonnie Y.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE! it's my new neighborhood spot that reminds me a 'taste of home'.

i think it's cash-only. super, super friendly service.

i love their vermicelli bowls - esp the lemongrass pork. portions are big. and i like to add eggrolls.

their bun rieu is a bit bland, so i'm staying away from the soup based items and going for the bowls and sandwiches.
author: Vanae W.

description:
Another one of the many local restaurants that used to cater for our company, I've tried my fair share of their vermicelli bowl and pho offerings. Personally, I'm not a fan of their pho: the broths are all a bit bland, and the flavors are a bit off. Serving raw meat with broth that isn't hot enough also means that, not only is the meat not properly cooked, the pho also isn't as tasty as it could be, so many a time, we'd have to pop our bowls into the microwave.

Their vermicelli bowls, on the other hand, have always been quite tasty. I can't say I've been adventurous enough to try the shrimp, but their pork, chicken, and tofu options (and sometimes all three at once) have always been quite satisfying.
author: Johnny W.

description:
$4.00 for a Banh Mi sandwich...are you kidding me?

I mean the Lemongrass Chicken Sandwich was very tasty and the meat was flamed really well. But $4.00 for a Vietnamese sandwich seems really high...considering this small little shop is the only Vietnamese deli within the radius of the busy Clement St.-strip. 

Not a bad tasting sandwich, but the busy Clement St.-strip have other options for lunch!
author: Matt G.

description: This is one of the better places I like for banh mi.  Their vegetable slaw has a really nice jalapeno kick.  Even though it's on the pricier side for a Vietnamese sandwich, I like the hefty portions and the flavors.  I know most people in SF are a fan of Saigon Sandwich, but I personally always liked this place more.  It's right by Green Apple books too, so grab a sandwich, peruse some books, and enjoy the hidden delights of the Inner Richmond.
author: Debra C.

description:
lil hole in the wall... no bathroom.. nice patio, 
chicken pho... was good.

just an average pho spot.. nothing much else

Their togo plates looked good though
author: Dubl A.

description:
If you're not into paying over five dollars for Banh Mi, but looking for a high quality lunch in the Richmond District, Little Vietnam Cafe is the way to go. 

For a mere $4.15 plus tax, you get a well sized, freshly toasted French roll filled with slightly sweet, slightly acidic pickled carrots, jalapeños and daikon, and exceptionally tender, well spiced meat. While they're famous for Five Spiced Chicken Banh Mi (which honestly may be the best in the city), the lemongrass pork never has disappointed me with its delecate interplay of well-heeled citrus notes and slightly charred exterior. Neither one of these options are overly salty, and the ratio of meat to veggies is absolutely perfect.

If your feeling spendy, order your Banh Mi with "Peter's Special". Despite sounding like an act you would find in the pages of "Fifty Shades of Grey", the extra $1.25 will get an over-easy egg and a generous dose of "special sauce" added to your lunch. The rich flavor of the cholesterol-endowed egg helps immensely to unify the textures and flavors of the sandwich, while the fish-sauce and garlic based jus seeps into the bread, imparting every bite with a fantastic marriage of flavors not to be found anywhere else in the City.

On the non-sandwich side of things, their Bun Rieu ($8.00)--featuring generous servings of crab, egg and tomato--is the Richmond's ultimate comfort food. Served piping hot and with a side of vermicelli noodles, the soup is extraordinarily filling, and an absolutely delightful panacea against the cold and foggy nights pervasive in the outside lands.

Service in this family-run restaurant is superb, with sandwiches and soup coming out quickly. Everyone is exceptionally friendly, and the owner (who works the counter) doesn't forget a face.

Five Stars: Excellent Sandwiches, excellent Bun Rieu, and excellent service makes this hole-in-the-wall one of my favorite places to grab a lunch on the go.

Extras:

-Outdoor tables available. Counter seating inside.

-Their Vietnamese Iced Coffee is remarkably potent.

-Spring rolls and Salads available.

-Near the 1 California, 2 Clement, 44 O'Shaugnessy, and 38 Geary.
author: Casey U.

description: Really really good food! Freshly made and very delicious. Even prices are ok. Portion size is ok, too, but could have been bigger. Had noodles with shrimps. Photo is attached afterwards.
author: Maike D.

description: If you want a bahn mi sandwich fast, this is the place to go! Bread is too crunchy for me so there are a ton of crumbs inside my keyboard at work, but it was still good! Sandwiches are cheaper then the other bahn mi place down the street! Support this little Mom & Pop shop!
author: Darlene M.

description:
This place had been voted best Vietnamese sandwiches in the city by SF weekly and so we were disappointed to find that it was just okay.

We ordered the pate banh mi (sandwich) and the lemongrass pork + grilled shrimp vermicelli along with a vietnamese iced coffee (all for $15). The baguette for the sandwich was quite soft and the flavors seemed dumbed down compared to a previous visit. Ditto for the vermicelli bowl. In both cases the pickled carrots were the highlight and added the most flavor.

Overall the food was just average, which we've set as our 2 star rating. A visit a long time ago would have rated a solid 4 stars but this visit was fairly blah.
author: Amy D.

description: I LOVE Little Vietnam Cafe. It's so cheap, the sandwiches are simple but amazing, the owner is so kind, and it's completely underrated. Only downside is that it closes early each night so you can't really eat there after work but it's great for the weekends or days off!
author: Ashtyn B.

description: Still a yummy place, great value & owned by the same family.  They make your banh mi to order so it's fresh & the meat is warm.  Not skimpy on the meat either.  Last time I also picked up a garlic noodle plate with stir fried chicken to enjoy for another meal.  If you're in the area, by pass the less traditional (& more expensive) places on Clement & head to this place.
author: Kim S.

description:
There once use to be a Little Paris where all my vietnamese sandwiches would come from.  Now maybe 10 years later, that Little Paris is no more and the next best place according to my sister is Little Vietnam Cafe.  

Well.....I still miss Little Paris, but maybe its because of the feeling of nostalgia, but Little Vietnam isn't quite cutting it.  We had the chicken sammy and pork sammy.  Pretty much the usual banh mi in my opinion.  Prices were a little steeper closing in at the $4 mark and we also got a side of fried tofu which was made fresh every day.  It actually tasted fresh, but not quite that good.   Think my banh mi go to in the Richmond remains a mystery.  The search continues...
author: Vincent K.

description:
I was driving one day, during my lunch break and came across this place. So I decided to give it a try because I never really tried a good Vietnamese sandwich. 

Very yummy sandwiches! I ordered the 5 spice chicken sandwich and it definitely brought out its flavor in each bite. It was pretty spicy, but that's mostly what made the sandwich taste good.
author: Julia K.

description:
Ordered the combination banh mi. It came within a few minutes and like others have said, their banh mis are a little too hard and crunchy for my liking. I'm used to having the bread toasted and warm upon pick-up, but mine came cold :( - I feel like they mass-toast their baguettes earlier in the day to save time, which could explain why their baguettes can be a little on the hard and cold side. 

In terms of the contents, mine had a good meat to vegetable ratio and it wasn't bad at all. But because of the crunchiness and hardness of the bread, it's so messy to eat and there were crumbs everrryyywhere! Since I was eating outdoors, I had a flock of birds surround me by the time I finished because of all the crumbs that fell to the ground.
author: Tee C.

description:
After walking for 20 minutes looking for a place to eat, my boyfriend and I settled here.  The prices were just right and they had a pretty large menu for being such a small place.  There are less than 10 seats available inside, so it's primarily to-go.  

I got the meatball sandwich and my bf got the Vietnamese ham sandwich.  We also shared the imperial rolls. The service was friendly and speedy.  We were out of there in less than 5 minutes.  I think they secretly had the whole family working back there.  

I really wanted to like the food, but the meatball sandwich was mushy.  The imperial rolls were pretty good, but they weren't as crispy as I would like then to be.  I definitely want to try their vermicelli bowls next time.  No more sammies from them anymore, though.
author: Lisa X.

description:
This place is awesome. It only seats about 5 people inside (and has 3 tables outside) but it seems to be a very popular take-out spot. 

I had the vermicelli bowl with pork and it was fantastic. It was also only $6.

I would highly recommend it if you are in this part of town. 

The young cashier is also very friendly and helpful, which is always a plus.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Background: Little Vietnamese owned Banh Mi place right off Clement and 6th. They sell Banh Mi, noodles - dry and soupy, and fresh spring rolls.

Details: Got Iced Coffee ($3.00) - super strong not too sweet, but will get you wired. And Spring Rolls: Tofu, Sweet Potato, Egg, yum + their dipping sauce. Pretty good, the veggies were fresh and clean and the wrapper wasn't dried out - still nice and chewey ($4.50). There's two in a set, but each spring roll is pretty long about 8 inchs so you'll be full!  Banh Mi's are $4.15 and come in a variety: chicken, vegetarian, combo etc. Lots of vegetarian options here! 

They have a few tables for people inside and then a few outside. Great on a sunny day!  Super Casual. Most people run in grab food and run out. 

Verdict: Overall, would definitely come here again! Cheap. fast  and efficient.  Cleanliness is questionable, though.
author: Christine B.

description:
My fiance and I went to a tea-tasting at Aroma Tea, which is right across the street from Little Vietnam Cafe. We were planning on going someplace else for lunch, but thought we'd check out their menu for future reference. One of the customers waiting for his order told us how great this place is, and since they had lots of vegan options, we decided to stay. 

We ordered: (1) Banh Mi Chay sandwich with tofu (no mayo) (2) Vermicelli Bowl with tofu and a fried spring roll and (3) fresh jicama rolls. 

I have to say that everything tasted super fresh, flavorful and amazing! Out of everything, my favorite has to be the vermicelli bowl (which was like a deconstructed fresh spring roll). Their prices are very affordable, which is nice b/c you can try a few different things in one visit. Also it should be noted that they have limited seating, but usually if you wait a few minutes, tables become available. 

I can't wait to go back and try their other veg options!
author: Kelly L.

description: My work catered from Little Vietnam and I was excited to try a vietnamese banh mi sandwhich! Since, I'm vegetarian, I had the tofu bahn mi and the tofu spring roll. The bahn mi sandwich bread was really flaky and fresh tasting. However, the fillings inside were not as flavorful as I'd like. The tofu was quite bland and it should have been seasoned a bit. The bahn mi had a cool refreshing taste because of the cilantro/pickled carrots but it just need a kick of spice to add to the flavor profile. The tofu spring roll was my favorite. It paired perfectly with the peanut sauce! Overall, decent place but the sandwich needed a hefty kick of spice in its rear end! Just sayin.
author: Avni A.

description: The spring rolls here are a must. They let you pick which ever 2 rolls you like so you can mix and match which is a major plus! My go to are grilled chicken, pork, and this red meat patty one but I forgot what it'a called. I prefer to eat them all with fish sauce. The service is always friendly and excellent here. I definitely recommend this place!
author: Sherry H.

description:
Wow this place really surprised me. I think this is one of my new go-to places when I'm craving some noodles. Not a whole lot of seating room. There are maybe two bar seats against the window and four small round tables outside. No wonder they are advertised as "Authentic Vietnamese Food To Go". 

Tried the "Homemade Chicken Noodles" and the bf had the "Homemade Beef Noodles". Both were very good. Food came very fast. The first thing my boyfriend said was "Wow that'd a really small bowl of pho" but instantly shut up the second he had a bite of the noodles. "Wow these noodles are fresh" And it was instant love for the both of us. They use wider rice noodles (think ho fun noodles, about 1 cm in diameter) and not your typical pho noodle "cake".  The broth was tasty and didn't scream msg. Fair amount of meat in both orders.

Parking is bad. it's between Clement/Geary after all, so timing is everything unless you're willing to feed the meter.

I will definitely be back.
author: Jenna H.

description:
I hearby proclaim Che Ba Mau ($3) the next big thing after Boba Tea!

Take creamy coconut  milk, combine it with simple syrup + ice + green gelatin strips +  some mung & adzuki beans, and you get a refreshing and addictive (dairy-free) treat. Myself and my friend tried it for the first time and loved it. What a surprise to see something I'd been curious about staring right back at me from the food case when I peered in through the door. Talk about a coincidence!

VERY CLEAN establishment, watched ESPN on flat screen TV while I waited for the order on a busy Fleet Week weekend. The waitress suffered my nervous & hungry babbling with a smile. Sorry about that!

Must return to try the good-looking food sometime.
author: Ziggy J.

description: I'm a pretty big cold noodle guy, and I must say, this is an excellent spot. Reasonably priced cold bun noodle dishes--extra big portions (I'm extremely stuffed!). They were friendly, though it was a bit awkward when the guy casually estimated the pricing and said "$20 even," almost on a whim... Either way, certainly better than some of the alternative (and overpriced) spots for bun noodles (Bun Mee, Saiwalks).
author: Andrew M.

description:
I am a fan of their Lemongrass Fish Sandwich, it's delicious and not too spicy. Their sandwiches are decently price. They have great drinks and prepackaged appetizers, their garlic noodles are pretty good too! There are usually two people that switch off being the cashier in the front and while they are both nice people, I have seen them make mistakes on how much they charge their customers. 

It happened to me once when I was charged $10.00 flat for two sandwiches and then after 5 minutes of waiting for my food, the guy told me that he was sorry to tell me that my total was actually $1.75 more than $10.00 so therefore I will need to pay the extra owed. In my opinion, if you made that stupid mistake then you should not ask a customer to pay you back for that mistake. 

A similar situation happened another time I was here to a guy who ordered extra carrots in his sandwich and was charged $6.50 total for his order, the woman behind the counter forgot to give him back his $.50 change in the midst of a lunch rush and after handing him his change and sandwich, told him that she forgot to charge him an extra $.50 for the carrots! 

Other than that, great place, great sandwiches. Oh yeah, don't forget that there are STAMP CARDS! BUY 10 GET 1 FREE! The stamp card is on the back of their business cards, they do not advertise or offer their stamp system, so be on the lookout to get one yourself.
author: Kawai N.

description:
The best casual Vietnamese food.  Hands down.  I have ordered the pho, the bun, the banh mi, and imperial rolls.  There is nothing on this menu that is not delicious.    

Cash only though.  My buddy took me for a friend date and he had only $2 cash.  So I paid for lunch.  Thankfully, it was only $12 for the both of us.  But it's a good thing that it was just a friend date because if this was a real date, I would never put out for a guy who "forgot his wallet."
author: Needles K.

description: Okay, I've been back to try the  lemongrass pork banh mi while hubby got his standard ham & pate combo. Again, the meat was good but overall the sandwich didn't come together. More sauce? Just very plain and a little dry.
author: Jean K.
