description: Great street food.  --that is all that needs to be said.  This is not a fancy restaurant.  It is a hole in the wall, but it is an excellent hole in the wall and I wouldn't change a thing.  Especially the poster of the Vietnamese lady near the counter that makes you feel like someone is staring at you when you exit with your food.  This is my bun mi lady.  You can't have it.
author: mick H.

description: Good Vietnamese sandwiches.  I got the five spiced chicken and added pate.  The chicken was flavorful and the pate added a nice creaminess to it.  The cashier was nice and the sandwiches are reasonably priced.  My only complaint is that I wish the veggies were pickled a little more.  I wanted more of that sour flavor to counterbalance the chicken and pate.
author: Elena N.

description: More than just good food (Best Banh Mi), this family run business takes care of their customers.  I come here every Wednesday for lunch, best restaurant near Clement Street!
author: Jakob K.

description:
My boyfriend and I always come here for the veggie bahn mis! I always feel very welcomed by the nice old man who I assume is the owner. The sandwiches are always filling, and my favorite compared to all the other bahn mis in the city that I've sampled. I've heard their vermicelli bowls are very delicious as well, and have been meaning to try them. But I'm just so addicted to that bahn mi...  

I recently converted a friend to vietnamese food by introducing her to this place, and she cannot stop raving about it! Definitely worth a trip to the Richmond! Delicious sandwiches and then Green Apple Books right around the corner!
author: Morgan R.

description: Excellent food by this little family-run, hole in the wall restaurant. The chicken pho is particular, is head and shoulders above other chicken phos in the city.
author: Katie T.

description:
I really liked my sandwhich. I had the combination and it was almost perfect, I just like more pate than others. My boyfriends sandwhich looked pretty good and he said he loved it. So on to my main review, the crab tomatoe soup. It was super salty, did not have a good tomato taste, and very little noodles.It was just ok, I would get it again if I was desperate for bun rieu and was to lazy to make it myself but its not as authentic as people claim it to be. 
The rice dish with pork was super fatty ( although my friend to like that alot) . 

Prices: decent, doesn't rape your wallet Bahn mi: around 4 dollars, Soup like 7:50, and rice dish was around 7. 

Food: Sandwhiches are better but everything else was just ok to maybe not great.

Service: great

Ambiance: clean and small

Parking is a super bitch.
author: Reiko n.

description:
My best advice for this place

1) Stop reading reviews and go.  
2) Get a Pork Sandwich.  Extra Meat if you're hungry.  
3) Consume.  
4) Repeat as soon as possible
author: Tom M.

description:
Their sandwiches are AMAZING, not to mention bigger and cheaper than the ones at Cafe Bunn Mi. (Theirs are a ripoff, in my opinion. Plus, I've found HAIR in my food there on more than one occasion! Ew.)

The family that owns this place is SUPER nice. They have a "secret recipe" for their tofu, which they refuse to disclose, but who cares, it tastes amazing. Lots of grab and go options on the counter if you're in a hurry. (Freshly made daily.) Clean and pleasant ambiance. If you live in the Inner Richmond, you NEED to stop by. Probably the best deal for lunch you can get on Clement Street.
author: L D.

description:
A wonderful small  treasure of a to go place tucked a half block away from busy Clement St.  This place has great Vietnamese sandwiches for under five bucks!!  And they taste delicious!!  I've gotten their chicken sandwiches and the chicken is always juicy, (they use thigh meat) it comes with pickeled turnips and carrots, jalepenos and cucumbers and a slightly sweet mayo sauce on a chewy and slighty crunchy white roll.

They offer other types of food like noodle soups, shrimp spring rolls and Vietnamese desserts and drinks.  You don't have to wait very long at all for their sandwiches.  Some of their food comes already pre-wrapped in a small tray.

The service here is good.  If you haven't tried this place and are in the area it's a great spot to check out.
author: Amy L.

description: "Well hello there Mr Roach, and how do you do? Out for a nice slow jaunt on a fine day?" A wise old man once said, "You can tell everything about a place, by the demeanor and attitude of the roaches that reside there. If they are darting and hurried, then they are uncomfortable and always under pressure and attack. Grab and run. If on the other hand, they are slow and casual and appear accustomed and comfortable, not fearful, then that means that they are long term and permanent dwellers, familiar and comfortable with their surroundings, as they eat unobstructed and unbothered and grow and prosper with the establishment." Wise words from a wise old man? Nah, no one old or wise said this, only me, yeah old but def not yet wise, haha. So, sitting at the counter window seat, preparing to take my first bite of the chicken sandwich i ordered, I suddenly paused, as I studied the demeanor and attitude of the large roach that slowly and casually strolled down the counter and stopped in front of me and lazily lifted its head to stare at me, I felt almost as if he was greeting me, and letting me know that from here on in, we would be sharing this counter. Me very temporarily, him long term. He was home, I was gone. Oh welps, I had suddenly lost my appetite anyway, and plus, the "five spice" chic sand was prolly the worst version of this Viet mainstay that I had ever tasted. And hella expensive too! ($6? for a mediocre version of an excellent $3.50 sand? Wth?) It was tasteless anyway. More like "no spice". I bid farewell to my slimy shimmering friend, as he stood there staring at the visitor that suddenly abandoned his living room, leaving him alone. "Stupid humans" he prolly thought. "Always comin and goin. Where the h--l are they always so busily off to? Why are they always in such a hurry? Leaving without breaking bread together, how rude! He left before we could both sit down and eat together. " I felt remorse at abandoning him suddenly, but as I turned to leave and head to the 38 Geary and the TL and Saigon, to try again, and I accidentally glanced in the kitchen, and seeing dirty plates piled high, unwashed, in the back of the dark kitchen, I left comforted, knowing that my new found slimy, shiny friend had many other similar friends, and a large extended family to keep him company and to give him permanent, daily, constant solace. Because as that same old wise man once said, "For every one you see, there are 30 you do not." No, this time seriously, he did say that. Now let's see if you can guess who that wise, old man was........haha. Oh yeah!!
author: George F.

description:
Friendly service, fast despite a long line, loved the 5 spice chicken bahn mi. Cool carrots and cucumber, mayo sauce, cilantro and jalapeños. Add some Siracha for heat and you've got a tasty sandwich. I think their bread is very good here, crusty on outside and chewy full bread on inside. Friendly people. Cash only.
PS the chicken spring roll is better than the shrimp and the dipping sauces were just "ok"
author: Piper W.

description: Excellent value.  Great tastes. Loved the recommended coconut drink.  Could use more seating but now that I know, I will definitely buy take out.  Definitely recommend try everything . Love the guy who takes your order... The leftovers I took home tasted great the next day too
author: MJ C.

description: I've never been in the restaurant location so this review is in regards to Little Vietnam's catering.  They have been into my office three times now to cater lunch and make noodle bowls on the spot.  I love how the employees stay and create the bowls on site - they are fresh, warm, and delicious!  On top of tasty food, the man and woman who come from the restaurant are extremely pleasant and friendly.  My coworkers all have nothing but positive things to report about the bowls they make for us.  I definitely recommend this place for in-office lunch catering.
author: Kristen F.

description:
I had such high expectations for this place, but when I tried two of their banh mi sandwiches, I was terribly disappointed. The baguette was dry, the meat did not have any flavor, and I was just sad because my girlfriend wasn't happy that I took her there. 

Skip it. Go to Cafe Bunn Mi or Lee's Sandwiches.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Little Vietnam catered our company lunch today. Food was delivered on time and presentation was nice.

Pros: Food seems very clean and fresh. I didn't need an MSG nap after lunch.

Cons: Bahn Mi had hard bread and spring rolls had very little meat. Papaya salad was lacking in flavor. I added salt to my sandwich and salad. I think the fish sauce was missing!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Haven't really tried a ton of Vietnamese sandwich places in the Richmond district, but I have had sandwiches from Lee's and Saigon Sandwich in the Tenderloin, not to mention I've actually had sandwiches in Vietnam before, so Little Vietnam was facing some stiff competition.  

*CHICKEN SANDWICH*
- The bread is French roll, so that's cool, but I like my bread crusty throughout.
- Chicken was a little too rough for me... not moist enough.
- Too many damn carrots!

It's not amazing, but it's not bad... probably one of the better Vietnamese sandwiches in the area.  $4.50 is on the higher price range with Vietnamese sandwiches though.
author: Christine A.

description: Best pho I've ever had!  Super fresh, very tasty not too salty, absolutely delicious!!  This Mom and pop restaurant is definitely a must go!!
author: Max S.

description:
This is for the sandwiches only.  I found this while looking for a place to eat after church.  We all now Clement is crackin' on a Sunday, so looking for parking is always a pain, so we just always take it to go.  
We've tried the cold and hot sandwiches.  Oh mayn, love it!  I actually prefer hot sandwiches and the meat is so tasty.  I've had dry or leftover meat that's meant to use for sandwiches I guess, but not here.  Prices are a little bit higher than usual sandwiches.  
Workers are nice too.  It's a family-run business and the guy is friendly.  
One of these days when we're able to find parking and sunny day, hubby and I gotta try their other dishes and enjoy the seats outside.  It's a cute little place!
author: Claire J.

description:
I got lost looking for a dim sum restaurant and when I finally found it I couldn't find parking. When I found parking it was just too far for me to walk to so I gave up. When I made the decision to give up I turned left and noticed this place. I hate to say this especially when my hometown is San Jose, but this place is pretty darn good! 

I got the traditional Banh Mi Thit Nuong (vietnamese sandwich with grilled pork). The french baguette was nicely toasted not like Lee's sandwiches where it's rock hard and tears up the roof of your mouth when you first bite into it. The pickled carrots, daikon, cucumber, cilantro, and jalapenos tasted really fresh. 

I'm not sure what made this sandwich so good. Maybe it's their secret sauce that they put in it? Either way friendly service and good food = 5 stars from me. 

One more thing...I think San Jose has bigger sandwiches. Size does matter! At least for me....in a non homosexual way. :)
author: David W.

description: Lemongrass Pork banh mi: for $4.50 incl tax ($2 for a nifty flavored aloe drink), I got a room temperature sandwich with some thin slices of lemongrass pork, similar to a hotpot or korean bbq. only one to two layers thick.  I wish sandwich places would do a better job of spreading out the meat; I'm not a fan of eating drying bread with some token vegetables as a sandwich.  Bread was ok overall; probably not super fresh, but it didn't scrape up my mouth.  Meat flavor was good in the middle where most of it was piled up, although one of my bites had a bit too much of a fatty blob.  Also, the cucumber carrot radish mixture was not as strong flavored as many other shops.  Not bad for the price, but I think some other places in SF do this better.
author: Linus W.

description:
I was crusin' on Yelp in search of quick Vietnamese food for lunch and I came up with Little Vietnam Café. 

When I got there folks were just starting to wander in. The first thing that caught my eye was the tempting display of ready to eat prepacked Pork and Shrimp Rolls. They all look so yummy! 

But instead, I decided on a Pork Banh Mi sandwich. I figure I'd go light today. 

The toasted bun had just the right crunch and the thinly sliced pork very flavorful. Accompanied with Pickled Carrots, Daikon Radish, Cilantro and Jalapeno it was music to my mouth with every bite. 

They also have several options on the menu from Pho to Rice Plates. 
I shall return for the rolls and more...
author: Gary E.

description:
Sloppy, unpresentable sandwich.  Friendly, but spaced-out staff.  

As my trek on my Vietnamese Sandwich quest continues.  I visited Little Vietnam for yet another sandwich to satisfy my craving.  

Excited as I was, as I had been hearing good things about this spot, I was less than satisfied with the Combination Ham Sandwich I received here.  

The visit started off smooth, and I was hopeful.  The gal working the front counter was friendly, but she definitely seemed like a little Ditzy Space Cadette, unaware of what was going on.  

Typically, after ordering, it's customary to collect payment first in a to-go place.   However, the gal just takes my order, and I sit and wait. Maybe they just collect payment after my order is finished.  Fine. 

Sandwich finally finished, the gal Thanks me, and quickly hands me my sandwich.  I'm staring at her, wondering if she remembered that I hadn't paid--which she didn't. 

Darn, if only I wasn't such an honest person, I could've gotten away with a free $4.00 sandwich.  Being the person I am, I paid the dead-head got on my way.  

Alright, so back to my sandwich.  As I mentioned, I was disapopinted.  First of all, my Combo Ham was the messiest, unpresentable banh mi I had ever seen. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/l-1eHkuvqXAo3CN3LvrfwA?select=dDn9C3GDulQFtiBltzHKnw
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/l-1eHkuvqXAo3CN3LvrfwA?select=zyiwnnWZ985kxaITWSfpjA

My bread was falling apart before I was able to get my hands on it.  I was looking at this wondering how am I going to pick it up without it falling apart on me.  Furthermore, they failed to cut my sandwich in half.  

Continuing on about my mediocre sandwich, the Pate was smoothered on like it was Mayonnaise--globbed on.  I had to smear it off to balance the pate out a little bit.  Pate is supposed to be a spread, is it not? 

Since being at work when I decided to eat my sandwich, I was only provided with a plastic fork.  Needless to say, cutting the sandwich in half was quite a hassle.  

Continuing on...Had I not been already been disappointed, I would normally let this detail slide, as "Shit happens."  But unfortunately, my sandwich put me in a bad mood early.  

I happened to find a nice little  h a i r  within my sandwich.  Not much to say here--just another added detail in to my reoccuring disappointment of this extremely mediocre sandwich that I had.  

Conclusion...Th ding-bat of an employee working, messy and unattractively  prepared, and hair in sandwich....

Will I be back?   N O ! 

I think this spot killed my Vietnamese Sandwich craving.
author: Cass J.

description:
I woke up on my first morning in San Francisco with a very fuzzy head. Was it the lack of sleep, the dehydration from the 16 hour flight (from Australia) or was is the three margaritas I had the night before?

Who knows, but the pork Banh Mi at Little Vietnam Cafe was the perfect cure for the awfulness that had sunk inside my skull. A cripsy baguette stuffed full of sweet, aromatic, slices of pork and monster loads of crunchy pickled veg, mayo and jalapenos really hit the spot and made me feel human again.

Banh Mi - the cure for hangovers and jetlag the world over.
author: Tresna L.

description:
As a Vietnamese person who is spoiled by food in the OC, I was glad to have stubled upon this place. The one thing you notice right when you come in is the friendly owner greeting you and taking your order. It has has indoor seating as well as a few tables outside. A lot of his regular customers come here while I was eating here. The food is ready within minutes of ordering; something that I'm use to seeing in OC but is rare to see here in other Vietnamese
 places in San Francisco. 

I come here to eat something that is hard to do well in a restaurant establishment but is also hard to cook for yourself at home: Bun Rieu. 

The Bun Rieu had a nice light tomato base soup that was balanced with the tofu and eggs with bits of crab meat. Topped with a generous portion of greens and bean sprouts. It was fulfilling to eat, yet light, and it reminded me of what I use to eat at home. 

I also tried the Vermicilli with lemon grass pork, which I took home for a later meal. The vegetables were fresh and there was a generous portion of pork. Good quality Vietnamese food. 

I am ambivalent on the sandwiches though. I think they need to work on the texture of their bread, but the ingredients are always fresh. 

I recommend to those that crave Bun Rieu and other Bun dishes to try it here.
author: Nam L.

description:
A nice Vietnamese fast-food joint.

A decent deal for banh mi + iced coffee ($6)  is a pretty good deal. Haven't had much else because the prices of a la cart items seem on the high side. They've always been friendly, however, and the sandwiches are pretty tasty. They are no Saigon Sandwich (and not as cheap) but a nice alternative for those with a banh mi craving and not wanting to venture into the Loin.
author: Jasmyn M.

description:
You know it's good place when actual Viets / Asian go here! Sorry hipsters, the ambiance is not that cool so I just go to Cafe Banh Mi and you'll be ok. 

Seriously, good prices, good sandwiches, good plates, and good people who work behind the counter. 

I love the beef bbq sandwiches here but I really like the noodle plates that they put out on the counter for the really quick to-go days. Try it out and don't be fooled by the location.
author: Ang P.

description:
Bread is great--I love either the pork or 5 spice chicken sandwich. Sometimes when I'm feeling a little crazy I go for the Peter Special which is a sunny side up egg with special sauce!

I've also tried their Pho Ga, which tastes different from what I'm used to but really tasty. Pretty garlicy and really soothing to the throat! Noodles are softer and wider too.

So glad this place is only a bus ride away!
author: An-Nhien L.

description:
Decided to try this place since I was craving a Viet sandwich. Good selection of Banh Mi but the crispy tofu caught my eye.  Since I took it to go, I can't tell you whether or not it was crispy by the time I ate it, but it definitely satisfied my palette. What I noticed was that they pull out the bread so that they could put more filling without it being too bready as some other places don't, making it easier to eat and getting more of the filling vs bread. Nicely done. The sauce seemed like a mayo mix and the veggies were delightfully pickled as they should be. 

All in all, it was very tasty. And they give you a stamp card which I will definitely fill up to get my freebie (after the 10th one). Overall, quick service and good food, great place to grab food on the go.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Came here last night to grab a quick dinner and they were closing up quite early but nevertheless still served my friend and I. Super cute hidden spot near Clement, the seating is quite limited but I'm sure outside seating would be quite nice during the lunchtime. I had the lemongrass pork sandwich and it was truly delicious. My favorite part was definitely the bread because it was softer, fresher and not overly crunchy than I've had at most places. I got the strawberry limeonade to drink and it was very refreshing but there was a little too much ice in it and not enough drink. Overall the food was great for the price and would highly recommend if you're looking for some viet food in the area!
author: Vonny C.

description: Their fresh spring rolls, which they assured me were fresh, had been sitting around for a while and the rice paper casing was chewy and boring. The inside had little taste. The dipping sauce did come to the rescue a bit. There are much better options for spring rolls elsewhere on Clement Street. I'll have to go back to try their sandwiches or soups later, but as of this last visit, the motivation lacks. It's too bad, I had high hopes for this spot.
author: Brian J.

description:
I pass by this place everyday on the 44 bus and I have always wanted to try it. I get the crispy tofu sandwich and it was amazing. I never though tofu on a sandwich would be good, but this place proved me wrong. All of the accompanying veggies went perfectly on the sandwich and the special mayo was really tasty ( I usually hate mayo but loved this kind). Getting the peppers is a must because it gives a nice spicy kick to to tofu and bread. One downside is its cash only, but its really well priced ($4.15 for my sandwich) that you should be able to find enough cash in your wallet. Wanted to try the tofu spring rolls but didn't have enough cash so I will be back to try those. 
Also the guy taking orders was super friendly and helpful. He didn't mind as we scrambled to find enough change to pay and was apologetic that they don't take credit cards. Very nice man.
author: Julie C.

description:
The service is awesome and they make you feel really cared for.  The prices are super cheap for what you get.   There are cheaper bahn mi's in the city but these are worth every penny...  I love how they give you a bunch of cilantro with the stems on and their chili sauce is perfectly spicy/sweet...

I haven't tried the Pho or any of their main dishes but they all look pretty bomb!   

The spring rolls are delicious and cheap.

I usually spend $11 on lunch with my girlfriend and I and always leave happy as hell...  Can't go wrong!
author: William G.

description: Yelp has it wrong on this one. I consider myself a pho connoisseur and if yelp had 2.5 stars that's what I would give to little Vietnam. I was on clement street looking to satisfy my pho craving and this did not do the trick. Completely overpriced, weird pieces of meat, and severely flavorless broth. I found myself dumping hoisin, soy sauce, and sriracha into the chicken pho to make it worth consuming. Save your $10.50 and go to bunn mi next door where you can buy two decadent Vietnamese sandwiches for that price. Nice staff and pretty good atmosphere but unfortunately the pho just has no flavor and has weird meat floating throughout. Not coming back.
author: Julian D.

description: I like this place very much.  Affordable, convenient, and great tasting Vietnamese food.
author: Hideki S.

description:
It's all about the bread...

And unfortunately, the bread here was just eh.  Not crispy enough I think was the problem.  And while they had lots of veggies and meat, it was just "ok".  Relatively inexpensive and it was cute - good for take out but not for eating there (only a few seats outside)

Still on the search for the perfect banh mi.
author: Lisa L.

description:
I've walked pass this little shop every time i walk to Smart & Final. Use to be an old Chinese bakery. Decided to check it out one day. A tiny hole in the wall spot, family run. I was greeted by Linda the daughter of the own. Great service!. She was very friendly and help me with suggestions for my lunch. Which came down to:

Bun Rui- Tomato paste and crab noodle soup.  Probably the best i ever had in the City. Noodles done right. Not too oily.  Lots of fresh tomatoes and ground pork. Portions were spot on. The soup was so good I even dipped the spring rolls. 

Limeade w/ Mint - Simple refreshing and delicious. Not too sweet.  The mint adds a complexity to the limeade.  I actually mention to Linda if she thought of adding crushed ginger in the drink. That's an ideal.

Pork Spring rolls- Good not great they were prepackage. Home made of course! Because they were pre-made the rice wrapping had dried little hard. Hence why i dunked them in the Bun Rui.
$13

I haven't tried the sandwiches yet but i have heard that the bread crust is hard.
A+ for small family owned business!
author: Brent W.

description:
Best Bahn Mi in the city? I disagree. Nothing compares to Saigon Sandwiches in the TL. Nothing.

But pretty great bahn mi in the city? Yes. They also have some pretty bomb vermicelli bowls. I actually prefer eating the bowls here vs. the sandwiches. Also they have great Imperial Rolls and Vietnamese iced coffee. I believe they do a combo meal for $7 too. Back to the sandwiches - stick with the pork and forget the lemongrass chicken. The chicken is a bit dry and doesn't have much flavor IMO.

Friendly staff, quick service...this place is a great alternative to the Vietnamese shops in the Tenderloin...you know, if you don't feel like setting foot down there :)
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
The lemongrass pork banh mi with Peter's Special. Do it.

For an additional $1.25 - the banh mi by itself is $4.15 plus tax - Peter's Special includes a fried egg & special sauce that will take an average, somewhat dry banh mi and knock it out of the park. I'm pretty sure that the special sauce is made up of tasty, tasty rainbows. I ordered a regular lemongrass pork banh mi today, and my friend ordered the same banh mi with Peter's Special...there was no comparison. After trying a bite of her sandwich, the rest of my sandwich was just sad, inferior. I had to sit there and watch helplessly as she rapidly devoured all of it before I could ask for more.

I used to say that you shouldn't have to pay more than 5 bucks for a banh mi, but I lied. The runny yolk and the special sauce are worth all 125 pennies.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
The Vietnamese family that owns this place is so sweet. I love them. And I love their food even more. Garlic noodles, lemongrass tofu, and of course banh mi (tofu and chicken being my favorites)... all delicious, convenient, affordable. What more could you ask for?

I guess I could ask for an egg on my sandwich. But they do that, too. Gotta try next time... and let me tell you, there will be many more next times.
author: Julie D.

description:
Great take-out food.  This place is really tiny, and can barely seat 5 people so plan accordingly.

Really good sandwiches - but they come with alot of bread.  I am a "low-carb" kinda guy, so if you are looking for sandwiches with light bread, this is not the kind of sandwiches you want.

I have had the 5-spice chicken sandwiches - yum!  Comes with a lot of flavor, cilantro, spice sauce and carrots.  I was pleasantly surprised by how tasty they were.  They have a $7 special of a sandwich of your choice + Vietnamese ice coffee, which saves you like ..... 50 cents.

Parking can be tough; what place in SF isn't?  Here is a tip: try the Office Max parking lot (at least in the late afternoon/evening), they dont seem to care if you dont park for longer than an hr.       =)
author: M P.

description:
Came because of the yelpers... to be honest I'm not a fan, and probably won't be coming back too often. 

I ordered the lemongrass pork banh mi and iced coffee. I liked the meat in the sandwich but think it's missing that "umph!" I get in more traditional banh mi. They don't put any spread on the banh mi that more traditional banh mi use and they put the jalapenos wrapped outside the sandwich... I guess this was good for those who don't want it too spicy, but it was a pain putting one piece at a time into the sandwich. The iced coffee was decent. The price here is also more expensive than average vietnamese sandwiches (no extra bang for your buck!), another reason why I will be a rare customer.
author: Jen L.

description:
This is great little hole-in-the-wall spot and one of my go to's in the neighborhood. Love their Vietnamese sandwiches and, when I have more time to eat, I'll get a big bowl of their vermicelli noodles.

The seating isn't super comfortable -- there's a little counter inside and a few tables out front -- and it can get kind of crowded inside if there are a few people waiting to order. But the food makes it more than worth it!
author: Fanny S.

description: I am so pissed I've been here before and gave them a good rating for the food. This rating is for their horrible customer service. I literally ran to the place before it closed to use my 50% off Scoutmob deal. I showed it to the lady, pressed use in front of her then she was insisted I pay full price. She said she can't offer the deal unless her boss was there.That wasn't my problem her boss wasn't there, customers don't know his or her schedule! I am not able to use the Scoutmob deal again after pressing it, which I did in front of her while she watched. She kept insisting I come back next time to use it, I walked out.
author: Karen T.

description:
Vietnamese chicken burritos.

Not served here. But they put so much chicken in their sandwiches you could eat half for lunch and save the rest of the chicken for another meal. Like a Vietnamese chicken burrito.

Two for the price of one. And $4 for that one is ridiculously cheap.

Older gentlemen running the counter couldn't have been nicer. Sandwich and experience (and burrito) couldn't have been better.
author: Jason B.

description:
Horrible food and bad service!

The owner was RUDE (he accused me of trying to cheat him when I mentioned that the Vietnamese coffee I ordered hadn't arrived) and food was horrible!!! 

(And I almost never capitalize a word or use three exclamation marks.)

The lemongrass beef banh mi sandwich: stale bread and dry meat.
The chicken noodle soup: soggy noodles, brown bean sprouts and dry old tasting chicken.

I cant imagine how this place was voted best banh mi sandwich by SF Weekly. Maybe in a parallel universe?

There are so many other options in this neighborhood, so save your money and skip this place!!!
author: David L.

description:
On my way to Clement I happened to see Little Vietnam sitting pretty on 6th Ave so I decided it was banh mi time. From the outside, you can see through their cute windows to find their small seating area, but the interior was not much bigger as the menu with pictures were posted behind the counter. Next to the register was a colorful array of packaged spring rolls that were nicely positioned  for easy pickup. 

I had a hard time ordering but eventually settled for their warm lemongrass pork sandwich ($4). Unlike any of my other banh mi ventures, their French baguette was not flaky or tough but it was more like a soft roll that was thick and moist with great texture. It was by far the best bread I've tasted on a banh mi and it was filled with generous portions of thick, tenderized grilled pork, jalapenos, cilantro, and pickled carrots and turnips. This banh mi was so good and satisfying it led me to become curious about the rest of the menu that included pho and vermicelli. I was able to convince my yelp buddy David N. to share an order of fresh shrimp roll ($3) which came with two humongous pieces that disappeared faster than we could anticipate. I thought the dipping hoisin could be better or instead be replaced with fish sauce but I can't really complain when it was wrapped tightly and richly bolstered with large shrimps and loads of greens and rice vermicelli. I love these goi guon!

As a hole in the wall, this place serves up some badass sandwiches. The ambiance was modest and laid back, and service was accessible but brief as the server tends to hang out in the kitchen and only to emerge when necessary. 4.5 stars for great value and for the tandem of two supersized torpedoes that were loaded with flavor. Knowing that I don't get this kind of food in Westwood I'm going to need this place to banh mi again real soon.
author: Daniel L.

description:
It was such a nice day that I was out and about walking around the city to meet some people and run some errands. I started getting pretty dang hungry and I was in slightly unfamiliar territory near the Warfield. 

Dum-ta-da-dum! Yelp to the rescue. I checked out a few reviews from fellow yelpites (yelpers? yelpies?) and opted for giving the Little Vietnam Cafe a shot solely based on Lauren S's note that the food was so good she might be selling her body outside of the cafe to eat there. Good food plus the chance of meeting the infamous yelper equaled me walking 6 blocks to get my bahn mi on.

So I totally dug the fact that this place had 'Authentic Vietnamese' on the awning but it looks like a trendy little deli. Really it was not what I was expecting when going to any Asian styled eatery. But different is good. The place was clean and it was easy to get what I wanted and go. To be safe I grabbed a pork banh mi and a spicy chicken. Not knowing how long I was going to be out doubling up seemed like a good idea; and if the food was as good as they say I might just pig out on the second one anyway.

The pork sammy was  delicious! Not at all what I would have expected. For whatever reason, it felt so much like a deli, my taste buds assumed it would just be a normal pork sammy. Two thumbs up for the bahn mi! Everything tasted really fresh. I saved the chicken for at least an hour before devouring it as well. High marks for this sweet spot!
author: Nick B.

description:
How is it that this place has been open for 5 years already, and I didn't even know about it??? Someone needs to revoke my 'self-proclaimed food-insider' card!

Little Vietnam Cafe isn't so much a cafe as it is a tiny little hole-in-the-wall. A small counter and a couple of 2-top tables inside, and a couple of tables outside. Understandably, most folks are ordering to go. I came here for lunch and it was crazy busy!

Ordered up a bun (vermicelli noodles with your choice of meat) with their BBQ pork and egg roll. OMG, it was seriously awesome. They are totally generous with their servings, and the food comes out fast! The BBQ pork was absolutely delicious - I don't know how they get that hint of smoke flavor in there, but it's incredible and melts in your mouth! 

We have already vowed to come back to sample the entire menu, so I'll update as I graze my way through. Can't wait to try the banh mi!
author: Christy L.

description:
I can not believe all the good reviews this place has.

I had the grossest Banh Mi sandwich here.  It was the five spice chicken and the first bite I took had a big piece of greasy skin in it!  Luckily my dog was nearby to eat that.

The proportion of meat to vegetables was 20% meat and 80% vegetables, I'd have preferred a little more meat as long as it wasn't skin.  The slaw was mostly carrots, cut really big and thick, and the bread was not hot and toasty and crunchy but just one step above a hot dog roll.

I ended up giving most of the bread to the ducks at Stow Lake and putting all those carrots in the green composting bin.

I love the Banh Mi's at Cafe Banh Mi so I will stick with them.
author: Madeline M.

description:
Every time I get a sandwich here out of desperation, I regret it.

The mayo/butter/pate is always sloppily put on, let alone not enough is spread on the mediocre bread.

The spring rolls also leave much to be desired.

I don't dare to try the noodle soup........... =|

2 stars because at least the service is nice.

And now with Cafe Bunn Mi open just a block away (I work in the area) I have no reason to come back to Little Vietnam.
author: Munnie T.

description:
The banh mis here are RIDICULOUS. Super cheap and loaded with meat, pickled veggies and jalapenos.  Usually, I have a hard time finishing my sandwich due to it's size and density of protein.  The sammiches here are seriously mind blowing.

I had the pho once and it was okay.  I'd say, go here for the sandwiches because that is their specialty.  Anything porky is spectacular.  Add a fried egg to your sammich for more awesomeness. THE END.
author: Sherry C.

description: Had food catered from here and had a really pleasant experience. Had vermicelli noodle bowls made to order and the beef was really tender, really flavorful, and the vermicelli was cooked just right. Props!
author: Austin W.

description: Their meat is actually meat, actually BBQ, not burnt, not fatty, not a day old, actually fresh, tender, juicy, and tasty.  They put alot of marinated carrots and the chili is not hot at all.  I'm voting this the best banh mi on Clement (technically not on Clement).  I really liked the Lemongrass pork over the 5 spice chicken.
author: Helen L.

description:
This is why I hate yelp. 

Yeah, at first it was great. I signed up as a "yelper" the day I read about Yelp in the Chronicle the year they debuted. 

The thrill of seeing my opinions about random SF eateries was titilating. I even got a few compliments. Which happened to be my mom, but still, it felt awesome. 

And then, like everything else, it became so goddamn hip. Fucking idiots with smiley icon faces as their lone review started cropping up. Fucking politics of the "yelp-way" became a matter of contention. Threads about profile pictures, or celebs or orther non-important issues were seemingly becoming de rigueur. Lastly, my favorite hole in the wall spots now were donning those obnoxious red  "People on Yelp love me" stickers.  Now numbnuts from New Jersey were trickling into Cordon Bleu. 

But here I was today, on my way to Green Apple Books in attempts to make some cash and off load some old books. Last time I was in that part of the hood, I happened upon a hole in the wall Pho joint. Alas, my beef tendon pho was severly lacking in freshness and tastiness. So I thought I'd consult the old standby (and yes, their admittedly awesome "things nearby" option) for some reputable Vietnamese restaurants/delis.  

Little Vietnam Cafe seemed to be loved by most Yelpers, so I took note of the address and was on my merry way. 

So it was good. I am not here to bag on the place, but it was just so fucking Americanized and over-yelped. Every single customer in there was white. NOt the best start. The group in front of me was a foursome of ladies who obviously were dragged there by their Frisco girlfriend, the one who had pink streaks in her hair in high school, the one who left all of her friends in randomtown Ohio to escape to the Wild West. Now here they were, all timid, meekly all asking for a chicken sandwich, and -gasp- of course no jalapenos!  I kind of was embarassed as every other customer there I witnessed made a substitution like it was fucking Applebees!

Oh well. People are weird. I've worked in restaurants many years, I am accustomed to the odd requests of something the chef created because, ya know, s/he's the chef and that is her/his art.  But good luck doing that at Saigon Sandwiches!

I digress. Back to the review (see! It's happening to me too! I want to feel vindicated by writing a long-ass review!). So my spicy pork banh mi was like a Mc Donald's version of the classic French-Vietnamese sandwich. The bread was good. Too good. Needed to be harder, like only a slightly stale piece of French bread can only offer. And the good stuff, the stuff that makes banh mi's so damn good, like the cilantro and the jalapeno, were pretty much nonexistent. I don't mind eating cilantro stems, in fact, I crave them in my banh mi's!

I bet they weren't like that pre-Yelp days. I bet I would have walked by it a few times deciding if I wanted to try it or not. I bet there wasn't  a large sandwich board describing offerred items. I bet I would have been ignored upon entering.  I bet it would have cost me $3.50. And, surely, I bet it was a damn good, rustic, and authentic banh mi.
author: Jane I.

description:
This family run place has the BEST vietnamese sandwiches hands down and they are really, really, friendly in a genuine, not I'm trying to get your business, kind of way.

They have a sandwich card so you can get a free one after you fill it up. :) yeah!

VERY reasonably priced with lots of things to take with you on the go.

My only teeny nitpick would be the use of plastic for some of their wrapped to go stuff and plastic bags (pretty typical for the Richmond).

They don't use plastic for the sandwiches but if they switched to all eco stuff I'd be even more excited.

Overall an EXCELLENT place and the kind of people i want to support!
author: Little B.

description: I love the pork BBQ banh mi here the best.  Sometimes i opt for "Pete's special" which basically means that they add a fried egg to the sandwich.  YUM!  Both ways are delicious and inexpensive.  I've had the BBQ chicken too, but don't find it quite as tasty as the pork.  Service is always fast and with a smile.  It's like visiting a Vietnamese family's kitchen each time I go.
author: Allegra H.

description: This is my favorite place for vietnamese sandwiches. It's hidden on a residential street in the richmond, next to Smart And Final. The prices are super cheap, the food is great, and the owner is super "vietnamese style" nice.
author: David L.

description:
OHMYGAWSOFRIGGINGOOD!!! Wow! I had been here once before but must have gone on an off day cuz the sandwiches I had today blew me away. My husband and I got a lemongrass chicken sandwich and a lemongrass pork sandwich to share between the two of us and we added the "Peter's special" to both of them where they drizzle a secret sauce in the sandwich and add a fried egg. So. Damn. Good. This is our new official banh mi spot in the city.

P.S. They have a scoutmob deal going on right now so you can get 50% off of your yummy sandwich :)
author: Angelina G.

description:
This review is only for the banh mi.  I cannot vouch for anything else.

If you are craving banh mi, stop reading and go here NOW.   Order the Lemongrass Pork or Chicken then add Peter's Special Egg.  Eat it there in the shop.  Do not take it home... the bread will be soggy by then and it will not be the same.  

This is one legit Vietnamese sandwich!

The french roll is perfectly crispy on the outside and light and fluffy on the inside.  The charbroiled meat is deliciously flavored.  All the ingredients tasted fresh and well balanced.  Left me wanting more!

5 stars for being the best Banh Mi in SF!  Slightly more expensive then the others, but well worth it.
author: Michael P.

description:
I wonder how prehistoric Britannians felt when metal was first introduced into their Stone Age culture by invading seafarers. Those visitors, appearing different and scary, possessed a greater knowledge of the world. The natives must've felt an increased propensity to throw down.

This is how I feel now, bringing news that the Banh Mi at Little Vietnam are better than those made at Saigon Sandwiches. Yet, before you shun my god(s) and the manner in which I dress, know that I'm only looking out for your best interests.

A Banh Mi from Little Vietnam has fresher ingredients and a brighter flavor than any other Banh Mi I've had in the city thus far. The bread isn't dry, but rather lightly toasted in such a way it perfectly complements the innards. Sure, it's $1 more than Saigon Sandwiches, but think of it as a you-don't-have-to-stand-in-line-in-the-TL-with-crates-of-human-poop tax.

That said, my god(s) and threads are way better than yours.
author: Keane L.

description:
3.5! But the iced coffee bumped it down to a solid 3.

The bánh mì sandwiches are really good here!  A little pricier than other places but I especially enjoyed the pork meatball sandwich where the meatballs were piping hot and "melt in your mouth good" (that's what she said).  The baguette has a good bite to it but isn't crusty to the point where the roof of your mouth looks like something that came out of a knife fight.

And yes, the iced coffee suzzucks here!!!  Not strong enough, watered down, not filled to the top of the cup, what the frick?!?
author: Ken L.

description:
One of my favorite cheap eat joints in the City.  All you need to try are the grilled pork sandwiche (don't order it like a yuppie by calling it bahn mi) and crab noodle soup (bun rieu).

You won't be disappointed by this hole in the wall in the Richmond.
author: Sunny W.

description:
$4.50 for a vietnamese sandwich?!?  That is nuts!! I decided to try this place anyway since I had some time to kill on my random day off.  Hoping that there was going to be some magic in this high priced sandwich, instead I only found the cashier picking his nose (okay, maybe scratching) and then pack my sandwich into the paper bag. Glad he is only the cashier and doesn't make the sandwiches.

But the dude was friendly and courteous, even tried to start a conversation.  Anyways, the combination sandwich was alright, your typical processed meats, pate, pickled veges, pepper and even some mayo. The bread was a bit disappointing; too light, without substance and just crumbles to the touch.  Lower those insane prices, stop touching that nose, improve your bread, and maybe I'll be back!  :)
author: Leeseuh K.

description: Now this is what I call a bahn mi  - fresh  ingredients, spices, good amount of jalapeños. I had the pork one and can't wait to come back for the chicken. The staff was very friendly as well!
author: Rebecca D.

description:
Came here on a spur of the moment. It's a hole in the wall. The staff is really friendly.

I got the tofu sandwich! OMG best tofu sandwich I have ever had. It was cripsy and fully loaded with vegetables. The bread could have been better, but I can't complain. The secret sauce on the sandwich was also really good! I'm hoping the sauce has nothing to do with meat products tho, but I'm also afraid to ask because it was so good.

I also ordered the jicama sweet potato tofu spring rolls with the soy sauce. It was amazing! Both items ran for about $9. It was filling. And felt like home. Good comfort home food!
author: Nathalie N.

description: Best bahn mi I've had in the bay, excellent salads and iced coffee as well. Plus the family that runs it is very gracious and welcoming!
author: Andreas S.

description:
I have returned 3 times in the last two weeks. I can't get enough of the chicken banh mi. 

I don't know if I can cure this addiction.
author: Judy L.

description: Sorry Little Vietnam Cafe. You just don't do it for me. After striking out at Cafe Bahn Mi around the corner (I went to get a sandwich and they were out of bread!) I decided to try Little Vietnam Cafe. The ratings and reviews made it sound promising. They were out of chicken, which is what I ordered. I opted for Lemongrass Beef Bahn Mi. It's supposed to come with mayo and special sauce, but I asked for no mayo. My sandwich had no special sauce, no pate, and was the driest Bahn Mi I've ever had. There was barely any beef and the roll, which is typically my favorite part, was not good. I opened up the sandwich to just eat the inside and noticed that some of my beef was raw - like, bloody uncooked right out of the package raw. So disappointing.
author: B B.

description:
Small Place (i only order out), Good Food (for Veterinarians - All Tofu based).
This place best replicates the "fast food" i had when traveling Vietnam, specifically;
Fresh Spring Rolls (Goi Rolls)
Sandwiches

Prices are fair (about $5/each for the above listed items).

The Salads are also good, but may be over priced for the quality/quantity.
author: Ayall S.

description: I'm sure everyone has wrote this but seriously.. get Peter's Special on your bahn mi. The sandwich gets pretty pricey when you do, but it's almost always worth it. I live out in the 40's and I ride my bike down here every other weekend to get a sandwich. The owner is super nice and friendly. The sandwiches are a decent size and fills me up every time.
author: Kevin C.

description: I had the spicy beef pho on a light rainy day. It felt nostalgic as a friend and I sat outside, eating while the rain lightly showered. Space is tight yet food is great! My friend loved his pork rice plate, he said the meat was "tender".
author: Jen C.

description:
I hate to be a Negative Nancy but this place was pretty disappointing. I can also blame Saigon Sandwiches for blowing all competition out of the water, but then again when I think about how delicious it is, it's not Saigon Sandwiches' fault that the just know how to make LEGIT banh mi's . 

The sandwiches here are $4.15 ($4.50 after tax) but are a major upset! The meat was pretty bland and the only taste I got was from the carrots and cucumbers. The bread was nice and soft but lacked that fresh bread smell I usually look forward to. I got lemon grass chicken while the BF got the meatball. The meatball was really disappointing with more fat than meat. They were stingy with meat, too. They offer other items like spring rolls, vermicelli, drinks, desserts, etc etc etc! I thought about it as I ate the sandwich that it wasn't too bad, BUT because the sandwich cost more than Saigon Sandwich and doesn't even compare in taste, it won't be a favorite.
author: Connie C.

description:
Delicious Vietnamese sandwiches and friendly service!  

I have been going here often for several years and have never been disappointed.  The sandwich rolls are fresh and crusty on the outside/soft on the inside, and are stuffed full of delicious, fresh ingredients in just the right proportions!  I have had the tofu sandwich and the pork sandwich many times, as well as the spring rolls they have on the counter.  All have been consistently delicious, and a really good value.  And the man who's usually behind the counter is super friendly.  Great place!
author: Meredith H.

description:
On a search for a place that serves both bun rieu and vietnamese sandwiches to satisfy our cravings. Thanks to Yelpers, we came across this place. Vietnamese sandwiches, packaged spring rolls, dry noodle bowls, rice plates, and specialty noodle soups. Small little hole in the wall with limited seating indoors and a few tables/chairs outside. We came here a while back and remember it was scorching hot inside the store, but we still ended up ordering a bowl of noodle soup and snagged a seat indoors...what was I thinking?! 

- Shrimp spring rolls: Nothing special to note, alright. 
- Grilled lemongrass pork sandwich: Flavorful and toasted, but I've had better and it was pricier in comparison to some other Vietnamese sandwich shops. 
- Bun Rieu (tomato crab meat soup): It even came with a little plate of veggies including bean sprouts, mint, etc. Everything from the meat, tofu, to soup was very tasty, but made me super thirsty afterward. 

Non-stop customers coming in and out during lunch time on a weekend day. No sign of a public restroom, but the friendly staff allowed me to use their bathroom hidden inside, plus! 

P.S. Cash only!
author: Tracy T.

description:
Peter and company were awesome. 

Really they were great - he worked with our budget and put together a great spread for our guests. With out a doubt, our next launch party will be catered by Peter and clan!

Bahn mi sandwiches + spring rolls + bar + music + people = awesome party. Really. It is that easy.
author: Ian T.

description:
I ordered the Lemongrass Pork bánh mì.  It was $4.50, which was on the 'pricier' side for the area, but that's ok.  I picked this place because of all the newspaper clippings in the window that claimed this was one of the best places in SF for bánh mì.  The filling of the sandwich was delicious, however I didn't like the bread - it was a little too hard/crispy and kept cutting the roof of my mouth.  I also ordered this spicy, but it didn't come out spicy at all.  

An "A-OK" sandwich.  Other things to note:  cash only.  The inside is kinda small.  It's more of a carry-out restaurant.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
I'm no banh mi expert, but I DO love a good vegetarian sandwich -  and I'm happy to report that the banh mi chay (tofu) from Little Vietnam Cafe not only amounts to a delicious $3.50, but it includes one of the best iterations of tofu I've had, ever. 

I'm actually not the biggest fan of tofu, despite its (ideally) versatile nature and my status as a vegetarian... and that's because most people DON'T know how to cook it!! (c'mon, how many times have you had a really, awfully bland tofu dish?!) The fried tofu here, however, has an interesting texture and is super flavorful, especially when combined with the other ingredients.

Alas, this is the only dish I've actually tried at LVC... but, when the banh mi chay is yummy, cheap, and filling, you can't go wrong!
author: Sam S.

description: Very Good Bahn Mi Sandwich. Probably the best in the neighborhood... but not as good as some of the shops in the Tenderloin. Must go with pork anything.
author: Zoran L.

description:
All I have to say is the Veggie Banh Mi sandwich is the bomb!  Don't know what makes that marinated tofu taste so good, but it hits the spot.  Of course you get fresh shredded carrots and cucumber, but also fresh bread that's crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.

Yummy soups and and super convenient takeaway rolls with all the fixings. Perfect local spot for a quick lunch or anytime meal at a great price, definitely will visit again.
author: J B.

description:
The pate banh mi is excellent--a lot of places use canned or pre-formed pate, this stuff tasted fresh and excellent.  The ham banh mi uses three kinds of ham--"american", "vietnamese", and pate.  The "vietnamese" ham looks like head cheese, and the pate is actually chicken liver-based, not pork liver, but that didn't bug me at all.  Still, if you are squeamish about head cheese, don't get this one, but it does taste great.  

These sandwiches are well worth the extra money you might pay over a Lee's banh mi or some other cafe.
author: Dave L.

description: I really wanted to like this place cuz this is like my 2nd time coming here but after i found long piece of hair in the spring roll i was disguised! YUCK!  I should have taken a pic of this...
author: Thomas C.

description: Great spot for quick and easy veggie sandwich.  Staff are all very nice and efficient.
author: Chuck M.

description: Had the roasted pork banh mi for lunch today.  It was definitely one of the best that i have eaten.  Glad i live just a few blocks away.
author: Dilly M.

description:
Wow, I've finally found my weakness. Finally the most authentic Vietnamese food in San Francisco. My coworker usually dubS me as the "Vietnamese food order-er" . I don't mind that at all, because I rarely I get to showcase my Vietnamese skills. 

One suggestion: Bun Rieu. By far the most authentic version of it. It comes dead second in comparison to my mom's which is THE BEST (hi mom!). Their bun rieu was perfectly tasting, great portion, full of crab rieu, and fresh veggies. Great value. Not expensive. Highly recommend this place for real great Vietnamese soup. 

They even have Vietnamese desserts in the refrigerated section. Kinda like in the fast food joints.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: since I was in the area, I introduced myself to a Vietnamese sandwich place I haven't been before.  I've passed by before, but having a small craving for Vietnamese, I thought I'd check the place out.  It's small, with a few table to sit-down, and clean.  The sandwiches didn't seem too special, so I'd say it was alright.  The other good thing is that the staff were Vietnamese, which I'd say made the shop more authentic.
author: Jessica S.

description:
It's a far cry from Saigon Sandwiches, but it will do considering it's just steps from my place (dangerous).

So far, I've tried the....

*Banh Mi Combo Sandwich: It was ok; it had more ham than anything; very little pate, fatty pork, etc. It was messy to eat; the sauce kept on dripping it out.  You have to eat it right away; otherwise the sauce would have made the bread soggy. It's NOTHING like the Banh Mi from Saigon, but then again I haven't found any place that trumps them. 
*Grilled Lemongrass Pork Sandwich: YUMMY! The pork was flavorful and hot. Condiments of pickled veggies help balance out the oiliness of the pork. Bread was nice and toasted outside and soft inside. 

Overall the food is worth 3 STARS, but the owner is super friendly which is why I'm bumping up my rating to 4 stars! 

I'll be back to try the bun...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Great duck banh mi, crispy and crunchy, bread is fairly soft.  Mint mojito is nice.  Stairs are crooked though, they need to fix it before someone gets hurt
author: Paul C.

description:
I love Banh mi (vietnamese sandwiches), so I might be bias, but you can't beat the quality of food this place has to offer. And considering the price, it is an added bonus.  The place is pretty small.  It does't offer much seating, but takeout is not a problem.  The only problem is having to wait to eat the delicious food.  I tried both the banh mi with grilled pork and grilled chicken.  Both meats were moist and well seasoned. I'll definitely be back to try more whenever I'm in town.  

Tip: Remember to bring cash with you.  I always forget to have cash with me whenever I visit SF.  Luckily, there are ATMs close by.
author: Priya J.

description:
My #1 spot to nurse a hangover on Sunday mornings. 

Love their bun bo hue, vermicelli with egg rolls and pork, combination sandwich. Even the picky vegetarian Marty loves their Vegetarian Pho and their bi chay sandwich.

They have no problem sub-ing items (ie, fried tofu in their pho)

ps. Just so excited to finally find a Vietnamese joint with people who SPEAK Vietnamese, AND make good legit food. cheap.
author: Jane N.

description: Delicious! Fresh ingredients and beautifully prepared! Glad I stumbled upon this place!
author: Grace L.

description:
I wanted this place to be good.  I really did.  It's such a cute little hole-in-the-wall, not crappy looking but actually semi-charming inside.  It's what kept me coming back until I realized it wasn't worth it (except for the pandan soy milk.)

But their food just isn't that great.  It's not horrible but the banh mi and rolls are slightly on the expensive end (though not too expensive) and not worth it.

The banh mi is overall decent but usually inconsistent.  Like sometimes it's solid, sometimes it's hard as a rock.  There's a bit too much of a bread-to-filling ratio usually.  They lack many of the traditional sandwich fillings but on the other hand they have a few extra ones you won't find other places (i.e. 5-spice chicken.)

Then their spring rolls, they serve them with the same fillings as the sandwiches.  And all there are is two average-sized rolls stuffed with about 90% noodles 10% filling for $4.  Lame.

Their pho/bun actually is a pretty good deal, pricewise, $6-$7 for a HUGE bowl. (I agree with the reviewer who wrote they look small in the picture but when you get them they're huge.)  Too bad it's not very good.  Actually, it's pretty bad.  It's oily and not very tasty -- since when was pho supposed to be like that?!?!
author: David A.

description: I go here at least once a week!! I usually grab food to go because it's not a very big place. However, there is outdoor seating, which is great for a nice day. It's a family run business, and the owner and his kids are always so friendly. The banh mi sandwiches are amazing! I usually get the pork or five spice chicken sandwiches. Their vermicelli bowls are so yummy too!
author: Sara C.

description:
I have been to this restaurant three times and I have come to the conclusion: THE BREAD IS "MEH".

I have to agree with one of the other reviews on here-- relative to other places that sell Banh Mi, the bread lacks the crunch. 

Five Spice Chicken Sandwich -- it was good, however I would have preferred more meat. The ratio between the stuff that was actually in the sandwich and the bread was about 1:3.

Grilled Pork Sandwich -- My first thought was "where is the cilantro?" which prompted a WTF face because at first glance it was just a meat sandwich if you're into that...unfortunately the meat was just OK. There were a couple cucumbers and some carrots, but that was about it. Maybe they ran out of cilantro? 

The sandwiches are $4.15 each excluding tax. Knowing there are other Banh Mi places on Clement Street including one right around the corner, they really need to step it up.
author: Carol W.

description: We had the grilled pork bahn mi, the fried spring roll, and a couple of fresh tofu rolls, and it was all just barely OK.  The pork didn't taste grilled at all, and it was sparse.  The rolls were rather dry. The bahn mi place a few blocks away on Clement is exponentially better, and just as inexpensive.  Why waste time with this joint?
author: Heather G.

description:
I have only tried their Viet sandwich and mmm, I like it. It's one of the better places to get if you're in the area. 

I like the combination and I like how they ask if you want it to be spicy of not. Other places just put it on and I hate having to take the jalapenos out.

I have also tried the beef lemongrass. It's not too bad, I would love it more if it had a more powerful hint of lemongrass.
author: Mandy D.

description:
How did I grow up in the Richmond, live down the street from this spot, have a best friend who's full blood second generation Vietnamese, and have never tried a Vietnamese sandwich until now?

Needs saracha, oyster sauce, and I wish they would add a little more meat.

DE-lish.

Service would have been better if I had brought Marilyn along to speak Vietnamese.  That's why I love Clement Street, though.  They don't like yuppies lol.
author: Lauren R.

description: Came here for a quick bite and tried out the banh mi. The bread was kinda dry but the meat was excellent. I loved the how the meat was marinated. The man was also very nice to give me a small bowl of soup to wash down the dry sandwich. They offer a bunch of other things on the menu too. I want to try the pho next. Probably won't eat the banh mi again.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
I am not the biggest fan of Vietnamese food but this place serves up my favorite Vietnamese food in the area.  

I have had most of the banh mi's here and all are good, especially the chicken and pork.  The tofu banh mi is a healthy alternative.  Bread is always fresh and vegetables have a fresh crunch to them.  Freshness of the ingredients is consistent.

The vermacelli and rice plates are very generous and always enjoy the special fish sauce they use.  

I'm not sure which is the most "authentic" but I do prefer Little Vietnam's sandwiches over those of Cafe Bunn Mi and Nom Nom Truck because the veggies are fresher.  Service is always excellent, even when it gets busy.

At lunchtime, they provide pre-packaged shrmp rolls and tofu.  Excellent value if you need a quick bite.
author: Re-pley Z.

description:
Another gem hole-in-the-wall eatery in San Francisco, amazing vietnamese sandwich place in San Francisco. Service was excellent... the owner is very friendly.
 
The pork sandwich served on a toasted french roll with pickled carrots, cucumber and jalapenos if you like it spicy. The tofu sandwich is not what you'd expect...very surprising good!

We all enjoyed our meals and their homemade soy drink.
author: Hector F.

description: I can't get enough of this place! I not only love their sandwiches, but I adore the workers! No other Vietnamese sandwich shops can compare to Little Vietnam's sandwiches AND service. It is my spot - can't get the Sunday Banh Mi experience anywhere else. I've tried.
author: Linda T.

description:
I can't boast about anything better then this honestly in terms of service and food is rather good too. they don't have too too much variety but still really good at what they do and not to mention the service is really good as I say, really friendly people, really nice and decent family, I've had a few conversations with david and min I believe that's his wife or whatever her name is. never unpleasant too happy to help.

I have a physical disability, I am totally blind and I really felt that they were very friendly and opened to helping. there was no reluctance to help, unwillingness to read off all that they have, and at first when I was getting to know the area he helped me outside and he was pretty willing to telll me which street was where without me asking. I had a decent hand on that aspect already but he inquired where I was going and detailedly told me a basic map, not that I needed it  I am thinking of going back today, and I am sure that he will once again do the same even if I've been there a million and one time. If he notices me, he comes out or shouts out the window at me to help me out. Even if I don't need it I find that being very courteous and shows a spirit of wanting to help.

The first time I was there I was confused what there was. Most restaurants don't really want to tell you or is reluctant, but david was more then happy, we had a bit of confusion because I was confused as to what he and the other catering guy was trying to tell me, and he patiently started over.

I enjoy the fact, that the family in general is so friendly that after my order we always manage to chat a bit, and sometimes at restaurants I feel so in the way as if they think I am some sort of inconvenience there. no such feelings here. I know david well enough, appreciate that fact. that place almost feels homely to me.


as to their food, I like the ham and barbeque pork the best, and his vermachilli noodles with the imperial rolls are excellent.It is always tasty and there are always premade stuff but if I want it fresh they are always happy to make it for me. 


so, give it a try, if you haven't.
author: Rachel N.

description: Little Vietnam just catered our daughter's birthday party, and working with them was a pleasure. Linda, who we worked with, responded to emails promptly, put together a great menu for us, and had the food ready right when we needed it. The food was absolutely delicious, and adults and kids (mostly 2 year olds) couldn't get enough of it. Thanks so much, Little Vietnam!
author: Karen L.

description:
My clients and I ALL really like this friendly, fast, and super healthy take-out cafe. Having now tried everything on the menu here, I would have to say that LVC's attention to the detail and refinement of their dishes truly ROCKS! Their prices are ultra affordable and there's a terrific variety of things to choose from so you don't get bored! 

It's great to find a casual  Asian cafe that has hearty soups(reduce/skip the noodles if you are eating 'low carb') with smooth flavors and seasonings along with fresh vegetarian choices. LVC also has awesome sandwiches, fresh/fried rolls, and prepared dishes. Perhaps one day they will consider offering their sandwiches on croissant rolls( the way Little Paris used to)?
author: Richard T.

description:
Love, love, love it here! 
The service is lovely.
The food is authentic and delicious. 

Eat in, or take out. 

Fantastic. 
Fantastic. 
Fantastic.
author: A. H.

description:
I've been coming here on a regular basis for over a year now. I always get the same thing; lemongrass pork sandwich with a fried egg, extra jalepenos and no cilantro and a coconut juice.You would have to eat it right away or it won't be as good--the soft yolk drips all over. Yum! It can get a little messy, but it is so worth it. I've tried the tofu salad once, it was good! =)

Love the old man there, he is so sweet. Always a big smile on his face, but if the Niners are playing, you won't find him there! He is a huge fan and looks super cute with his red niners hat. =)
author: Michelle C.

description:
Since the Vietnamese restaurant on Geary (at 4th Ave?)  changed owner, I've been coming to this one instead.  And thanks to Yelp, that's how I found it!  For years I've been walking by after having done Asian grocery shopping, I didn't really notice it.

The reason I didn't notice it: yes it's small.  So it's primarily a takeout place.  It's kind of like the sandwich place on Larkin street (Lee's Sandwich), but on this side of town.

The staff is super friendly.  The pricing is great -- one of the main reasons I like Vietnamese food places!  And the food is fresh, and what you'll expect from a good Vietnamese restaurant.  As I often tell my friends: the PBS program globe Trekker spent two episodes just on Vietnamese food (most countries get one episode of less).  Vietnamese food is lighter (less fat and salt, I think), but still very flavorful because they use plenty of herbs.  

I wish they would open a little later. So my friends and I can come here for dinner.  At the time of my comment, they actually open until 6:30.  But that still put dinner out of the picture for me and my friends most of the time.

Took one star off because the noodle soup is just slightly not as great as other Vietnamese restaurant I have tried, and a little less generous on the ingredients -- and noodle soup is my favorite kind of Vietnamese dish! But I would come back again and again for their sandwiches and vermicelli bowl!
author: Charlie Y.

description: Very nice staff, fast was prepared quickly and as ordered, and  the Banh Mi was the best I've had, it is my favorite Vietnamese shop.
author: Tim H.

description: Little Vietnam Cafe offers quite a tasty and sizable banh mi. The pork is packed with heavy lemongrass flavor and although the pork is more on the fatty side, the meat is still very tender. The chicken is also another good option but I prefer the flavor of the pork more. Sandwiches are built upon a crusty roll which can slightly scrape the roof of your mouth due to its extra toastiness. They are packed with your standard banh mi fixins including lots of cilantro. The jalapeno slices do not hold many heat packed seeds so feel free to ask for more if you'd like a spicier banh mi. To top it all off, the older man running the cashier is very friendly and full of smiles! Be sure to also check out their spring rolls and rice plates too. There's even a hand-sanitizer dispenser mounted on the wall by the front windows so that your hands can be germ free to hold your bahn mi.
author: Maya S.

description: Quick and easy spot for a great Vietnamese sandwich and an ice coffee to-go.  The owner is always working the front, and I think its his wife in the kitchen.  Very little seating.
author: Andrew R.

description: Great Chicken Pho- killer noodles, and all around very authentic and comforting. Only downside is MSG, which is discernible (dry mouth and buzzing tongue), but not to the point where I would avoid the place as in other Pho joints that use buckets of it. The BBQ pork spring rolls are top quality. Lastly, extremely friendly service.
author: Earls C.

description:
Having lost our neighborhood Vietnamese sandwich place, the Mr. and I are ever on the lookout for somewhere new to feed our cravings. Today's answer was Little Vietnam Cafe.

The pork Vietnamese sandwiches were delicious. They came with all the usual veggie fixin's (which, might I add, tasted VERY fresh and crisp), and weren't too spicy. The bread was toothy but not hard, and the pork itself was flavorful and tender. Not only that, but the portion size was more than generous for the price!

We'll most definitely be back.
author: Liz E.

description:
Solid place. I want to give it 3.5 stars. This is my neighborhood bahn mi place. For $6 you can get an iced coffee (strong, the way I like it), and bbq pork bahn mi. It's on Clement and 6th, so hard to find parking though.

If you are watching the Nom Nom truck on the Great Food Truck Race on the Food Network and all of a sudden get an inkling for bahn mi, they are the place to call.

This really should be at about $4 but I forget I no longer live in the San Gabriel Valley area of LA and we are just coming out of a recession!
author: Tian L.

description:
Loved the banh mi here - the meat is marinated so perfectly. My best friend brought me here, and I followed suit by doubling her order: the chicken banh mi with no mayo and extra cilantro. Definitely beats Lee's Sandwiches!!

We also got the shredded tofu spring roll, which was really good. It doesn't come cut, so it kinda looks like a rice paper burrito. The sauce is soo good and adds the perfect flavor. The spring roll seemed really authentic and homemade - just don't wait to eat them! The rice paper gets gross after it's been in the fridge. It can also be a bit messy to eat, but so delicious!

I'll probably be back to try all the other delicious dishes on their small but modest menu. Oh yeah, and agreed.. the man behind the counter is the sweetest person ever. So great service too!

**EDIT: I should also mention that this place is CASH ONLY for all you fellow credit card users :)
author: Catherine C.

description: The bánh mì here is cheap and good. A great go-to lunch spot if you're in a pinch.
author: Nick F.

description:
Massive portions. Dirt cheap prices. Clean. Healthy. My favorite Vietnamese place as of yet.

Too bad they don't stay open past 6:30pm.
author: Hilarie S.

description:
I have trouble enjoying a good book when my tummy is screaming "Feed Me".  Fortunately, Little Vietnam Cafe is located near three good books spots (Richmond Library, Goodwill, and Green Apple)  If my tummy is screaming before I find my book (and because my chopstick skills are rudimentary at best and I don't trust myself not to make a complete mess if I am reading and eating with chopsticks), I order a vermicelli bowl with chicken and dine at the cafe.  I love the crunchy veggies, the fresh mint flavor and the amount of chicken is just right..  I've ordered this dish several times and there is always enough chicken to last until the last few bites. If I get my book first and want to dine al fresco at Mountain Lake Park, I will grab a bahn mi to go.   It is much easier to turn pages while eating a sandwich.

If you get a canned beverage, take an extra napkin to wipe the grim form the top of the can.

Even when the place is empty there is a noticeable amount of time between placing your order and when it is acceptable to pay.  But maybe this is a courtesy.  

I like the small counter with window seats.  I would recommend against the outside tables unless you like pigeons as dining companions.

The family that owns the cafe is very nice and the food is wonderful alternative to all the dim sum along Clement.
author: Amy M.

description: Really enjoyed finding this little local place for a great simple lunch.  Typical Vietnamese vermicelli with the spring roll, chicken and pork.  Everything was very tasty and fresh.  Appreciate the family run business.  Ordered it to go and enjoyed it on the outside tables.  It's good and local.  Thank you.
author: Stefan L.

description: There's a reason why these guys got the Best Of award for their banh mi. For me, it rivaled Saigon Sandwich when I first had it. Now, I look forward to going to this place. Maybe it's the neighborhood and the tea shop across the street that add to it, but I cannot deny that my mouth waters at the thought of their banh mi.  I even tried the one with the egg and special sauce and though I am firm believer of leaving perfection the way it is, I left no crumbs. :)
author: Norma ..

description: This used to be my go-to place for vietnamese sandwiches because when i first started going here they really put a lot of love into their sandwiches like really stuff 'em.  But now its not the same.  Before their fancy pork sandwich had pate smeared on the bread and then the fancy pork slices would come next.  After they put up a new menu board the pretty woman i think it was the daughter claimed that they never did it that  way ever, the way she said it made it sound like i was making it up to get free pate smear which i wasn't but i remembered it clearly because that was the reason why it became my favorite sandwich.  The pate made it creamier and tastier, because fancy pork without it is kinda bland.  Oh well i guess i have to find a new bun mi spot.  Thanks for the years of good food.
author: Joseph G.

description:
I had lunch here a few days ago, deciding against Pho Clement, a tried and true Pho spot right down the street.  I'm intent on trying as many Pho places around that area as possible to make a final decision on who wins in the Pho race... pho show!  

Anyhow, this location is a tiny little spot... hole-in-the-wall status.  When I found parking to pick up the Pho (To-Go), I couldn't even see that I was parked RIGHT IN FRONT of the darn place.  The red awning, Little Vietnam Cafe.

The elder gentleman behind the counter was very nice, greeting me with smiles and excitement.  I ordered the usual: Pho Tai Gan.  

Issue # 1:  Instead of the tendon I usually order (Gan), they gave me beef brisket (Nam).  On the phone, I told him "Pho Tai Gan," and he said.. "Pho Tai Nam?"  I corrected him and enunciated "Gan."  He said "ohh, okay okay.."  

Issue #2:  There was very little food... the equivalent of a "Small" in most Pho restaurants.. except it was $7.50.  Wow?  That's an awful lot of money for a SMALL bowl of Pho... leaving me still hungry after my meal. 

Issue #3:  Little Vietnam Cafe was less tasty and more expensive than their neighbor, Pho Clement.

They had dessert cups available as well.  When I saw them, it shot me back to 10 years old when my mom used to get them for me.  They were $2.50 a cup.  Yikes.  

I'm going to continue my journey to find a Pho place around this area that takes the cake.  

Truth be told, if there were no other Pho places even remotely nearby, I'd probably justify coming here for their Pho.  Like I said, it isn't BAD, per se, it's just not as good as some of their local (3 blocks away!) competitors.  

2.745396 Stars for their efforts... even though they messed up on my order!
author: Johnson N.

description: Love the Banh Mi! Great laid-back atmosphere with good food.
author: Bridget B.

description: I've had their chicken, pork, and tofu bahn mi's, pre-packaged pork and shrimp rolls, pho, bun rieiu (crabmeat soup), and refreshing vermicelli bowls.  Everything, and I mean everything, is delicious here.  You cannot beat the prices, and the flavors are more vibrant for me here than at Cafe Bun Mi down the block.
author: Seghel Y.

description: Super friendly people and delicious tofu bahn mi to be found here. Came in after a trip to goodwill on the advice of well-trusted yelpers. The sandwich was $4.25 or so and came out super fast! This is the bahn mi bread I expect- super light but with a crispy outside that just has to leave crumbs all over your shirt with every bite. This sucker was loaded with carrots and cilantro, sweet mayo dressing, a few jalapenos and deliciously thin chunks of tofu. The owner was very friendly and seemed to know his frequent customers. Their thai iced tea was fresh and not too sweet, perfect for this freak warm winter we're having. This sandwich made its way to my top bahn mi, up there with Saigon.
author: Cori W.

description:
This is my favorite place to eat on Clement st. 

Every time I mention the place to somebody they say they haven't been I take them immediately. They have the best pork sandwich in the city. I actually like it equally or more than Saigon sandhich, which is saying something.
