All the employees seem to be family and that is of course charming. The prices are very low and the food is a great value. I'm actually leaving to go there right now.
author: Jay C.

description: I had the combination beef pho tonight. The noodles were thicker than the usual rice noodles I'm used to in other pho restaurants but it didn't bother me either way. The noodles weren't mushy or hard. I'm not a big meat fan, but the combo had 3 or 4 types: meatball, ribeye, and shank, I think. The broth wasn't too bad: it was hot enough, not salty, it had some flavor. There were enough herbs, bean sprouts for the meal. I feel like this place is a 3.5 star? Better than A-OK but I'm not convinced I'm a fan just yet.
author: Vicki T.

description: This is a total bias since these are the only Vietnamese sandwiches I've ever had.  I always get the same thing:  Lemongrass beef and pate in my sandwich...it's 5 bucks!  And I love going there on my lunch breaks!
author: Sam K.

description: This is far from the best Vietnamese food, but they have my favorite vermicelli bowl and it is priced right.  We had a bahn mi, vermicelli bowl, sodas and a spring roll for $18.  Not bad.
author: Cork C.

description:
This unpretentious little shop makes delicious and cheap Vietnamese food. I almost always get the $6 grilled chicken sandwich combo that comes with a Vietnamese iced coffee. 

The sandwiches are perfect: hefty toasted french rolls, lots of freshly grilled meat, crispy carrots strips, cilantro, mayo, and jalapeños. They are are neither too big, nor too small. If this size were the bear's porridge, it would be just right. That's right, the sandwiches are so good they make me reference Goldilocks and the Three Bears!

The little man behind the counter is incredible sweet and polite.

If I could eat here everyday I would, but I fear I'd start looking like a sandwich. And that's not a risk I'm willing to take.
author: Nik D.

description:
Makes great vermicelli bowls and banh mi for reasonable prices.

The food is authentic and you never have to wait too long.

Minus one star though because the last time I was there, the old man at the front counter accidentally threw a pair of used chopsticks into our takeout bag. Clearly an accident but still left a bad impression.

Favorites include Pate Banh Mi and Grilled Pork Vermicelli bowl.
author: Tina G.

description: Tried the chicken pho, they provide good meat portions but I didn't like the noodles, it was over cooked and the chow fun kind instead of the traditional pho noodles. The place is small and the staff is friendly but in terms of food, I would say it was just A-OK, will I come back? I am willing to try something else that is popular, maybe a sandwich instead.
author: Johanna P.

description:
Small shop with a lunch counter and a few tables in and out.  Nice man taking orders. Quick service.  Tried two different noodle bowl dishes which were just ok: 
broiled pork w/ spring rolls (a bit mushy texture on the inside) & vermicelli
broiled pork w/ shrimp (kind of small) & vermicelli

Overall, not bad, but i've had better for similar pricing.

Tip:  cash only; a few customers had to go to an ATM.
author: Pat W.

description: My favorite place on Clement st for sandwiches !! great service, always fresh products I highly suggest to anyone and all my out of town guests I take there for lunch .!!
author: james m.

description: Had the banh mi and Vietnamese iced coffee here many times and it's been consistently good. The guy who runs this place is quite friendly and gets your order to you quickly. I like that they sell the Vietnamese desserts in the refrigerated case as well as some small entree dishes that are prepared and ready to take to-go.
author: Kent W.

description: Come here for an authentic vietnamese meal. It's really fresh and tastes great. The customer service is really quick, friendly and efficient.
author: Tom T.

description: I LOVE THEIR SANDWICHES! The chicken sandwich and beef. I love the chicken sandwich because it is SUPER MOIST AND YUMMY! This place is also really cheap.
author: Linda P.

description:
This review is for the chicken pho.
Service was fast and friendly. Prices were standardly cheap.
I'm not a picky eater, especially when it comes to pho. I understand that the perfect balance is hard to strike for a bowl of pho, especially for pho ga (chicken), which is often bland compared to the beef. This is my first time eating here, so it is very possible that the restaurant was just "having a bad day" or my bowl was the "1 in a 100 miss". In any case, here's the breakdown: the broth was the blandest I've ever had. Period. The absence of taste actually grossed me out. The noodles were okay, the texture was a little off but it wasn't what made the soup bad. The chicken also had absolutely no flavor and some pieces were undercooked. Overall, one of my least satisfying bowls of pho. 
Considering the other reviews of this place, my advice would be to stick to the sandwiches.
author: Yana N.

description:
I had ordered my chicken bahn mi to go and ate it an hr later so my review may be different if I had eaten the sandwich right away, but overall I thought the sandwich was a little above average.  I'd be back to try it again to make sure.

The flavors were all there...it was just the consistency of the chicken was a bit tough and thin, the bread not toasty enough (again it could be because I ate the sandie later rather than right away), and one half of the sandwich had a great dollop of mayo which I don't like in my bahn mis.

I need to research if mayo is usually used in bahn mis because I've had it with and without.  I'm not a huge mayo fan and I actually think it detracts from the flavors that make a bahn mi so delish.

But again the flavors were good (when the mayo didn't overwhelm): the saltiness of the chicken mixed with the nicely sweet pickled veggies, burst of cilantro, the crunch of the cucumber matched with the hint of heat from the jalapeno all worked.

And at $4 a sandwich, not bad...not bad at all.  Will be back to try again.
author: C A.

description:
*The best banh mi in the city.

Must Order:
Pork Banh Mi
Lemongrass Tofu
author: Tina N.

description:
Being a white girl from the suburbs of the Midwest, I was skeptical when my Yelp Friends (aka, people quickly becoming My Only Friends, God Help Me) told me about bahn mi, a Vietnamese sandwich that they all had a raging boner for. A sandwich with carrots? Get the hell outta here with that. Clearly you don't know me and we shouldn't be friends, because I fuggin' hate carrots. Except I love them on bahn mi and I am on the verge of selling my body outside of this cafe just so I can eat these sandwiches everyday. Chill out guys I'm only going to have to do it like once a week because these things are like $4 a pop. Actually, if I'm going to whore myself out, I'm going to do it for Bun Mee because 1. it's closer to my house 2. it's slightly better and 3. they have authentic Vietnamese sweet potato fries with the authentic Vietnamese spicy mayonaise that I like. 

I went here with some fellow good looking Yelpers after a walk around Land's End, during which we encountered this cute Australian chick who was looking for Baker Beach because apparently China Beach wasn't g-d good enough for her (maybe she wanted to see some franks and beans?). My friend Peebs, who is very sweet and would never make fun of me, asked if she was from England and I followed up with: "So, are you here by yourself?" BECAUSE I AM A CREEP LIKE THAT and while I totally didn't suggest she come to a party in my basement, I knew there was no recovering from my attempt at being polite to foreigners so I kept my damn mouth shut from then on. 

The point of me telling you that story is that SHIT GOT WEIRDER with strangers at Little Vietnam Cafe. Peebs got some kind of rice noodle dish that had some kind of fried roll in it that looked hella good. So good in fact, that not just one old Asian lady stopped to comment about it, but two old Asian ladies at two separate times stopped to comment about it. After the first one, Peebs was already on the verge of strangling the next person that came up to her because naturally she wanted to eat her lunch in peace. The second lady came over, hovered over Peebs while commenting on each individual ingredient, as steam slowly started shooting out of Peebs' ears and I was sitting next to her laughing my ass off. "Oh, rice noodles are good for you...oh and pepper! Pepper keeps your body warm...Looks soooo good!" I think that old lady wanted a bite, and was seriously standing there until Peebs would give her one, except Peebs didn't because THAT IS WEIRD, LADY.
author: Joe T.

description:
i'm not going to tell you a thing more about this sacred gem other than that i absolutely adore it. 
now forget i ever said that and don't go clogging up my new favorite spot!!!!! 

p.s everything is delicious and affordable and homemade and exquisite. 
pps. bring cash... AND a smile!!!
author: Libra J.

description: This is the best banh mi you will ever experience. I've been coming here for the past year and finally got around to posting a review. Get a banh mi with a Peter's special and you will most likely incur an orgasm. From what my Vietnamese friends tell me, this is as close to authentic Vietnamese banh mi you'll come across. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone.
author: Michael S.

description:
Friendlly service with a flair for perfection.
Mmmmm tasty vietnamese foods. I can sit outside on their silver chairs and tables enjoying my meal on 6th ave. and clement st.
author: Noucha A.

description:
I only got the cold combo banh mi, but based on that alone, I'd go back for more.  It was one of the best Vietnamese sandwiches I've had in the whole Bay Area, and worth the extra dollar, in my opinion (sandwiches cost $4.50).  The bread was light and airy... could have been a little crisper, but at least it didn't cut up my mouth.  The pate was plentiful and tasty, and the deli meats were really flavorful and much higher quality than most places use.  Maybe the best part was the pickled veggies, which were much tastier than average - crispy with a nice balance of sweet & sour.

Now I'll have to think of excuses to visit the Inner Richmond more often!
author: Mona S.

description:
A small place with a couple of tables outside to enjoy the sun...when there is sun.

sandwiches are $4,( we had the combo and fancy pork) and they have other stuff like spring rolls and pho and rice plates and noodles. We just came here for some sandwiches, they're not bad, pretty stuffed and filling. spring rolls were huge, but needed more sauce than the dinky lil cup they give us. 

parking for us has been ok both times, will be back!
author: Christine M.

description: First came here because of a ScoutMob deal, and have been coming back ever since. Oftentimes when shopping on Clement, I feel very white and out of place. At Little Vietnam, the old man behind the counter doesn't expect me to pronounce menu items like a native and his team in the kitchen makes a mean, quick sandwich. I recommend the pate banh mi and a mint limeade!
author: Tatyana K.

description: Probably the best banh mi I've had in the city. The bread is fresh, warm and crispy on the outside, and they're not shy on the fillings. The soups are pretty good here, too, and the owners are super friendly.
author: Sabrina V.

description:
I probably visit Little Vietnam Cafe...about once a week! The shredded tofu spring rolls are the best.  It's the perfect little meal and they're only $4.  My sister really likes the Vietnamese sandwiches!

This place is really low-key and you would probably miss it if you we're just walking by, but I love it!

They also have a variety of drinks and a coconut drink that is soo yummy. I always feel a little healthy when I have the spring rolls from here because they're light, but still filling and a pretty good size.  Must try this place if you're in the area and need a quick meal!
author: Cherie A.

description:
BAM! I just sunk my teeth into a hot pepper in my 5 spice chicken sandwich. I drove across town for this place and it did not disappoint me. The french bread was stuffed filled with ingredients and all were exceptionally fresh. 

I loved the consistency of meat, carrots, cucumbers and spicy peppers in this sandwich. I am going to make this a must visit when working from home as it was cheep and fantastic.  5 bucks for a sandwich and diet coke.
author: Ryan B.

description: I love the sandwiches here as well as the 5 spice chicken + imperial rolls. One of the best Vietnamese hole in the walls on Clement.
author: Mike M.

description: I've only had their Banh Mi and some of their pre-made rolls, but it's always awesome. It's small but quick and efficient. Try their pandan flavored soy milk, mmmmmm!
author: Joh W.

description: Craving for Vietnamese sandwich? But too lazy  to make a trip out to Little Paris in Chinatown? Now you're perplexed because by experience, you have not encountered a Vietnamese cafe that serves a good Combination Ham sandwich. Give Little Vietnam Cafe a try, its right off Clement street and the parking situation is better than Chinatown!
author: Rebecca L.

description: Ordered the lemongrass pork vermicelli bowl, along with the fresh tofu spring rolls.  Not only was the service fast and friendly, the food was delicious. So glad I found this place! The kitchen gladly modified some of the dishes I ordered to my specs and everything was fantastic.  Little Vietnam will be my go to place on 6th & Clement!
author: Rosanne D.

description:
They weren't kidding when they said "little Vietnamese Cafe." I came across this place for lunch craving some warm soup to ease the discomfort of a previous night of killing my liver. 

Anyways, I ordered the Beef Combo soup bowl and was it awesome. The broth was on hit, and the size was just quite enough for a lunch. I also wanted to try all of the rolls they had on advertisement infront of the cash register. Next time... 

Overall, I would say this place is worth seeking out.
author: Jason C.

description:
The Food:
I'm a total fan of Vietnamese sandwiches and I can totally say this place ranks as my favorite local place for a perfectly flavorful and filling sandwich. I always get the Barbeque Chicken Sandwich for $4. I remember they used to put mushrooms in it too but they don't do that anymore. There's always a good amount of meat and veggies in it and it's always super well seasoned. The bread is always fresh and toasted. They also serve pho, which is the next thing on my list to try.

The Atmosphere:
The place is super tiny but there are about 3 seats near the window for a quick meal. 

The Service:
The workers there are always super friendly and they have pretty fast service. I've never had to wait a long time for my sandwich.
author: Tiffany Y.

description: Been here twice and both times have gone above satisfaction for my banh mi cravings. Chicken or roasted duck are bomb.
author: Garrett O.

description:
Went for lunch

Mom had the lemongrass pork with rice and two eggs
I had the chicken salad rolls. 

Mom said there was alot of pork, fresh salad, freshly cookied rice. The pork was tender, flavorful and plentiful. 

The chicken salad rolls were bland. Needed more sauce. THey should include two sauces. But my mom was smiling, she was soo damn happy. 
No bathrooms, so minus a star.
author: Charlene C.

description:
got a tofu bahn mi here a while back.  it was good but not super-fantastic. i remember thinking it needed more flavor and some spice.  perhaps their other options are better.

i'm on a quest to find the best bahn mi in SF - lemme know what yer fav is!
author: Diane D.

description:
Oh my.. what happened to this place?  I'm hoping they didn't change owners.  We called an order to take out : 2 chicken noodles soups and a bbq chicken sandwich.

The noodle soups were TERRIBLE!  The broth had no flavor, tasted like MSG mixed with hot water.  The chicken they used is even different.  It was so bad my husband and I both ate less than half and threw it out which says a lot since we were both starving and would have inhaled an semi-mediocre noodle soup.  It was that BAD.

The sandwich was good... the only reason they were not demoted to 1 star.  The usual friendly older male owner wasn't there, but a young girl.  I really hope they didn't change.. and it was just an off day..
author: Sam S.

description: Their spring rolls are GIANT and super tasty. I love this place and wished I lived closer.
author: Sally S.

description:
Pricey for what you get.

AMBIANCE: Small store front off Clement.  There are a couple tiny tables inside, and a few tables outside (good for people watching if the weather is nice).  Best to take your food to go-- especially if its sunny out, since GGP is so close by!

SERVICE: The guy working the register was super frantic, but managed to still be friendly.  There are some people working in the back (couldn't count how many) who were incredibly efficient.  Food came out in mere minutes (practically seconds) after I ordered.

FOOD:
- Banh mi + drink combo ($7): Individually, banh mi costs $4.15 and drinks anywhere between $2-3... so the combo meal doesn't save you much (if at all).  I ordered the lemongrass grilled pork banh mi and an iced coffee to go.  I thought the portion size was pretty small for the price you pay.  The sandwich had an uneven distribution of meat (a large proportion of which was fatty/gristly), pickled carrots/radish, jalapenos (not very spicy at all!) and cilantro.  The bread lacked the crunchy/flaky crust I've come to associate with banh mi baguettes, and was chewy.  All these criticisms aside, the flavors were harmonious, and what I expected when I ordered the sammich.  The iced coffee was SO anemic.  Two to three sips later, I was hitting the dregs.  However, it was super concentrated, so if you do order an iced coffee to go, try to be patient and let the ice melt a bit to give you more bang for your buck.     

OVERALL: This was the most expensive banh mi I've ever eaten (I typically pay around $2-3 for a larger sandwich).  While I don't regret stopping into Little Vietnam Cafe to order my lunch, I probably won't be returning in the future.
author: Susanna W.

description: It's been years since I first reviewed this place and it's still fabulous as ever. I went here tonight with my boyfriend and we both had a grilled pork rice plate with imperial rolls and a side of vegetarian spring rolls. MMMMMMM....tender and smoky grilled pork: crispy imperial rolls filled with flavorful, moist meat: refreshing vegetarian spring rolls. this place is sooooooo good.
author: Robbie R.

description:
I like the concept  of this cafe. (FOUR STARS)

A small kitchen in the back, pre-made vietnamese items on the counter to go (spring rolls, papaya salad, banh mi sandwiches, soups (pho, bun bo xue, and the noodles without the soup), and canned drinks.  

There are mini stools along the window where you can sit and eat your food. There is a marble counter top ledge which gives it this homey feel.

I ordered the BANH MI PATE. (THREE STARS) Unfortunately  I was not too impressed. 

*The bread was not toasted or crispy. I SHOULD OF TOLD HIM TO REHEAT IT FOR ME

*The pate was too thick while it had good flavor, it did not come with Cha Lua (my favorite pork) In which case, it's my fault, I should of asked BUT most San Jose Viet joints do include Cha Lua in the sandwiches.  

$4.00 for this sandwich which usually should only cost about $ $2.50 to $3.00. 

Anyways...a lot of people stop by to pick up food to eat while on their lunch break or just pick up something to go. 

I'll have to revisit again.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Got the noodle bowl with shrimp and pork.  The shrimp and pork were SO flavorful, it was ridiculous. I also LOVED their pickled carrots.

BUT I will ask for more veggies next time.
author: Josie A.

description: I always get Tofu Banh mi, it's good. The same thing all the time and it doesn't get old. Good crunchy bread, but not like chewing on a rock. Fast service and friendly people. Perfect place for an impatient customer like myself.
author: Asako N.

description: I got the beef and chicken banh mi sandwhich. It was pretty darn tasty. I would definitely come back here although $4.50 is pricy for a vietnamese sandwhich.
author: Brian W.

description:
Saigon Sandwich is much better tasting, faster and has more bahn mi variations. 

The sandwich was pretty good but "fancy pork" = slices of processed pork loaf. The bread, jalapenos and sauce were very good. There were only 2 or 3 variations of the bahn mi and surprisingly pate cost extra and was barely detectable by taste when added. This sandwich did not take me back to my travels in Vietnam.

The shrimp spring rolls were pretty average and the wait was a bit long for a sandwich when I was the only one in line. 

If I was in the area and did not have time to head over to the Tenderloin I might try this again but given an option I would choose Saigon Sandwich or Lee's every time. 

The place is very small with only 1 or 2 2-person tables and a counter with 2 or 3 stools so not the best place to eat in.
author: Mike L.

description:
Truly excellent banh mi chay (vegetarian sandwich).  Nice slabs of flavorful tofu and plentiful vegetables.  Great bread and a generous size - just enough to allow me to leave without too much regret about not ordering a second one.

The space is tiny but there are a few window seats.  Definitely go for the hot sauce on the counter - I assume it's homemade, but either way it's delicious.

Up there with my gold standard, Mei Sum in Boston ... (http://www.yelp.com/biz/mei-sum-inc-boston#hrid:SbJYwqwQ4YTxkPZFUwVfGw)
author: Ethan R.

description: Wonderful Vietnamese sandwiches in the Inner Richmond that really rival others in the area. For about $4 you can get a great banh mi with lemongrass pork. Yummy! Also if you're in the mood for a more substantial lunch you can order udon or vermicelli. I can't wait to try their spring rolls! Remember it's cash only!
author: Rebecca D.

description: Great Bahn Mi (sandwiches) here. I know the owner, Thao, and she gave me a special order of 5-spice chicken, special sauce (it tasted like XO sauce), pickled veggies, pate, egg and green chilies. It was yummy. Thanks Thao!
author: Robert C.

description:
Craving a chicken sando from my favorite little Vietnamese cafe today, although the 9000 mile voyage is a bit of a problem.

For $4 I think it's a pretty good deal - sandwiches are made spicy with lots of veggies and meat on a crunchy baguette. I've had their spring rolls too, which are fresh and delicious. 

(Word to the homie outside selling eggs by the piece or by the carton and newspapers too.)
author: Kelly R.

description:
We're in heaven, a disco heaven!!!

This has my favorite sandwich EVER.  Pate.  Cold.  But the bread is hot.  And toasted.  And the filling was tender, juicy, zaftig, and an overall disco heaven in my mouth.  

The fur is shaking in this disco heaven......-Lady Gaga.  

That's how good it was.  I even walked over here from my house.  I, who abhor walking anywhere that the muni goes (because I bought a pass and it expires soon, and I want to get the most use out of it), walked the good 25 mins to this location.  Luckily it was all downhill after we got over the lone mountain.  And Lou made fun of me the whole time, wheezing and panting.  But it was worth it.

The sandwiches are not made until you order it.  The generous portion of pate is what my mother would have put on.  The seasoning of the pate was perfectly drool inducing.  I wanted to laugh, to cry, to shake someone.  I wanted to hold a penguin.  And the little trinket, the toxic smelling rubber band that held together the wax paper, it was still close to my heart that night.  Plus, it yanked some hairs off my BF's body when he unromantically rolled on to my arm in the middle of the night.  Silently, it protected me even in sleep.  

What other sandwich can do that?
author: Christina C.

description:
I am eating my way down Clement Street, at least Sandie S. says so.  

I had the misfortune of fracturing a tooth (probably Gialina hard crust pizza to thank for that), resulting in a root canal and now a temporary cap.... the short story of this is, 2 more dental visits over the next few weeks.  But, the silver lining is, I get to shop or eat around the Richmond dist.  After 2 long hours in the dental chair, a growling stomach and sore tush, I hightailed out of the dental office to go get me some grub  even 'tho one side of my lower jaw was all numb and I was barely coherent when I spoke.  I can tell from the look the cashiers gave me.

Furthermore, my dentist told me no food until I could feel again.  No way!  I'm on Clement St.  Even if the food was drooling down one side of my face, I was gonna eat.  After a little shopping, I turned the corner and decided to give this place a try.  For $3, I got a fancy pork Banh Mi.  I'd have to agree with Lolia "Smurf/Froyo Girl".  There was alot of cilantro, and doesn't hold a light to the sandwiches at Saigon Sandwiches or Irving St. Deli.  The bread was dry and harder than I liked, a layer of mayo, lots of carrot slivers, slices of jalapeno pepper, turnip and 3 small round thin slices of pork.  

The Banh Mi looked large and when I got home (hoping for resolution of the numbness), I took a bite and found the taste rather bland, even thru my paralyzed jaws.  I also picked up their 5 spiced chicken lunch tray for $5.  Slivers of dry BBQ chicken over thin rice noodles, served w/a sm salad and one chewy Vietnamese fried egg roll and a cup of sweet dipping sauce.  This was better than the sandwich.  

I wouldn't really call this a cafe.  I remembered it used to be a take-out dim sum shop years ago and the space is cramp with a couple of 2 person tables if you must eat there.  For Banh Mi, Saigon Sandwiches is still tops for me.  I'd consider returning to try another of their lunch trays 'tho.
author: Ry T.

description:
EXTRA! EXTRA! read all about it! yummy vietnamese sandwich in the richmond!

i seriously can't think of anything bad to say about their lemongrass pork sandwich. i couldn't wait to try it so i ate the whole thing in my car in about 2.5 min, no joke. it was delicious!!! if i wasn't so embarrassed i would have run right inside to get another.

i am in love with the meat. the lemongrass marinade was unforgettably tasty and made the meat a bit saucy and juicy! i felt like there was the right amount of cilantro, right amount of mayo and the perfect amount of carrots. and the bread was warm and didn't cut up the inside of my mouth. definitely worth the $4.
author: elsie k.

description: This is exactly how I want my vietnamese food-fresh, friendly, authentic and tasty. They have typical vietnamese sandwiches and pre-made plates with grilled meats and greens for those on the run. The man working the front is always smiling, and the woman in back was wrapping up the food with one hand and holding her baby in the other, haha...they yell the orders in korean to the kitchen. I'm glad this place is near my work.
author: katrina w.

description: I like this place enough and have been here many times.  The sandwiches are pretty good.  My favorite is the BBQ chicken.  The pre-made rolls and noodle plates are good too.  Haven't tried the rice plate dishes or sat down to eat here -- always to go.
author: barry a.

description:
2.5 stars really.

The cheap bastard in me thinks the mediocre (not enough meat) banh mis here are overpriced because you can get a top-notched one in the TL for a whole dollar less. Their pho is really average and you can taste the freezer in their meats, but I love pho of any kind so I slurp every bowl up anyway. Their 3-color drink is OK. Man, do I miss Little Paris when I am here.

I would never take anyone here....but this has become an usual spot for me. Why?

Because the bar stools, a window view and people watching on 6th Avenue makes it the best place to eat by yourself on Clement.

And I suppose that is worthy of rounding up.
author: Faffy L.

description:
Listen up: the real reason why this place is so highly reviewed, is that the owner's son who works here sometimes is a tall, very handsome Vietnamese guy... which is fine, but ya know, I'm here just for a sammich, not sausage.

The "best Vietnamese baguette shop on Clement" doesn't really say much.

1. This place essentially has no competition.
2. It's not really on Clement.
3. It's pretty bad.

You're better off running to the TL and grabbing a baguette from somewhere like Lee's Sandwiches. Vietnamese baguettes are one of my favorite meals... the thought of having to eat another one of these sandwiches turns my stomach.

The real problem here's the bread. Low volume = stale bread. They're not made here, and they're too big for even people with big mouths. As for the ingredients, the meager portion of meat is overwhelmed by the filler: large amounts of pickled shredded carrots. I also must mention that ordering one sandwich with no one in front of me took around five minutes for them to put together...

They sell other premade dishes like spring rolls, but I'd stay away. The shrimp I tried tasted foul and left a nasty taste in my mouth. Definitely not fresh.

The only plus side: noticeably nice service from a real Vietnamese guy serving real (though substandard) Vietnamese food. Eat here if you are on Clement, need some to go, and are tired of dim sum.

(Gomen Mia... I really wanted to like this place, just for you...)
author: Perci N.

description:
Every time I'm near Golden Gate for work or pleasure, I always go to Little Vietnam Cafe.  They have wonderful, authentic Vietnamese food.  Two big spring rolls for $4.  I like their traditional pork/spring rolls and the grilled chicken spring rolls.  Also, I just tried their banh mi ga (grilled hot french bread sandwich).  It was delicious and I great deal for $4.  

By the way, the owner is the sweetest man.
author: Quynh N.

description:
One of my favorite eateries in the Richmond. Inexpensive, fresh and light sandwiches. I order my sandwich with a side of spring rolls and a Tasco coconut drink, and love sitting outdoor table side. 

Fast and friendly service. 

One recommendation:  the out door sitting area could use a good scrubbing.
author: w l.

description:
Update 10/23/06: ****** 
If you are in a rush, call them in advance and order your sandwich: it will be waiting for you as you arrive!!!
They are getting pretty busy during the lunch hour, so calling ahead is not a bad idea.. ***********

After whining, keveching and moaning for over a year and a half about the demise of Little Paris, (which became a medical supply shop run by the landlord's son- the landlord wanted to double the rent, so LP had to leave) FINALLY we have found the most scrumptious and warm and toasty and crunchy and tasty Vietnamese BBQ Sandwiches in town. 

The man who owns the place is the nicest guy, always offering suggestions and today he even got me to try that drink in the refrigerated case (the one that I kept thinking reminded me of little clear tadpoles floating in a cup)... and YUM. I think he said they were some sort of seed and acidophilus (healthy, too!) and it was refreshingly good! 

$3 for a gigantic sandwich, but honestly I could probably put away two of them in one sitting. I haven't yet, but I think that day might come soon... mmmmmm. 

Freshly prepared take out (they run out of some of their stuff) and they are open till 8, which is perfect for the busy working Richmonder! 
5/5 because of the service, cleanliness, fresh food and value. 
Also, because he remembers that I like my sandwiches sans cilantro, always!
author: M'ia K.

description:
Okay, so for bun thit nuong, now we're getting into some quality territory. This is a tiny little place, and it's best to go ahead and call in advance. Also, be careful -- they sell prepackaged bun, which is pretty meh. What you want is the fresh made stuff, because it's pretty right on. The pork is very flavorful, the vegetables just right, and the sauce is just the right amount of sweet and spicy.

The sandwiches are okay, depending on when you get them. I absolutely concur with the stale bread thing -- get a bad one and it'll cut up the roof of your mouth something fierce. But we're not coming here for sandwiches, we're coming here for some fucking bun fucking thit noung.
author: Jake S.

description:
Two and a half stars, technically...

The vietnamese iced coffee ranks amongst the worst I've ever had: it manages to be both watery as well as burnt-tasting.  I had to toss it away after a few disgusting sips.  I thought, I hope the sandwich makes up for this.  And it did.  The sandwich was among the best I've ever had.  Very flavorful and delicious.  Get a sandwich, and go elsewhere  (anywhere elsewhere) on Clement for coffee that won't end up making you angry.
author: Susan B.

description: I eat here atleast once a week. The Vietnamese tofu sandwiches are amazing if you are vegetarian and the older guy that runs the counter is one of the nicest coolest guys ever. A++
author: Matthew C.

description: little vietnam failed the critical misha bun test of warm noodles. i think it just throws the whole dish and is a cardinal sin. 5 spice chicken was also not super great but was redeemed slightly by a good egg roll.
author: Misha T.

description:
I was devastated when Little Paris closed down - but alas we have Little V to reward my eager taste buds! Cheap, fast, DEE-licious! The sandwiches and soup bowls are out of this universe!  No offense to Lee's Sandwiches, but they suck compared to Little V's...  their ingredients are questionable - very "Hit or Miss" with me. 

Little V's is consistently " Mmm-mmm" Good...
author: Maya L.

description:
It is not a Vietnamese sandwich without pate. Some Vietnamese cafes will leave pate out bc not all their customers like pate. That's fine. So, I always order my sandwich "Pork and pate" or "chicken and pate". Twice I've ordered sandwiches from Little Vietnam Cafe, drive home with excitement bc I'm getting my pate fix....then as I bite into my sandwich, a big disappointment . The first time, there were no pate in my sandwich at all. Yesterday,  I gave them another chance.  I ordered a five spice chicken and pate. (i made sure I said pate) I took a bite, then two, then three, didn't taste any pate. I even opened my sandwich to look for it. I was so upset that they messed up on my sandwich again, that I wrote my 1 star review in my head as I ate my 1st half with disappointment. I decided to eat the second half bc I didn't want to waste food. As I got to the middle of the second half, I got a chunk of it in one bite. Really? Are you that busy that you couldn't spread the pate a whole 6-7 inches? 

I read Yelp reviews almost daily but I haven't written a review on yelp in over a year. This compelled me to write one. 2 stars bc you guys are a nice family owned cafe, but you messed up on my order twice. I'm sad bc you guys are the only decent Vietnamese sandwich shop in the Richmond. Please work on it.
author: Kim D.

description: BOOOO They raised the prices ealier this year...possibly after learning they would be in Best of SF Weekly. Many places in the TL that are better but it is as good as it gets in the Richmond. Stay away from the Pho. Bahn Mi and Noodle dishes are good but not great. Now that they have raised there prices, it is worth getting on the bike or in the car and heading to the TL if buying for more than one.
author: John D.

description:
From the moment I knew I was moving to San Francisco, I began dreaming of my first horrific food experience on Clement St. Thanks to Little Vietnam Cafe for making my dream come true!

There's no need to get into details, which are suitably mundane and visceral. Instead, I'll quote the doctor at the Emergency Room, who told a happily-morphined me as he looked at a scan of my insides: "It looks like something indigestible here" - he points to some curly spot in my nether regions - "but it should be fine. We see kids come in here all the time after they swallow coins."

Indeed, doctor. It is fine. And, also, thank you for the new nickname. I am now known as "Nickels."

Despite all that, I'm not giving up on Little Vietnam. Their rolls are good, but I'm going to hold off on the nickel sandwiches for a while longer.
author: Stephen S.

description:
For $4 a sandwich, it's not a bad price especially when the sandwich itself is very good. I love the fact that there's hardly any mayo, but a good balance of meat and veggies.

For the combo, it was a sandwich + vietnamese coffee for $6. Pretty good deal especially when you are low on cash. My only complaint would be that the coffee wasn't filled to the very top of the cup.

Other than that, I'd come back to try something else another time.
author: Kim L.

description:
Due to slow business at Vege House, they were forced to close down.  A new restaurant, Little Vietnam Cafe, has just opened in its place, featuring, you guessed it, Vietnamese cuisine.  

The cafe has just enough window seating if you want to eat in, so it's considered mainly a take-out spot.  But unlike Saigon, they feature more than Banh mi.  Menu items include appetizers, soups, rice plates, and a good number of vegetarian options.  The veggie Banh mi here, $3, was excellent.  (Check out the specials board behind the counter.)  In addition, they offer small dishes on styrofoam wrapped in cellophane on the counter.  I picked up the Chay, grilled tofu and peanut sauce--good overall; the peanut sauce is not the best I've tasted.

But the coolest thing for all my fellow veg heads:  They have a chef that specializes in vegetarian cooking, so anything that's on the menu can be made suitable for veggies!

The staff was extremely welcoming, a real delight to talk to.  I look forward to checking out more dishes.  I have a feeling that their location on 6th Ave may hurt business, as most of the traffic, foot and vehicular, is on Clement itself.  So, spread the word.  I'd hate to see these folks go belly up like Vege House before them.
author: Marsha Z.

description: MSG update:  I spoke to one of the owners on a subsequent visit and they use no MSG in the shrimp rolls, but all of the meats are in a marinade with a tiny amount of MSG.  Unless you're hypersensitive to MSG, it's an ok amount.
author: Bodhi D.

description: Really? 4 stars people? Seriously. The bread is undercooked. The rolls are not tasty. The ratio of dipping sauce to spring roll is way low. And the prices are higher than other places. I do give props to the owner...sweetest people. But unfortunately, asian people will NEVER rate asian food according to service-- it's all about product. And this product doesn't rate as high as other banh mi places. Sorry!
author: Lauren C.

description:
One of SF's best, if not the best, banh mi in a pleasant little storefront just off Clement Street.

Even if you show up at around 5pm, the bread is hot, crisp on the outside and light and fluffy on the inside even though the juices from the sandwich fillings soak into the bread.  This amazing bread also didn't cut the roof of my mouth like most versions of banh mi. 

I usually get the meatball [xiu mai] banh mi.  Soft, rich, porky goodness offset by the pickled veggies' and hot pepper's crisp, zesty tang.

A great find in the Inner Richmond!
author: Suo L.

description: The sandwich is good with the egg in it ( I think it was the special order)..But nothing out of the ordinary. The service was excellent! :)
author: Jazzlynn L.

description: I'm in love. Pork sammie w jalapeño - yum-o. Bread fresh and toasted, carrots and radish crisp and cut the right way, meat bbq'd perfectly. And all for 4 bucks. That's a no brainer 5 star rating for me!
author: Beverly C.

description: Possibly the most delicious byproduct of the French control of Vietnam is the banh mi sandwich. Why not with its juxtaposition of sweet, sour and spicy ingredients inside a warm fresh baguette roll. Which is why I also have overwhelming desires for this sandwich about once a week. Unfortunately, trying Little Vietnam Cafe's spicy pork banh mi did not satisfy my craving. The sandwich fell flat and was not spicy at all. The ratio of bread to filling was off and the flavor of the ingredients themselves didn't make my taste buds want to dance around in my mouth. Maybe an off day because the reviews for this place are solid but I'll be sticking to my tried and true places for my banh mis.
author: Jane K.

description: I stopped going there because I found a better place to buy Vietnamese sandwiches. I was okay with their sandwiches when it was between $3.75 to $4 but they jacked up the price to almost $5. If they would get better quality bread and toast them, I might go back there someday.  Y & Y is a much better choice.
author: Wine L.

description:
Just like half a dozen other times, I phoned in an order for sandwiches and headed to work.

Back at the office, I nearly broke my jaw on their french bread.  (If I threw that baguette across the room, it would have surely put a hole in the wall.)  I thought to myself..."OK, maybe they missed a bread delivery???"  I was in a forgiving mood knowing that I had my coffee & coconut agar to move on to for dessert.  I had taken a bite of it heading out of the store in the morning and it was delicious!  What a brilliant combination, right?  Only now did I realize there to be little white fuzz balls on top of the agar.  EWWWWWWWWW!  Never again- I am completely traumatized!

Now I know that little trek to the other side of the park is well worth it...Head over to Irving instead for Vietnamese sandwiches!
author: Judy K.

description:
I have to say, outside of Saigon Sandwiches, this is the best Banh Mi I have had thus far in the city.  

I kind of wish I tried the spring rolls here as well as their salad.  Both look good.  Maybe next time.  

For Vietnamese food,I guess it is a bit pricey, but it's still cheaper than most anything else in this city, so it's all relative.  I had a Banhi Mi in the Financial District that was the same price (if not more?) and 10x worse.  So relative, for sure.
author: daniel m.

description: It's about time I wrote a review on this place. Little Vietnam Cafe, how you saved me one time or another from my cold symptoms, cleared my sinuses with your Chicken Pho. The banh mi (pate) I had was equally delicious--the crunch I got out of the french roll and the pickled vegetables was incredible. Prices are affordable. Totally recommend this place if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Trisha M.

description:
Great for a quick and tasty lunch or early dinner. 
Vegetarian options: 
1) tofu summer rolls: perfect for a good & filling low-cal meal
2) deep fried veggie tofu imperial rolls: really good especially when you get it freshly made. You get 2 rolls with rice noodles. Sure it's oily but very tasty and fresh and that's what you get for deep fried!
3) seasoned fried tofu: very good-comes with some tasty ginger garlic sauce. If you have left overs, it's perfect to chop them up smaller and mix it in with veggies. 
4) Two types of veggie sandwiches with either tofu or veggie ham:  have only tried the tofu sandwich and it is mmmmm good!  I really like the bread they use and the ingredients are always fresh.  I'm looking forward to trying the veggie ham. 
The man who works there is super nice and kind. I also like to support local family owned businesses like this.
author: Lucky P.

description: Was at Green Apple Bookstore on a rainy Saturday and decided to grab a quick snack.  i searched Yelp for food close by and landed on Little Vietnam Cafe less than 200 feet away.  Ordered their acclaimed Pork Banh Mi that was rewarded SF Gate's Best of Bay.  Quick was 5 minutes from order to food in hand at the super economical total of $5.50 including tax.  While not as mind-blowingly great as Miss Saigon in the Tenderloin, it is very, very good and a fantastic snack place.  And the owner was incredibly friendly.  Eat, recharge, and back to more shopping on Clement.  I'll be back.
author: Stan S.

description: Really good Vietnamese sandwiches.  The veggie sandwich is excellent.  It was so good that my fiance couldn't believe there wasn't any meat in it!  I've had their chicken sandwich too and it was also quite tasty.  The person at the counter was very friendly and wanted to know if there was anything they could do to make the sandwiches better.  In my opinion, nothing more needs to be done since they're really good as they are now.
author: Karen W.

description:
warning! cash only! luckily theres the bank next door. Definately worth a trip to the atm. I love this place. first bit was magical. I eat everything with a smile and nod thinking.. yup! mMmmmMMHmmm IM HAPPY.. im very happy!

I got the beef sandwhich with egg and special sauce. i believe it was called the peters special!
author: M A.

description:
Damn good Banh mi.  I'm sure the elite banh mi freaks will compare this place to saigon sandwich, but it's a tough comparison.  Both are very good, but different styles.

The bread here was how i like my banh mi rolls.  a nice crunch, but not too much crunch that my mouth gets cut from rogue sharp bread pieces.  not too much mayo.  great pickled veggies.  use of cuke (a rarity in this city and a nice touch IMO) and the proteins for very flavorful.  it isn't as "dirty" as saigon sandwich. in fact the store is clean but so is the presentation of the product.  

This place would def bring me back for their sandwiches.  the bun cha looked fresh but not amazing.  most of the reviews say stick to the sandwiches and i think that this is a good call.
author: Andrew r.

description:
Came here over the weekend for some banh mis w/ the family.

The bread is just ok, a bit dry if you ask me and not enough crunch on the outside.

I got the fancy pork (cold, $3.50) and everybody else got the lemongrass pork (hot, $4).  I think the extra 50 cents is worth it cuz the lemongrass was more flavorful.  Sandwiches come w/ a lot of cilantro, so beware if you're not a fan.

I happened to be in the area and had a craving for a banh mi, but Saigon Sandwiches is still my top choice.
author: Naoko M.

description: Come here right now for lunch. Can't wait to try the sandwiches. Very tasty pho ga and bbq pork rolls. Inexpensive but not cheap.
author: John F.

description: Banh mi pork sandwich to die for! Very fresh every time, love it, And 4.5$, really?
author: Harold D.

description: I've been to this place on and off for about 5 years now. After being told "$4.50" for my lunch, they get docked 1 star. What the heck happened to the prices??? Their sandwiches and spring rolls used to be $3.00. It was well worth it for that price. Now it's just a mediocre value. With that said, the quality of the food is high. It's clean, fresh, simple, and super fast. If I lived in the area, I could easily eat here once a week.
author: Arick R.

description: Garlic Noodles are really good here, so are the Banh Mi, Lots of Vegetarian Choices and owner is super friendly, gave us a discount on our meal!!
author: Chris H.

description: These guys raised their prices $.50 on every item without putting the new price on their menu. I was scammed $.50 extra for my combination ham sandwich. I probably won't come here as much now.
author: TruthTelle R.

description:
I don't get it when people complain about $4 sandwiches.  I mean, this place is wonderful.  Their sandwiches (the tofu one is my favorite) are big, and delicious.  The bread is fresh, hot and crunchy, the vegetables are fresh and cool, it's just a flavor sensation in your mouth.  Plus, it's ready in exactly one minute, and it costs a measly four bucks.  There are a million places that serve crappy sandwiches for twice that.  I mean really, what's not to love?

Plus, the soup's great, the bun is lovely, service is friendly.  We go here all the time.

The only bummer about this place is that they're only open till 6 Pm or something, so it's more of a lunch/afternoon spot than dinner.
author: Melinda A.

description:
One of the best vietnamese sandwiches I've had yet.  The grilled pork was lean and flavorful.  I ask for extra cilantro and easy on the mayo (not big on mayo but I appreciate the moisture)  Really quite perfect, great balance of pickled veggies and meat.  The bun isn't anything special but it's not bad at all.  My gf gets the veggie(tofu) sandwich and loves it.

The guy who always seems to be there (probably owner or parter) is very friendly.  This place is great and soon I hope to try their Pho if I'm hungry enough.

If you sit down to eat there, you plop on a counter facing directly at the window.  It's great for eating and watching weird people walk by with pink bags.  Last time there was a truck parked out front with two mexican dudes eating their lunches and we kept accidentally making eye contact with them.

The previous time a baby was getting her diaper changed in the trunk of the car parked out front and  the shit was EVERYWHERE.  I thought she was wearing brown shoes.
author: Boiled H.

description:
The best Vietnamese Sandwiches I've had in the Bay Area and I'm Vietnamese.  My mom doesn't even make it this well.

I'm from San Jose and I'd rate the ever famous Lee Sandwiches or Huong Lan a 3 on a solid day.  However, Little Vietnam Cafe,  which I've visited on several occasions, shows promise and consistency in their food.  Their ingredients are fresh and the customer service is always sincere.  Their chicken isn't premade grilled on the spot in the back.  

I came during the lunch rush hour which was packed but got my food as fast as Mcdonalds.


Good price, good quality, good quantity.
author: Johnson N.

description: It just started to get chilly here in San Fran so I needed some Pho to keep me warm and cozy. We yelped a couple of places and for some reason they were closed on this Tuesday evening, and I'm glad they were or I wouldn't have ever discovered this little gem. Sure with their positive reviews I knew it wouldn't suck but I'm glad they lived up to the hype. I satisfied my Pho craving with their Vegetarian Pho...delicious - fresh veggies, great broth...yummy. We also ordered their Crispy Vegetarian Rolls (another delish dish) and their Garlic Noodles (OMGosh - not very gluten friendly, but for those days you need some comfort food...this will do it.) The staff was friendly and very attentive. They only have 1 2-top table inside with 5-6 counter seats and 3 2-top seats outside, so if you want to eat here, get here before 6 (when they close) and maybe don't go at your typical lunch hour! I'm craving them already!
author: Kristy H.

description:
Just found this place out recently. Really good sandwiches and rolls in the city outside TL. I've been brought up on these since I was a wiii pup, so I've been around the block when it comes to well made, quality Vietnamese sandwiches and the rest of the crap, and this place safely isn't the latter.

I like that it's family-owned (which is a nice bonus) as it gives me an extra good feeling that i know I'm giving my business to someone that's from the city and is helping giving the neighborhood its character compared to a corporate business around the corner.
author: M T.

description:
Great Vietnamese sandwich.  Perhaps best in SF area!

Toasty.  Tasty.  Meaty!  Full of veggies!  All in one sandwich!  

Order the Combination Special!
author: Alan T.

description:
Too bad the seating is so limited here.  The pre-prepared take out food I bought was mighty mighty good.  I can only imagine how great the fresh stuff must be. 

Cheap, fast and good ... double park and run in for some rolls and other goodies.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I love this place!  Last time I was there I chatted with the owner and I asked him when he was going to open up a shop in the Mission.  He told me they were working on it!  If anyone hears about the progress on this, please let me know!

I've had sandwiches from them about 3 times now and they've been consistently good.  I usually get the Banh Mi Thit Nuong - BBQ pork sandwich - with extra jalapenos!  I've also had vietnamese coffee, some of their rolls, and other starters - can't say that I have a single complaint.  Except for the fact that they're lagging on opening their Mission store!
author: Nicole N.

description:
This place gets four stars because it's right by my house, it's good, and it's right by my house! I really don't know what you negative people are talking about. It may not be as good as the ones in the Loin but I'll take my Vietnamese sandwiches without the army of crackheads and 20 minute drive (don't make me talk about the bus ride).

The bread has NEVER been stale whenever I've visited and although it's a bit pricey for a Viet sandwiches, it's still cheaper than a lot of places for lunch. I'm down with a fresh spring roll (with so many options! Shrimp! Pork! Tofu!) for $3 and yum that sauce is good.

It's a small hole in the wall and the people are always friendly.

Quit whining and eat your goddamn pork!
author: Salina Z.

description:
Excellent sandwiches with speedy service. The pork, chicken, and tofu sandwiches have all been delicious every time with excellent veggies and crusty bread. 

 Also, who doesn't love a punch card for a free sandwich after you buy 10?
author: Michael H.

description:
This place is so great! From the outside, it looks really unassuming, but once you step inside you get the most delicious, affordable, and authentic Vietnamese food in a clean setting.

There is no sitting room.
Cash only.

But well worth it. Call ahead and by the time you get to Clement and find parking, your food will be ready for you to pick up. 

I really like number 28 which is the rice, grilled pork, with the egg/meat loaf cake. Their sandwiches are delicious. 3.50 gets you a sandwich filled with fresh grilled meat, and plenty of carrots and daikon. The spring rolls are great as well. You can get full for under 5 bucks here.

Most importantly, this place is authentic. I grew up eating Vietnamese food, and this place is comparable to the food I ate in Westminster.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Great Viet Sandwiches

Flavorful
Good bread
Lots of Veggies
Slightly on the expensive side
Friendly service

This place is small, counter space along the window for maybe 3-4.  That is it.

A place I would go again
author: Po L.

description:
This is the best place in the city to eat lunch!

$5: Vietnamese Sandwich and a canned drink. 

How can you beat this. It should be billed as a recession special. 
I have had a Vietnamese Sandwich at Cafe Dolci on Market that everyone seems to be real high on.  The only thing I can say is that those same people must also be big fans of KFC and Taco Bell. 

Cafe Dolci is a turd compared to LVC, an absolute shit stain. I waited 20min at Dolci for a dry, stale shit burger of a 'Nam Sandwich. 

At LVC, before I could even plop my ass in a seat at the bar my hot, moist, spicy sandwich was splayed out in front of me on a cloud soft french roll. 

Get it Spicy with Jalapeno's and you will very happy. When you leave only $5 lighter in the pocket you will sign on to yelp and drop 'em a bomb ass review. Now, I am going to slam Cafe Dolci.
author: Jackson D.

description:
One of my favorite food items are fresh spring rolls. One of these days I will learn how to make it.
Anyway you can get two huge rolls for 2.5 
I love Clement Street. 

Marcus
author: Marcus R.

description: This is my favorite place to grab a quick lunch during work, or after. I always get a tofu veggie sandwich "spicy" and a coke. it's 5 freaking dollars!!!!! Can't beat that....and I reccomend eating there because sometimes they forget the peppers and it's fresher that way and warm. yummmaaaay!!!! Also, in and out in like 15 minutes flat...no joke
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Really terrific food, but the sandwiches are a little pricier than the Tenderloin/Larkin st variety.  But that's a small complaint, all the other dishes are good for the most part, tho some of the fried things are a little past their prime by mid-afternoon.  The usual caution: spicy means a lot of jalapenoes, and if you touch your eyes, you'll need a guide dog.

Service is top notch, the folks here are super friendly and greet everyone.
author: Gene T.

description: I work about 6 blocks away and calling ahead to place my banh mi order is key due to the lunch rush.  They have prepackaged meals ready to be picked up at the counter and also food they make in the back kitchen.  I've never bought any of their desserts in the fridge but they look good.  My usual is the chicken or the tofu banh mi which are both very good.  But I recently got the tofu and it was soggy and lacked a lot of flavor.  I don't know if this was fluke but I will go back and give them a try again.  Oh, and I order them extra spicy!
author: Rosalind S.

description: There is not a better place to go for a bahn mi sandwich in the Inner Richmond.  Extra meat and jalapeno for $5, pick up a bottle of Sauvignon Blanc from Smart & Final and you have a wonderful, smokey, sweet, herby, spicy sandwich on the best pistolette of french bread and buzz potential!  You get an endorphine rush from the jalapenos and the spicey smoked pork or beef that mixes nicely with the wine.  Of course, the flavors compliment each other well.  This place, on some days, has been the highlight of my day.  Simple, inexpensive, quick and friendly.  I told them they should stay open later, but everybody has their reasons and I wouldn't change a thing.  Cheers!
author: Sean M.

description:
Another vote for Little Vietnam. I have been craving those tasty vietnamese sandwiches ever since Little Paris closed and haven't found a spot on Clement that served them until now. So tasty and fresh, personally, I like a bit more mayo and sriacha, but thats me. I go back and forth between the bbq pork and the bbq beef, both are great. $5 gets you the combo of a sandwich and a (small) cup of vietnamese coffee. 

I've missed you paper wrapped and rubber banded delicious sandwiches! So glad to have this spot in the 'hood.
author: Brenda K.

description:
Tried a couple of their Large Pho to go.  The guy at the counter was polite, even though it was just about their closing time.  We put the noodles, spouts, broth together at home.  They do package it nicely. But, it wasn't great pho.  The broth left much to be desired, and the sprouts and mint stuff was kind of not-fresh smelling.  Ended up eating only half of what I brought home.  Kind of a big disappointment, as pho can really make me happy.

This place might just be better for their sandwiches, so will give them another try one day.  I think 3 stars at the best for now.
author: Joe T. C.

description:
High quality BBQ chicken sandwich. The BBQ beef is really good also. The meat was cooked with good sauce and not overly fatty. A lot of Vietnamese sandwich places use poor quality meats and don't grill the meat properly either. The use some other cheaper process to cook the meat, other than Vietnamese-style grilling. The result is very different. The meats here are actually very good - as in you could eat it with rice and it would be good. The rest of the ingredients were tasty and I was a fan of the bread. I'm curious about their Pho and other soups so I'll be back.

This place is tiny though so I'm not sure about actually sitting here..
author: Sven S.

description:
Little V holds a special place in my heart. 

Many moons ago, my grandparents opened up the first dim sum/Chinese bakery in the Richmond called Dor Lim (my grandad named it after grandma). They were famous for their goods (all made by hand) especially their moon cakes. They were even written up the Chron in the 70s because they did everything by hand and refused to buy into an automated process. I was born on the day of the Harvest Moon festival and my grandad used to make special mini moon cakes for me. I haven't eaten one since he passed away a few years ago.

I remember spending much of my youth there and having meals in the kitchen in the back after the shop had closed for the day. As my shrink will tell you. this is where my obsession with food began. 

Little V is great. I love the people who own and operate the place. I think they make some of the best spring rolls in the City. The lemongrass tofu got me through my kitchen remodel. 

Sometimes, I like to walk by just to reminisce.
author: Monica L.

description:
Yum! Came here for lunch last week with a friend and we both got the vermicelli bowls with imperial rolls. Huge amount of food for $6.50 each, we managed to eat all of it but man, it could haev been 2 meals. I've had their sandwiches too, very yummy, I've had the chicken and the vegetarian ones.
There are a few tables outside and a few counter seats inside, but I'd say this place is better for take out. Or just eat outside and people watch!
author: Rachel M.

description: This places makes a delicious sandwich, but I came right before closing and the bread was so hard it made my jaw hurt the next day. The old man working there is really sweet though so I'll probably go back at a more reasonable hour.
author: k h.

description:
i came here for a sandwich before heading to napa.  the sandwiches were very good.  i got the chicken and the pieces of chicken were big, not chopped up like other places i've been to.
i also ordered the che ba mau (3 colored drink) and that was very good!  they were kind enough to put in a separate bag so if it leaked, it won't get on the sandwiches.  there's a small seating area for those who eat-in.  
if i lived in sf again, i'd definitely come back!
author: Serena L.

description:
Banh mi! So after hearing over and over about these Vietnamese sandwiches, tooted as the best bang for your buck in terms of cheap eats ($4 here), I recently found myself biting into my first. I obviously have no real reference point for other Banh mi in the city but I do like to think that I have quite the repertoire for tasty food references and this place definitely has made the cut. So to all you Banh mi connoisseurs, you're going to have to bare with this "rookie" assessment til I get to the legendary Saigon sandwich... 

I have to go and recommend the lemongrass roasted pork sandwich. The bread, tightly holding together the pork and veggies, was a good balance of crunch on the outside with a soft fluffy texture right before you hit the inner fixings of the Banh mi. The meat came in a good portion with a lasting flame roasted flavor that instantly gave me flashbacks to many a happy, meat-filled barbeque. And with a big ole portion of cilantro, jalapeños, cucumber, and carrots, I found a good bit of crunch to contrast the tenderness of the meat. And well I just happen to be a big fan of cilantro and anything with a high spice level! But the one thing that did put me off was the sauce. It definitely didn't stop me from eating the sandwich but not being a fan of mayo I would have definitely enjoyed a more easy application. So beware mayo-phobes, but otherwise definitely recommended! If not for the food then just for the friendly neighborhood chat with the unusually nice staff!

As for the rest of the menu, it doesn't seem too extensive but you'll probably find what you need. The spring rolls were big and filling, with no great surprise but overall a quality I'd come back to. And I can't say much for the pho but I'm pretty biased living around the corner from the tried and true inner richmond staple, pho clement. But if their sandwiches are any reflection of the rest of their menu ... I'll definitely be back soon for some new ventures.
author: Dominique C.

description: best Bahn mi i've had in the richmond area yet.  About a buck more than the other places nearby, but worth it (still crazy cheap).  Got the tofu, and the only thing i might have wanted more was for it to be a bit spicier, but really that's just nitpicking.  Definitely coming back, the other items on the menu all looked good as well.  I'm just happy I finally found a sandwich place in the area this good.
author: Phil J.

description: Yummy neighborhood Vietnamese spot... good bun, good bahn mi, good prices.  I'd recommend this for anyone in the area that wants their Vietnamese food fix and doesn't want to haul themselves all the way out to Little Saigon.  The owner is nice, quick, and efficient.
author: Erin B.

description:
This place is a total find, in my opinion.  I often find myself on Clement St.-- at Green Apple or on my way to the beach or the Legion of Honor-- and need a bite.  Sometimes you want something quick, easy and delicious and this is the perfect place.

I love their Vietnamese sandwiches and the tofu ones are my favorite.  Great soft French roll, chewy, yummy fried tofu strips, shredded pickled carrot and daikon, jalapenos and a little mayo.  They're great and they're $3 or so.  They also have great fresh spring rolls, again I usually get the tofu ones.  I'm not a vegetarian, but I like the fried tofu texture and don't always trust the meat at little inexpensive places.  They have other pre-made snacks for sale that I still have to try.

If you're in the neighborhood, I strongly recommend you stop by for a sandwich.
author: Ariel D.

description:
I've been here weekly the past month. Besides finding convenience in this place as I live 6 blocks away, the food is cheap and delish! I strolled to this joint with my pal Angela and I think the only words which exited from our mouths from when we walked into the door until we left was from our food orders. We had the sandwiches and rolls shoved continuously in our mouths and finished our meal in less than 5 minutes. 

Definitely a 10 on a scale for food comas.

This place is perfect for the post-late night, Sunday hangover feeding session. I think I've slept walked to this place just to get a fix on the savory sandwiches which I drown in the yummy mystery sauce (i think it's fish sauce and soy sauce combined) which they lay on the counters.

When the season changes I look forward to trying their noodle soups. They seem to have a large diversity of grub for such a small hole in the wall.
author: Jonny M.

description: I have never had anything else besides the Peter Special with Pork because it is outrageous!  I keep meaning to try one of their noodle bowls but am always drawn in by their very affordable and delicious sandwiches.  These people are family owned and very friendly.  Check them out!
author: Adam L.

description: I give 4 stars for their sandwich. My favorite is the spicy tofu sandwich. They also have great soup though I dont like their tomato crab noodle soup. Place is super duper tiny and bathroom is terrible. The old gentleman who receive orders is super nice and super friendly so he make up for the dissapointment of tiny place and terrible bathroom.
author: GreasynCrunchy H.

description:
family run. get the bahn mi with an egg and get it spicy. the chicken is better than the pork. 

its cheap!
author: Sam S.

description:
Eh.  It's one of the better ones in the Richmond but it's really not that good.  I can't believe people think it should get better than mediocre ratings.  

The bread was kinda hard, not fresh.  Had the dac biet.  Decent enough flavor, maybe a little too much cilantro and I love cilantro.  Wasn't really stuffed with meat but wasn't horribly skimpy either.  

And it's price at near $4, way too much for this.  Prices should be closer to $3.  That doesn't seem like a much but a lot of places with better sandwiches charge $2.50. 

I was hoping for a selection of rolls or noodles pre packed.  Nope.
author: Bruce B.

description: there's nothing bad about this bahn mi sandwich, the flavors weren't really popping though, and the combo didn't have any pat'e just liverwurst and I forget what else but not the greatest bahn mi
author: Jeremy S.

description: $4.50/sandwich is a tad high, given there's cheaper competition in the area.  The strong point to Little Vietnam Cafe is the baguettes they use.  They're made properly, with a super thin crust that shatters with each bite and a fluffy, airy interior that cushions your teeth right before you get to the veggies and meat .  To prevent a mess if you're eating in your car, keep the sandwich in the bag while you eat to catch the crumbs.
author: Sam W.

description: I had their regular pork bun mee, it was ok.  I would rather buys Lee's Sandwiches instead.  The sandwich was lacking in flavor.  But I will go back to try the pho and rice dishes.
author: Ammala B.

description: I've eaten here a few times with my other half who loves the BBQ chicken sandwich they service, however it was just "ok" for me. The first time I had it the bread was either too toasted or too stale which hurt my teeth to eat, so I had to return it. Fortunately the guy making the sandwiches was happy to make me another one which was much better. So overall, if you have the craving for a decent tasting Vietnamese sandwich I would recommend coming here, though the seating is VERY limited OR if you have a car and don't mind driving out to the San Jose area try one of their Vietnamese sandwich spots.
author: Petra S.

description:
Viet-tastic!

This is my new favorite Vietnamese place in San Francisco.  The rice noodles with imperial rolls and grilled pork (Bun Cha Gio Thit Nuong) and Vietnamese Sandwiches are so trill.  Highly recommended.  There is only limited seating (4 or 5 seats) along the windows though.  Also it is cash only.
author: Matthew H.

description: This place is a hole is the wall but has the best vietnamese food in the city that I've had. Since it is the size of a shoebox so I recommend takeout. Really great pho, fried spring rolls, vietnamese sandwiches but what I really recommend is the fresh vietnamese spring rolls. Everything here is ridiculously cheap as well. Menu items are between $5-$7. It's only open until 6pm so recommend going early if you want to get dinner there.
author: Ally L.

description:
I like this place.

The rice plates are pretty good but I go  for the combination meat cold sandwhich.  For $3.50, you can't beat that with a stick.  The french baguettes are pretty good.  This is like a vietnamese po-boy.

Not for those afraid of pate though.

Tiny hole in the wall off clement definitely worth checking out in a neighborhood with a myriad of choices.
author: Michael L.

description:
After seeing a few people with what appeared to be really small $7 bowls of pho I began to fear that my vermicelli noodle bowl would leave me hungry, but was pleasantly surprised to find out that not only was it really tasty, but sizable as well.  For $6.25 or so I had a vermicelli salad bowl with lemongrass pork that was just as good as Slanted Door's* with more food for less money.

*I am fully aware that Slanted Door is not a good benchmark for Vietnamese food, but I haven't tried a Vermicelli bowl from anywhere else.
author: Krystle S.

description: I have been coming here for awhile. My quick fix for banh mi cravings. I always get the pork sandwich and the spicier the better. The owner is super nice and friendly every time I go there.
author: Jen F.

description: everything here is delicious, fresh and tastes like I'm eating something my friend's mom made.  they're really creative with their dishes too!
author: June C.

description: A fellow foodie friend took me here for lunch. There are a ton of Vietnamese sandwich shops in the Richmond, so its not always easy finding a legit shop. Little Vietnam Cafe has super cheap and delicious Vietnamese sammies, just be warned it's cash only! I had the lemongrass pork sandwich, crispy tofu and strawberry lemonade. Delish!
author: Dennie B.

description: Bought two PORK combo sandwiches. I found them to be pretty boring and the bread tasted pretty stale. I think I can find a better vietnamese sandwich place on clement st with better meat and softer bread.
author: Mika K.

description:
Ah, I found the one I had just mentioned in my review of Saigon Sandwich Shop on Larking. This one is not so manic because it's not downtown and they also have Pho and a few other dishes.  See my review on Saigon Sandwich Shop for my opinion of the bread difference. But, if you're in this neighborhood it's great. The owner who is almost always there is very nice.

And, just around the corner 2nd door over is a Dim Sum joint where you can eat a decent little lunch for like $5.50 including a bottle of soda or water.

There's seating for I would say 14-16. the place as zero atmosphere but you will see all the Chinese people there ordering to go. It's on Clement Street just off 6th avenue. Not the place pon the corner, the one next to it.
author: Lee S.

description: Came here with my friend as we were trying to escape the cold and rain. This place is legit - the pho is delicious, the prices just about right, and the owners very sweet. I've been spoiled in SoCal when it comes to Vietnamese food and this place reminds me of home. I wish I lived in the Richmond just so I can come here more often. When I do come back, I'll have to try the rice vermicelli and the banh mi.
author: Devy E.

description: Great sandwiches and rolls and vermicelli bowls, very inexpensive, The family that owns and runs the place are extremely nice and friendly. Definitely one of the best little spots in the Inner Richmond
author: Doctor S.

description:
If you don't have time or want to head down to the TL for a vietnam sandwich Little Vietnam Cafe  is do-able.  I've tried the Fancy Pork sandwich, and my advice is to not get the sandwiches with the carrot/daikon relish, it makes the sandwich soggy. and who wants a soggy sandwich?.  I've had the prepacked shrimp rolls "Goi Guon Tom" and find it to be fresh but not that tasty.  But they are more generous than some places with the quantity of the shrimp, vermicelli noodles, and greens wrapped in it. 

It's a good place to try if you down on clement and want  to grab a vietnamese sandwich.  Again it's do-able.
author: J. C.

description:
I am a fan of the Bahn Mi (Vietnamese sandwich) and this relatively new place on Clement is probably the winner for me. There are others on Clement, but I really like the convenience and the speed of Little Vietnam - 5 min. at the most. It's cheap, and if you need maybe just a bit more sustenance, pick up some spring rolls. All together, maybe about 6 bucks and some change.

The Pho' is also great along with their rice plates and vermicelli bowls. They also make their own fish sauce, and if you're a fan, which you should be if you're into Vietnamese food, then this is a plus.

And they're also veggie friendly...for those who condone the killing of plant life (which I'm against).
author: Ted P.

description:
I am stuck between 3 and 4 stars, I'll round up. The guy is really nice. One time he could tell I was hella hungry and gave me some extra chicken spring rolls on the house. I am not Vietnamese sandwich expert, but regardless of what they are supposed to be, the sandwiches here are perfect for a light meal.

Oh, and it took me a while to try this place because everytime I passed by I get freaked out by that flight attendant cardboard cutout in the travel agency (which the guy also owns) next to Little Vietnam. And yeah, talk travel to the guy, he will give you some great pointers. Now that I think about it, this place definitely deserves the 4 stars.
author: Lee M.

description:
I've been looking for a Vietnamese sandwich place to replace Little Paris (it went away years ago) and I think I've found it. I tried the chicken sandwich and my partner in crime had the pork combo. We split a little plate of rice boodles and Imperial rolls. It was really good! Definitely coming back again.

This place is tiny. There are 6 folding chairs inside along the window where there is a slim marble counter acting as a table. The day I was there there were 3 patio tables outside as well. It ain't got ambiance. Take it to go, I say. Which is what we did. The old guy behind the counter was really nice. When I asked what fancy pork was, he gave me a slice to taste! That was shocking to me because Chinese peeps don't normally don't give samples. I'm just sayin'.

Despite the look of the place and all the dry erase menu boards, they do have a decent menu for something this size.

***4.5.08  I've also tried the pate banh mi and the chicken rice noodle soup. I didn't love the type of pate they used. The noodle soup on the other hand was very good. Loved the garlicy broth!
author: cyndi L.

description:
Unlike servers and cashiers at the majority of cheap, fast Asian restaurants, whether in NYC, LA, or SF, I found the staff at Little Vietnam Cafe to be polite and even sweet. So I really must disagree with the previous comment made about the person working the counter. Personally, at places like this and at fast food joints, I don't have to be instructed to pay for my food after I order it. I just do. Maybe the cashier was just  being nice, and wondering why the customer wasn't paying up front, and instead of being rude to a valuable customer, he/she let the customer pay on his/her own time. 

In addition to great service, or perhaps more importantly, food here is consistently delicious and I will definitely be going back on my frequent returns to the lovely city.
author: Kris K.

description:
I love getting Pho on rainy days, which is an unfortunate way to go when entering the parking gauntlet that is the Inner Clement area.

There seems to be a ratio of inevitability that the more you have to do the parking tango in the rain, all the while having to circle further from you real goal - the greater the desire grows (and sometimes the expectations).

And Whoa is the experience if expectations are sorely missed.  Thus was mine.

This was the 1st time me getting the Pho at this place - and my last.
But I'll be back for foods other than the Pho.   But the lesson learned is to: "Go here for the sandwiches only".

This isn't the cleanest place, or the biggest, or the cleanest, and I would give it more stars were it not for the recent Pho meltdown.  But I do like the older folks behind the counter. 

BUT WAIT!!!! I've been occasionally known to make a mistake (none yet in my Yelp reviews) and I would suggest the Bun Rieu.  Yep - you heard it here.  Break out of the sandwich shell and try their Bun Rieu.
You like Bun Rieu - you know what is - what's your favorite place in SF to get it?  Try this place's.
author: RiCH K.

description: Every good review for this place is most likely by an employee.  I went once and the pork sandwich was terrible.  I gave it another chance because the new Bunn Mi Cafe on Clement was busy. It was an awful decision.  The chicken sandwich is bland, slimy, with the all nasty carrot and daikon.  My roommate took a bite and spit it out.  Also, if you go here expect to wait for a small, poorly assembled sandwich.  I signed up for Yelp for the sole purpose of warning people about this place.  Go to the new Bunn Mi cafe on Clement and 6th instead.
author: a h.

description: Great food! I mean, okay, maybe I shouldn't be one to talk because I literally only ordered two of the same dish (the lemongrass pork vermicelli) but it was delicious. Not the best I've ever had (I've had a lot), but definitely worth recommending. The prices are right, and the guy behind the counter is so friendly it makes me want to go back every day.
