author: Michelle G.

description:
I've been hunting for good Vietnamese eats in my hood other than Golden Deer and its orgasmic BBQ pork.

Little Vietnam fits the bill perfectly. It's mainly a take out, which brings me back to my days in San Jose eating at Lee Sandwiches (not the crappy businessmen eatery place u see in SF downtown, but the real Vietnamese grub chain in South/East Bay). 

I walked in to find all sorts of veggie and meat-packed rolls all ready to go. Even some fresh angel hair noodles with shredded pork combos were just chillin there, waiting to be eaten. 

They make HUGE Vietnamese sandwiches for $3. Great deal, considering we're still in San Francisco. One of the choices is Fancy Pork.. Oooooh! Faaaancy!   must try that next time.

I had the rice plate with the lemon grass pork. Boy was it good...!!
Spent the whole afternoon burping. 

Their menu is straight to the point, comfort Vietnamese food that doesn't involve Pho (for once, thank u Buddha!). They even have yummy authentic desserts all ready to go. I was pleasantly surprised at this place. 

Ooh! The girl helping out there is quite the friendly gal. 


A 2nd visit on its way.....
author: Tomas V.

description:
A sandwich for $3 is a total steal, especially when it is damn good.   I don't know what they do to their tofu, but the texture and spices are perfect with the crunchy shredded carrots, cilantro, jalepeno and spiced mayo. Great friendly service also.   I'm withholding the final star because the tofu sandwich used to be EVEN yummier when they did not add big chunks of raw onion in it.  I'm not sure why they started doing that, because as far as I saw in Vietnam, that ain't how it's done.

Besides the sandwiches, another superstar on the menu is the bun rieu - tomato crab noodle soup. if you've never had it, TRY IT!!!  the flavor combination may sound strange to those with primarily western palates, but trust me, it works.
author: Leona K.

description:
This place is great great great!!! 
 When Little Paris shut down I was bummed.
 But alas, now there is Little Vietnam Cafe!!
I love everything I have tried here, it is CHEAP, and you can sit outside at a little table and watch the hussle and bussle of the neighborhood or inside at the counter facing the street.  I brought a book with me the other day and put it down because watching people was waaay more entertaining.

This little hole in the wall is the bomb.

Totally need to eat lunch here if you live in the hood.
author: erin f.

description:
when you see SFPD at a place you know it's good. had a 5 spice grilled chicken vietnamese sandwich. although you pay a $1 than the usual places, it was DELISH. I also noticed that have a TON of tofu and chicken and pork dishes and different flavored springrolls for sale, more than I've ever seen.

the sandwich had marinated CRUNCHY sweet carrots, they got my no cilantro no jalapeno order perfectd (which doesn't always happen in other places), the amount of mayo and other stuff in the sandwich was perfect and the CHICKEN WAS FABULOUS.
author: Win H.

description: Fresh, affordable, and extremely friendly. Vegetarian banh mi is very good.
author: Joshua V.

description: pate and veggies in my sandwich is all i need. even though i didnt understand a word the owner was saying, transaction was smooth and easy. pretty $$ though.
author: kim w.

description:
the man was sooo sweet! i told him i liked my soup spicy, so he brought over to me all these hot pickled jalapeno peppers, sriracha, and extra hot sauce from the tables outside for me. he was like the viet daddy i never had!

the broth was very flavorful, too! good, cheap eats! cute, clean place with warm and friendly service! =)
author: gookgette c.

description:
th owner and people are very friendly. they know me and my co workers who go there during lunch. they have a variety of food and fresh too. 

3 stars that made me go there less often, i usually  special order my food. bbq chicken salad. almost $8??? hmmm...

i just wish that this place would price 'my' salad cheaper.
author: Elly G.

description: Best Vietnames sandwiches in the area, hands down. Delicious, great price, sweet owners, and speedy service. Love their spicy tofu sandwich. This is a great local business to support!
author: Julie S.

description:
average... not too bad but not very good either...

this place has the highest stars among all vietnamese sandwich places in inner richmond and i was very excited to try their sandwiches... but they are just ok... they are expensive side ($1-1.5 more) compare with other vietnamese sandwich places.  the service was nice but i will rather go other places.
author: waguri m.

description:
Small. That's what i noticed the first time I walked into this place.  But you know, they made it work.

Very good sandwiches, especially the veggie-tofu sandwich; makes me smile everytime I here "your sandwich is ready".

affordable, friendly, small. 4 stars well earned.
author: Celso C.

description: This place is going down hill.  We use to come here every Saturday for sandwiches but their quality has really gone down. The chicken sandwiches are now bland and dry. They do not take directions well. Every time we have asked for additional veggies and no mayo, we either get no veggies or tons of mayo. Out of the 12 orders we have made with them, I would say they got 4 done right.  When I called to complain that they had put mayo in my sandwich yet again (I am allergic), they claimed they did not, proceeded to argue with me and then asked for evidence. What ever happened to customer service!  2 stars for the decline in the taste and quality of food. 1 star for service. Skip this place and go down the street for a better alternative.
author: J. K.

description: mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm their knife sharp day old french bread is a tad easier on the gums than saigon sandwhich. they do have a nice pho as well. all good here. tasty stuff.
author: aidan m.

description: I come here once a week for lemongrass pork banh mi.  In fact, I prefer Little Vietnam's sandwiches over the ones I've had from San Jose, which is saying a lot.  They go light on the mayo, heavy on the meat - they'll even hook you up with a bag of pickled carrots if you want extra.
author: Victoria G.

description:
My new favorite spot. They have ample vegetarian options, soup, sandwiches, and most importantly: DESSERTS!!!! They also make some of their own drinks: I had a green drink which was like a sweeter wheat grass and is supposed to be very cleansing for the digestive track. The dessert I had was a sweet rice with black eye'd peas and a warm coconut milk to dress on top. Oh lordy, this was tasty. 

Their flavors are simple, seasoned, fresh, and satisfying! I don't really live in the neighborhood, or else I would frequent this place all the time.
author: C. G.

description: banh mi is really good, vermicelli bowls were just aight...needs more veggies and eggroll wrapper is rice paper not the egg paper which i prefer.  The man behind the counter is extremely nice.  We will be back for banh mi!
author: LT B.

description:
Went to Little Vietnam Cafe today since it had good reviews on yelp. I love pho, but this was my first experience with Vietnamese sandwiches. I ordered the pork lemongrass binh mi since a few people had mentioned it in their review. It was absolutely delicious! The flavors were much livelier than what i expected. For only $4, you cant beat this for a quick, cheap meal on Clement.

Note: Cash only. But that's to be expected from a place with such great prices.
author: N B.

description:
I wasn't that impressed.  I got both the veggie and the meatball sandwiches.  They lacked flavor.  And too much mayo.  American mayo, not the spiced kind.  No pungency.  No aroma.  No crunch.  Too few veggies, that weren't even pickled.   I expect a lot more flavor for a $3.50 Banh mi.   Could have been fixed by cutting the mayo with a lot more fresh veg. and fish/chili sauce.
Yes, the fresh spring rolls are large, but they are also tasteless, lacking in the fresh aromatic veggies and spices that bring Vietnamese food to life.
The fried ones were better, with a better dipping sauce as well.

I'll try them again and see if they will make it to order for me and see how they do then.
author: Lavinia F.

description: Today Tony and I came by for a lite lunch, either a banh mi or some noodle soup. So we got one of each, a grilled pork banh mi and a bun rieu (tomato crab meat soup). I love bun rieu, and it's hard to find a good full-flavored bun rieu that doesn't require the addition of more fish sauce to get more flavor. Their bun rieu rocks! It tasted home made, the egg/crab meat/shrimp was tasty, and the fried tofu were thin slices, so it absorbed the full flavors of the soup.  I can't believe I waited this long to try their bun rieu, but will definitely be back for some more good ole comfort food.
author: Annie Y.

description: A great find (thanks SFgate and yelp). The sandwiches are second only to Saigon Sandwich (had the tofu and a meatball), and we've tried them from all over - I'm so happy to find excellent sandwiches closer to home. Lots of fillings. Shared a pork "vermicelli bowl" bun, which was also very good although possibly a bit reheated or something (the pork). Service was really friendly - the dude kept getting us everything and making sure we were happy - despite we were the jerks who walked in right before they were closing. We'll definitely be back (at a better time).
author: Jen D.

description: Can't speak for the sandwiches, but I should have known better than to order bun Bo hue from this joint.  Yuck!  I don't know if it was the end of the day or what, but the bun noodles were soggy as eff. They were in two in pieces and mushy.  I wanted the bun rieu, but they were out.  Guessing I would have gotten the same noodles though.  My bf lucked out as the noodles for the pho ga were fine.  Not sure how sanitary this place is, my guess is not very.  The dude took my cash, then went into the kitchen, where I could see him put our veggies in pouches.  Didn't see him stop anywhere to was his hands tho.  Will try a sandwich next time.
author: Nancy V.

description:
i finally went here after reading about this place in the chronicle.
this place is great!  we ordered:

bun cha gio (rice noodles with egg rolls)
pho ga (chicken pho)

portions are plentiful, and our bill came out to $15 total.  the rice noodles dish was really delicious: noodles, fresh veggies, bbq pork and egg rolls.  what is not to like?  the pho ga was definitely not the best i've  had in the city (turtle tower is better), but good nonetheless.  i can't wait to go again to try their banh mi (sandwiches).  i'd recommend taking the food to-go since parking can be a pain, and the restaurant only has a small bar and a few tables outside for seating.
author: Brian S.

description: I've never had a sandwich here, but they have the most legit bun rieu in the city. Their bun rieu is nice and hearty with big chunks of tomatoes, fish cake, tofu, and shredded crab, swimming in a flavorful sour broth with vermicelli noodles. Greens and sprouts arrive on a styrofoam plate and the only seating is counter seating. Definitely not a place you go for ambiance, but somewhere you go for nothing more than the food itself.
author: Victoria N.

description: I love sandwiches and this is one of the best damn sandwiches I've had in a long time. Very friendly service as well.
author: Sabrina L.

description:
"5/5 SERVICE: attentive hostess was full of great recommendations.  food came out fast
3/5 AMBIANCE: definitely a take-out/quick bite joint.  very clean.
5/5 FOOD:  like vietnamese home cooking!
5/5 VALUE:  where can you get a meal for under $5 anymore? 

Little Vietnam is the quick fix to my noodle cravings.  I cannot get enough of their Bun Bo Hue (spicy beef noodle soup).  The broth is flavorful, spicy, and the meat is tender - the fattiness just falls apart in your mouth.  Most places the pork is chewy and you end up pushing it under your noodles.  I've had the Bun Rieu (Tomato Crab Noodle Soup) there and it was delish too - clean tasting tomato broth with chunks of juicy crab & shrimp meatball.   This is like eating in your mom's kitchen!

For dessert, pick any one of the many to take home - I love the one with the tropical fruit and little jellies in coconut milk.

Being a recreational vegetarian every few weeks, I was so happy to see that they have tons of Viet veggie dishes that are hard to find in other places, like tofu spring rolls & the aforementioned Bun Rieu!  I'll have to test next time when I'm in a non meat mode...
author: Josie M.

description: I still love their BBQ chicken sandwich but I hate the huge chunk of  chicken fat/skin that comes with it. I think I will stick to Lee's it is cheaper and and there isn't a huge chunk of fat/skin on the chicken! But if I am in this area course I will have to resort to this instead of Y&Y. But a plus is that the bread and chicken is really toasty and warm when you get it.
author: Janet Z.

description: Excellent sandwiches!  Really like the grilled Lemon grass pork sandwiches. Good service.  I've been a customer for a couple years!
author: Sparky W.

description: Tasty Pho and good Banh Mi - although the bread was a bit oversized for the fixin's, and not terribly French. The selection of rolls looked interesting, but we had our work cut out for us already.
author: Karsten P.

description: Absolutely savory and big Bahn Mi's are what this joint are about. Had the veggie sandwich and was thoroughly filled by the $4 spent, which usually doesn't happen with other Bahn Mi's in town. Good stuff!
author: Haz O.

description: The chicken sandwich was decent but not in the same league as Saigon Sandwiches (but then nothing is...my second favorite spot is Irving Cafe).  They put more cilantro in it than any place I've been to.  The meat was not bad.  The filling kept falling out of the bread which was annoying.  $3 is a lot though, given that it's not as good as Saigon or Irving.
author: Lolia S.

description: I will not hold against them the fact that I somehow managed to get jalapeno juice all over my lips and tongue, thus causing what is currently feeling like a third degree burn. That being said, I just wolfed down a sandwich and feel like I could eat three more. This place is goooooood!
author: Dixon T.

description: Very good food.  Just make sure to call ahead. a bit slow.
author: Randy W.

description: Dee-lious!  Although my eight yr old is a much better vegetarian than I am, we can both get something we like at Little Vietnam!  I like the pre-packed trays of yummy tasty food on the counter...cheap, too.  Meat and non-meat selections galore!  Whenever I need to bring food to a potluck, I stop by and pick out a few trays (better than my cooking).  Try the lemongrass tofu....wow, it is an instant favorite of everyone who tries it!  The sandwiches are ok....I still miss Little Paris and I crave Ba Mi in the hood in oaktown....but if you need a fix, then you can't go wrong.......
author: Valerie L.

description: I had this strong desire for some Banh Mi(vietnamese sandwhich) this weekend.  I saw that there were several places around the clement area that sold them.  I remember seeing this place listed on yelp so I checked it out.  At this point I've only had Banh Mi in SF from that food truck that comes to my office every so often, it's a green truck, I forget the name, but it's pretty popular.  Anyways I found LVC to have a very good Banh Mi, cheaper than the food truck which is priced at $7, I believe here it costed me $4.5.  The bread was perfectly crunchy, very generous on the fillings(I had the pate sandwhich)  Excellent staff and very quick.  Plus everyone at LVC was actually Vietnamese, so you know that it's authentic.  I am Vietnamese so I like to get Vietnamese food from Vietnamese people, Chinese food from Chinese people, etc.  I will be coming back.  I may upgrade this review to 5 stars if I can't find a better place.
author: Thomas Crown O.

description: Love this place! They're so friendly, and everything I've tried here has been delicious (the pho broth in particular is great, not too salty). Prices are reasonable too. Nice to sit outside on a pleasant day or squeeze in to one of the small tables inside.
author: Geoffrey U.

description: Luv luv luv all their food!  The sandwiches are definitely to die for especially when they are hot. Service is fast and friendly. Definitely a gem in the Richmond. We go often.
author: CR L.

description: I went to an event that had food from this place and surprisingly, it was good!  Spring rolls are my absolute favorite food in the whole wide world and this place did great - they had rolls with beef, shrimp or tofu.  There were also egg rolls with carrots and pork, I think.  It was also tasty.  My only complaint would be that the rolls are kinda large.  I was next to someone who had rolls that were coming apart because they were so big.  Note for next time: Bigger doesn't always mean better!
author: Lynnie P.

description: this place is pretty good.  The noodle soup is always great, however, the  Vietnamese sandwhiches are inconsistent (sometimes amazing, sometimes not so good).  Their pre-wrapped food is a treat though.  Whenever I'm on the run I stop by this spot for some three bean desert or some fresh rolls (w/chicken or pork).
author: Paul Michael A.

description: Very basic place that sells a few Vietnamese staples. I only had their excellent banh mi - be sure to get the spicy version (if you like it hot ;) ) - and their iced coffee. This $6 is hard to beat, that's why I'm going there often :)
author: Dumitru E.

description: I was sad when Little Paris closed and there was no Vietnamese sandwich shop in the Richmond district and more specifically on Clement.  I was thrilled when the Little Vietnam Cafe opened up because their sandwiches are even better than Little Paris'.   I've only tried their sandwiches (try the grilled pork is the best--so tasty) and the spring rolls and tofu (packaged).  A plus--they are opened late (after work hours)!
author: Marie B.

description: Yum! I tried this place on Saturday and it was great. I'd never had a Vietnamese sandwich before, but you can bet I will again. I had the tofu sandwich, and it was just delicious. My friend had the pork sandwich, which she also loved, and the Vietnamese coffee, which I tried and we both thought was great. I can't wait to go back! I love tiny little places like this. We grabbed a seat in the window, and the owner was so nice and friendly and kept talking to us. Can't wait to go back!
author: Janet G.

description:
--disclaimer: this was my first vietnamese sandwich experience. the credibility of my opinion to this cafe's authenticity is not guaranteed.--

i walk by this whole-in-the-wall on a weekly basis & didn't get around to stopping by until this week. coming home from the library in the rain, little vietnam seemed like a great choice for lunch. i was not disappointed.  there were two older men chowing down on their sandwiches at the short counter so my boyfriend & i decided to give them a try. we ordered two pork sandwiches from the nice young lady at the counter. they were hot & ready in minutes: at only $4 a piece!! the bread was perfectly crisp on the outside & fluffy on the inside, the pork was cooked to perfection, the veggies added a crunchy texture, & the cilantro was abundant! my mouth is watering just thinking about it.

i will be walking the one block from my apartment to get a sandwich or salad, or whatever else they will sell me, on a regular basis.
author: Lizzy L.

description: fresh inexpensive food that tastes great. Staff is cheerful too.  A great place to pick up healthy food quickly
author: Tina F.

description: I love the fact that I can usually just run in here in the morning and grab a sanwich for lunch.  My favorite is the combo ham with peppers.  For $3.50 they are pretty big.  I think sometimes I come in too early cause half the time they are just setting up shop.  But when they are fully set up they have all this little to go things all wrapped up.  When I am in the mood to pig out...I usually get the spring rolls and the bun with my sandwich.  I still haven't tried the pho here as I usually go to the sister restaurant Vietnam on Broadway.
author: Allison T.

description:
very good sandwiches.  

Not sure if it was something else we ate, but gave us indigestion that day.
author: Bob D.

description: I'm all about the lemongrass bbq pork bahn mi!  It's always the young, friendly girl working... she's the best, and her bahn mi she whips up in the back are a great way to drop a few bucks for a quick lunch.
author: Cooper S.

description: One of my biggest pet peeves with Vietnamese sandwiches is when the proportions are off. Most of the time there is either too much bread or cilantro or too little meat or pickled carrots. The $3.50 pork sandwich I had was perfect. The cafe is a tiny, so plan on making it a take out meal.
author: Michael A.

description: Awesome little cafe!!!! i live right down the block and whenever I'm hungry or don't have anything for dinner I walk to this place and always order their pork or chicken vietnamese sandwich for only $4.50!! it is soooo good! PERFECT. the owners are super nice and so sweet!!! And also their imperial fried rolls and spring rolls are also phenomenol! It's fresh so get them while they make it!
author: Iba N.

description: yummy, i love this place, fast, tasty, friendly service, filling sandwiches, fresh ingredients, reasonable prices
author: bucky c.

description:
i like their banh mi here.  it's wonderful tasting and fresh.  in fact, i think that they have one of the better banh mi sandwiches i've had (tofu).

but the last time i went they're spring rolls were not so springy (fresh).
i can't justify giving them a higher rating at this time, because they had these things out on the counter, and there is no way for a passerby to see whether or not they're fresh.

also, in general, i find their spring rolls to be a bit under prepared.
it wouldn't be too hard to make a bunch of smaller ones instead of this heaping mound that approaches the tenacity of a burrito (without the flavor).
author: linden d.

description: Fresh! Juicy! Yummy! Excellent banh mi. And friendly people, too.
author: Fawn F.

description: They make good Vietnamese sandwiches. I always order the BBQ chicken. It makes for a cheap and delicious meal. I'd have to order at least two to feel somewhat full. It's been Clement's replacement for Little Paris since they shut down due to health risks.
author: Armstrong B.

description:
my sis' bbq chicken rice plate was excellent.

my chicken pho SUCKS..plenty of rice noodles with WATER.. not even chicken broth

fast orders and service.

convenient location
author: Sue S.

description: I love this cafe! The food is fresh and especially the sandwiches are so delicious. Spring rolls either fried or not are great too. I have been to many Vietnamese delis but this one is by far the best. Lee's Sandwiches can't beat their sandwiches. The staff is very friendly. I usually go there at least once a week and also on weekends. Highly recommended. I am glad that they are getting more business after they were featured on SFgate.com.
author: MS K.

description: Finally, the return of Vietnamese sandwiches near the Clement!!  This joint is a nice replacement of Little Paris.  They have $3 grilled chicken or combo ham sandwiches.  Lots of grab-and-go plates on the counter to choose from.  I'm a bit hesitant to try the pho here since the place is so small and lacks seating.
author: Mick S.

description: Aptly named, this tiny minuscule Vietnamese sandwich shop can be a hit or miss, sometimes the meat can be tender and juicy or dry and under seasoned. The bread can also be nice and soft like a Phillie cheesesteak Amoroso roll or completely dry on the outside. Luckily I haven't run into both at the same time. I think this place is owned by the same people who run the Vietnam travel agency next door as I have walked into the cafe with nobody at the counter when all of a sudden somebody from next door runs in and takes my order. I like all there Grab n' Go items such as all the various fresh rolls and their lemongrass tofu. I will give the benefit of a doubt and give them four stars bcuz although the sandwiches aren't up to Saigon Sandwiches standards in the TL, they still are better Than Little Paris ( I still miss them and the friendly man behind the counter though).
author: Brian J.

description: I've only gotten their bahn mi and have been disappointed.  The roll falls apart in your hands as you try to eat it (and this bread I can get at my local Korean green grocer).  The veggies weren't pickled much so they lacked that nice pucker.  No onions in the sandwich at all.  Pate and veggies are add-in at 50 cents.  I think I can make better (which is just sad, sad, sad).
author: Kai T.

description: This cafe is small and offers ok Vietnamese sandwiches. It takes them like 6 minutes to make a sandwich and its not worth the wait or effort to go to this place.
author: Prescott T.

description: I love this place for sitting down and on the go. Food here kicks butt with great taste and quality. If you got the time sit down and enjoy a big bowl of Pho and if your not try one of their special Viet sandwiches or prepack meals. In all you'll leave with a smile, full stomach, and a very minor expensived meal.
author: David M.

description:
great for lunch. and cheap!

the sandwiches are bomb. did i mention cheap??? it's a small place, so it might not be a good idea to bring a group of hungry people here. order for pick up instead.

parking sucks.
author: Rosalee C.

description: Three  stars for the friendly service I had at 8 am on Thursday morning... they had just opened, but kind enough to make me a combination sandwich to go for my lunch that day. I must say that the sandwich  was not bad... but it was not great either! First, the taste was alright for their pickle vegetable and they rather cheap about putting it on my sandwich. I had way much better sandwiches before... so, it was really okay... don't know if I would buy more sandwiches from them. I think I'll try somewhere else.
author: Daisy S.

description: This place is awesome - the sandwiches and imperial rolls are top-notch, and the prices can't be beat. I highly recommend stopping by. Go on a weekday when the bread is the freshest.
author: Mary C.

description:
There's not too many good Vietnamese sandwich and/ rolls in Clement - Geary area, thus this one fit right in to that particular 'need.'  I love this place, partly b/c it is consistent and cheap, and partly because the owners/workers are very 
nice.  I go there to grab quick lunch to go and to order for gatherings/meetings.   I wish that someone would invest a tiny bit of money in this business and help them make the space more attractive, like a tidier counter and/ shinier flooring. Other than that, check it out and support small businesses!
author: Angie H.

description:
great iced coffee for about $3.  they have a coffee / sandwich combo for $6 out the door.  i love this place for to go.  theres not much in the way of seating, but you can grab one of the two small 2 person tables outside to bask in the sun.  

great little joint, the people are really friendly.
author: Jason J.

description: A small little vietnamese cafe mainly for take-out.  There is however about 5 seats facing the windows if you're really desperate to dine-in.  I ordered the grill pork sandwich for $3.  Like a standard vietnamese sandwich, it's a french baguette filled with pickle carrots, cilantro, jalapeno pepper and the meat, spread with mayo.  First of all, the bread is not toasty and crispy, it's chewy.  Also, the sandwich can use more dressing, the one I ate is kinda dry.  Overall, I've taste better sandwiches.  Might be an ok spot if you're just looking for a quick lunch, but I don't think I will return anytime soon.
author: Heidi F.

description: Great Banh Mi.  Got the Dac Biet (combo) and it was stuffed with meat and veggies.  Good french roll too.  So often the most crucial part of a sando (the bread) falls short and is neglected.  Not here.
author: Al K.

description: Excellent. A wonderful addition to a neighborhood with great eats. - The roast pork sandwich is fantastic, as are the vegetarian imperial rolls. We enjoyed the lemongrass pork over rice and the Vietnamese shrimp rolls in peanut sauce. Service is very friendly and the tiny restaurant is clean and well maintained. - The coffees are also excellent and the choice of drinks is much better than usually found. - You'll leave stuffed and ecstatic.
author: Eric F.

description: great for lunch on the run. Love their spring rolls and vermicelli bowls.
author: Cristina C.

description: I purchase lunch or dinner here at least once a week, and I LOVE it.  Usually go for the tofu Banh Mi (perfect bread, just crusty enough, and good veggies), but I've also enjoyed their spring rolls and marinated tofu.  It is so cheap - you can buy a hearty dinner for two for $15.
author: A W.

description: This place is great, the spring rolls are top notch with a peanut sauce that has just the right level of sweetness, and sandwiches that are second only to Saigon Sandwiches.   I also dig the weird drinks with virus-looking eyeballs in them, but I think those might be outsourced.  All in all, some seriously good eatin!
author: Isaac H.

description:
I ought to stop being surprised anymore...I realize SF has higher standards for eating establishments than other cities, but whenever I picture a little inexpensive takeout-only Vietnamese place with yummy sandwiches, I picture a grimy little hole with illegible menus and creepy-crawlies running around in dark corners.

Little Vietnam Cafe, however, is a delight from the moment you walk through the door to the moment you are licking your fingers clean back home (or, at times in my case, driving in my car 4 blocks away, with bread crumbs in my lap and down my shirt...so much for hands-free!).  

Clean and bright, with an attractive display of all kinds of rolls and colorful, scrumptious-looking desserts; delicious and reasonably-priced sandwiches, spring rolls, garden rolls.  I was lucky to even catch the spring rolls hot and fresh last time I was there--yum!!  I have to try the noodles next time I'm there.  Did I mention how prompt and friendly the service is?  What's not to love?  If I lived any closer, I would never cook.
author: Yvette H.

description: The consensus has it right -  4 stars - and I love vietnamese.
author: r g.

description:
The BBQ pork sandwich is pretty decent, and so is the vermicelli noodle dish. It's a small place really meant for take-out, but there are a few counter seats, too. 

Asian tip of the day: If you don't eat your Vietnamese sandwich right then and there, the bread will get hard really fast. So if you can, eat it ASAP.
author: William S.

description:
This place is a tiny dive with some the best 5 spice chicken and lemongrass pork Vietnamese sandwiches in the city. Most Vietnamese sandwich places offer versions of bbq chicken and pork sandwiches, but use these as an opportunity to foist off grizzly. fatty mystery meat. Not so at Little Vietnam, where these sandwiches are instead happily filled with healthy portions or tender and juicy chicken and pork. 

One star from perfection because they recently raised their prices to $4 a sandwich.
author: Kelly D.

description:
I tried this place on sunday and the vietnamese sandwichs are so good!!!! I got the pork sandwich and it was huge.
This place is cheap and it fills you up.  The three dollar spring rolls are a super deal and tasty. I prob come back 2m to get another sandwich.
author: Jason L.

description: We tried our first Vietnamese sandwiches here. What a treat! The papaya salad was excellent as well- fresh, filling, and affordable. Go for friendly service and yummy food, not ambiance (the dining area is tiny). This might become a regular place for take-out.
author: Sarah A.

description: delicious bahn mi!  they are very generous with the amount of meat/tofu and veggies that they give in the sandwiches.  you can get the vietnamese coffee and sandwich as a combo deal.
author: Sheri N.

description: The food is not authentic!  I have been exposed to vietnamese food all my life, never have I encountered a goi cuon with so much vermicelli and lettuce in it.  Yes, the rolls were huge, but where is the fresh mint or the protein?  The rolls broke apart after one bite, and all you can taste is the lettuce and the vermicelli.  Very disappointing!!!
author: Leslie C.

description: Cute little spot that I tried once before where I got the BBQ lemongrass pork banh mi.  The meat was quite tasty, however the bread didn't quite hold everything together, and the sauce was just OK. It just doesn't match the perfectly toasted baguette that Saigon Sandwich uses (along with their tastier-than-ever sauce) that'll hold up even until the next day!  However, if the TL is too far from where you live (and you need to pick up a quick lunch on the way to work), then I'd say that Little Vietnam cafe is adequate.  I found a hair in my banh mi today (this is my second time getting a sandwich from there), so that kinda bummed me out.  But hey, it happens.  Hairnets should do the trick in the future.  I prob won't be trying another banh mi from here, personally, but I'll have to come back and try the soups.  The ladies were friendly and service was fast, so I'm not gonna knock em down just for one item on the menu that I wasn't too thrilled about.
author: Arama M.

description: I think the combination ham sandwich is the best there although they don't give you too much meat.  The bread was actually old bread where it all fell apart.  All their rolls are pretty good as well.  Overall, I think their sandwiches are tastier and better than Saigon Sandwiches.
author: Mary L.

description: my vietnamese sandwich fix has been fixed! their stuff is good and hits the spot. i had to minus a point because it was $4 for a sandwich, which i hardly think is appropriate.
author: Regina C.

description: awesome vegetarian food!  so good i try not to go more than 1x week!  perfect stop for food to eat there or for on the go.
author: Nothin G.

description: Not bad for the price. The amount of meat they put in is perfect. Their bread is nothing special it's the same as all the other places in Inner Richmond, even the same as Saigon Sandwiches. You can buy the bread on Clement they are 4 for $1.00.
author: Rick C.

description: This is a simple cafe with good food. Pretty much you grab and go. You can get a sandwich or wrap for about $4.00 bucks, which seems like a good deal to me.  The people are very nice and it makes a great snack if you are going to the park or just happen to be in the Richmond. They many other food offerings in their glass case, but you would have to ask the proprietor what they are because I have no idea.  Worth a try especially if you never had a Vietnamese sandwich.
author: Niko P.

description: the owner knows me by my face.  i have came here a lot in the past and ordered either fancy pork or combination viet sandwich.  this is a great place to pick up some viet food whenever you're in a hurry for lunch/dinner.  another good thing about this place is that the food is VERY CHEAP!
author: Henry K.

description: This place kicks balls. the bun mi is out of this world, and cheap.
author: Patrick A.

description: Ate here today and loved it.  Had a bahn mi and a papaya salad -- both were spectacular and super cheap.  The sandwich was top flight:  hot, fresh bread, delicious pork, peppers that were crisp but not oppressive.  The papaya salad was the perfect mix of crisp, tart, sweet, savory and spicy.  The pipikalua/beef jerky on it was the perfect addition.  Get some!
author: Owen B.

description: Love this place, fast, fresh, authentic, convenient, and super nice family.
author: Charlie C.

description: When I'm shopping on Clement, getting abused by old ladies and their plastic bags, I get hungry.  I want food fast, but not fast food.  Little Vietnam!  I love the lemongrass pork sandwiches.  One of these days I'm gonna try something else on the menu.
author: Gabe N.

description: Very friendly service, reasonable prices, and very tasty food.
author: Snow B.

description: I would give this place zero stars if I could. I am a Vietnamese sandwich expert. I know my stuff.  Little Vietnam Cafe is a poor excuse for a Vietnamese restaurant.  Their sandwiches are utter disgraces to the Vietnamese cuisine.  The bread was soggy, not crispy as it should be.  There was not enough meat. It was poorly seasoned.  Because it was so soft, the sandwich fell apart before you could even bite into it.  I bought three sandwiches on my first and last visit.  Purchased the chicken, pork and combo.   I judge a sandwich shop by their combination sandwich. A true banh mi dac biet (combo) consists of slices of pork, pork skin, pate, and cha lua (a type of vietnamese sausage/meat).  Little Vietnam's cafe sandwich consists of regular cured American ham, a slice of cha lua, and american mayonnaise.  It was horrific!!!!  If you want an authentic sandwich, I strongly suggest another sandwich place.  Do not visit this shop!!!
author: Vivian T.
